HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

Now Playing

"ALL THE REAL GIRLS," starring Paul Schneider, Zooey Deschanel and Patricia Clarkson. Written and directed by David Gordon Green (R, 108 minutes). Mr. Green follows "George Washington," his luminous found fable of Southern childhood, with a more conventional story of young love. Mr. Schneider plays a small-town cad whose easygoing promiscuity is derailed by Ms. Deschanel, whose character has just returned home from boarding school. Their sweet, fumbling romance is captured with scruffy, low-key lyricism. The film is an awkward hybrid of free-form, do-it-yourself filmmaking and professional discipline (supplied by the wonderful Ms. Deschanel, and by Ms. Clarkson), but its beauty and sincerity overcome its flaws and hesitations (A. O. Scott).

* "CITY OF GOD," starring Alexandre Rodrigues, Leandro Firmino da Hora and Seu Jorge. Directed by Fernando Meirelles (R, 130 minutes; in Portuguese, with English subtitles). A scorching anecdotal history of gang warfare in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, "City of God" is narrated by Rocket (Mr. Rodrigues), a young photographer who chronicles the deterioration of the housing project in which he grew up from a shantytown into a war zone. The movie, which begins in the 1960's and ends in the early 80's, parallels Rocket's story with the rise of his childhood playmate Li'l Ze (Mr. da Hora) from a petty thief into a ruthless drug dealer and neighborhood kingpin commanding a small army of gun-toting children. The history is told in a loose, tall-tale style that suggests a quasi-cinema-verite version of Martin Scorsese's "Goodfellas" (Stephen Holden).

"DAREDEVIL," starring Ben Affleck, Jennifer Garner, Colin Farrell and Michael Clarke Duncan. Written and directed by Mark Steven Johnson (PG-13, 96 minutes). Sometimes playing a comic-book hero gives actors a chance to show suave, stylized moves. After stripping off their civvies, they emerge from the phone booth a star. Christopher Reeve gave a breezy, farcical charge to Superman and Clark Kent. As Batman and his alter ego, the wastrel playboy Bruce Wayne, Michael Keaton seemed to have a thousand things on his mind, most of them unpleasant. But poor Ben Affleck is lost in the minor, passable "Daredevil," where he portrays the blind, red-costumed and horn-headed crime fighter whose other senses -- hearing, touch, taste -- were exaggerated in the chemical accident that cost him his sight. A big man, Mr. Affleck is shriveled by the one-dimensional role. Even his scarlet leather outfit makes him diminutive. The interlocked double D on his left breast makes him look like part of the food-service industry: "Hi, I'm Daredevil, and I'll be your superhero this evening" (Elvis Mitchell).

"FINAL DESTINATION 2," starring Ali Larter, A. J. Cook and Michael Landes. Directed by David R. Ellis (R, 97 minutes). This gleefully morbid sequel may, in the end, be as nonsensical as its title, but it's also much more imaginative. Ms. Larter is Clear Rivers, the sole survivor of the first "Final Destination," who has locked herself away to hide from the grisly death she is sure must be stalking her. Ms. Cook is Kimberly, who has foreseen, and escaped, a horrific traffic accident and is now similarly stalked. But death, which turns out to have a macabre and elaborate sense of humor, gets all the best material, and the filmmakers delight in staging a series of ghoulishly slapstick demises, involving pigeons and refrigerator magnets as well as the more traditional exploding cars and out-of-control elevators. The spirit of the movie is best summed up in the following line, spoken by a television news reporter after one such death. "Ironically, the woman was impaled through the head after her air bag inflated." Ironically indeed (Scott).

* "GANGS OF NEW YORK," starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Daniel Day-Lewis and Cameron Diaz. Directed by Martin Scorsese (R, 165 minutes). Long awaited, enormously expensive, endlessly gossiped about, Mr. Scorsese's brutal epic of mid-19th-century Manhattan is a near-great film that, as time goes by, may well make up the distance. As has happened before with this director's films, the fairly conventional story -- a revenge tragedy pitting a young Irish immigrant (Mr. DiCaprio) against his father's killer, a nativist warlord (Mr. Day-Lewis) -- is less interesting than the setting. Mr. Day-Lewis gives his character, known as Bill the Butcher, an earthy Shakespearean grandeur. In his mouth the rough vernacular of the old New York streets becomes poetry. If Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Diaz (in the underimagined role of a spirited pickpocket) don't shed their movie-star auras, they do show themselves to be intrepid and engaging actors. But the real achievement of the movie is the way it brings history to life, not merely by meticulously recreating its details but by offering a troubling and timely interpretation of how the violence and iniquity of the past continues to ramify into the present. The film, flawed and indelible, is nothing less than an attempt to re-imagine the germs of America's historical identity (Scott).

"HOW TO LOSE A GUY IN 10 DAYS," starring Kate Hudson, Matthew McConaughey and Bebe Neuwirth. Directed by Donald Petrie (PG-13, 100 minutes). Yet another mediocre New York romantic comedy, yes, but notably less mediocre than "Maid in Manhattan" and "Two Weeks Notice." This is because Ms. Hudson and Mr. McConaughey are an energetic, well-matched comic pair, and because the writers have smuggled a few sharp, funny jokes into the lockstep conventions of the plot. The premise, too, has a nice frost of screwball cynicism, as the two principals woo each other for venal, professional reasons. Ben (Mr. McConaughey), a tomcatting ad man, must make a woman fall in love with him if he is to win a big account; to write a feature story for a women's magazine, Andie (Ms. Hudson) must drive a man away. Would you believe that they actually fall in love? Nobody would, but it's sometimes fun to pretend, just as it's fun to pretend that the advertising and magazine industries are untouched by recession, the Knicks are in the N.B.A. finals and Staten Island is full of people who talk as if they're from Texas (Scott).

"LOST IN LA MANCHA," with Terry Gilliam. Written and directed by Keith Fulton and Louis Pepe (R, 89 minutes). After watching this fascinating and compelling new documentary, you may forever wonder how it is that movies are made at all. "Lost" may not be a great piece of filmmaking, but it is a great story; its directors display dramatic intelligence. "Lost" is an inside view of how a film -- in this case, Mr. Gilliam's "Man Who Killed Don Quixote" -- can fall to pieces, even under the guidance of a master director. Imagine watching a real-life version of Ian McKellen's kindly, indomitable Gandalf in "Lord of the Rings" give his life for his cause, only to find that his supreme gesture is meaningless because his fellows are slaughtered anyway. That's what "Lost" is like. What's clear and astonishingly entertaining about "Lost" is that the directors' only good luck was that they happened to be safely behind the scenes when epic mishaps struck so often on the set that Beelzebub probably put in for overtime (Mitchell).

"THE RECRUIT," starring Al Pacino, Colin Farrell and Bridget Moynahan. Directed by Roger Donaldson (PG-13, 105 minutes). The C.I.A. setting, the utterly predictable plot twists, the chase scenes and the climactic bout of gunplay may suggest a thriller, but really this slick and pointless exercise belongs to a more specialized genre: the Al Pacino crazy-mentor picture. This time, Mr. Pacino is Walter Burke, whose job is to recruit and train intelligence operatives. "I have a scary eye for talent," he says. What Mr. Pacino displays is his peculiar, and often amusing, gift for ranting, spluttering and braying, and his wildly unpredictable, borderline-incoherent performance is the only interesting thing in the movie. Mr. Farrell, as Burke's troubled protege, James Clayton, an M.I.T. graduate student who seems to have misplaced his shaving kit in all the excitement, works very hard without producing anything like the casual, nutty intensity Mr. Pacino can summon so effortlessly. Ms. Moynahan is James's fellow trainee and love interest, who may or may not be a mole (Scott).

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer Garner and Ben Affleck, as a blind crime fighter with heightened senses, in "Daredevil." (Zade Rosenthal/20th Century Fox)

HEADLINE: Inside the Music: A Cellist's Perspective 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
CARTER BREY could be having a major solo career. He used to have just that, appearing with virtually every leading orchestra in the United States, becoming the first musician to win the Arts Council of America's Performing Arts Prize and earning international attention as a prizewinner in the Rostropovich International Cello Competition.
 Instead, since 1996, Mr. Brey has been playing cello with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. True, he is principal cellist, which means he leads the section. Otherwise, though, he is no different from the 11 other cello players, several of whom could also have solo careers but instead perform about 34 weeks of subscription concerts a year, as well as tours and special appearances. 
 For those attending a concert, it is rare to know much about the musicians beyond the music they make together. To most audiences they are little more than a sea of anonymous figures in black, bent over their music stands. But singling out one section of the New York Philharmonic -- the cellists -- for a closer look offers some sense of the varied, complex, accomplished individuals behind the instruments. As a group that helps to depict the sunrise in "La Mer" by Debussy and to establish the theme of the Offertorio section of Verdi's Requiem, they are an integral part of the top-flight 106-member ensemble known as the New York Phil. 
At the end of every performance, the cellists pack their instruments -- which can cost anywhere from $40,000 brand new to $5 million for the rarest of Stradivarius -- away in their hulking cases and haul them back into their personal lives. The players range in age from their early 30's to their late 70's. Some have been with the orchestra for 40 years; others joined more recently. All are adjusting to a new maestro, Lorin Maazel, who took over the baton from Kurt Masur this season. All have taken different routes to this point in their careers and have particular reasons for deciding to perfect the sometimes understated but often lyrical, insinuating instrument that is the cello.
During the week between Christmas and New Year in 1995, Mr. Brey was washing the dishes when the phone rang. He and his wife had just had a second child, and he was preparing to go on yet another concert tour, wondering what was wrong with this picture. The more successful his solo career became, the more it took him away from home. The larger his family grew, the less he wanted to travel. The call was from Catherine Cahill, then general manager of the Philharmonic, who invited him to audition for the position of principal cellist; Lorne Munroe was retiring.
"It couldn't have been better scripted by Frank Capra," said Mr. Brey, now 48. "In the space of a few seconds, it appeared to me this would be the perfect solution."
He auditioned on a hot and sultry Tuesday the following May. Preparing wasn't simple; having concentrated on solo performing, Mr. Brey said, he needed to reacquaint himself with the orchestral repertory. He rehearsed meticulously for the audition, he said, and was one of 14 finalists. "Auditions are peculiar," he said. "You have to go in for a limited amount of time and prove something about yourself."
"I had an attitude of pleasurable expectancy," Mr. Brey continued. "The pleasure is particular and intense. I was very relaxed after the first 10 minutes." By the time he was through, a thunderstorm had started.
"I walked all the way home in the rain," he said. "I ruined my suit."

Supporting Actors, Not Stars
Ask cellists to define the part the cello plays in an orchestra, and they describe it as subtle but essential. "It's a foundation role," said Eric Bartlett, 45, who joined the orchestra in 1997. "It provides stability and structure."
Rather than supplying the main melody, the cello generally supports it. "It's hard to be the background," Evangeline Benedetti said.
At the same time, Ms. Benedetti added, the cello is "a very sensuous instrument, a great part of the musical sound," she said. "Because of its range, it makes a huge contribution."
Avram A. Lavin said the cello was more versatile than many other instruments. "It's an instrument that has unlimited possibilities; it has the widest range of any string instrument," he said. "It can be a soprano, and it can be a bass, and I think it's generally accepted that the total quality comes closest to the human voice."
"The cello is a solo instrument, though not as popular as the violin or piano," Mr. Lavin continued. "There's no doubt that the first violin section has some of the most demanding material. However, the cello mostly plays a middle voice. It would be hard to rate instruments in terms of importance, because if you take any of them away, you have no orchestra."
Mr. Lavin, who auditioned for the New York Philharmonic in spring 1963, is in his 40th season with the orchestra. He is 77 -- "but you don't have to stress that," he said. In World War II, he played in the Signal Corps String Quartet that gave concerts around the world. "It certainly was better than getting shot up," he said.
He was reared in Chicago. His father was a violinist; his mother played piano. "I think my parents wanted to have a trio, so they stuck me with the cello," he said.
"It's an interesting life," he added. "I don't think hard is the right word. After all these years, I wouldn't want to do anything else."
Hai-Ye Ni, 30, auditioned for the position of associate principal cellist in 1999.Having made her New York debut at Alice Tully Hall in 1991 and become, at 18, the youngest musician to win first prize at the Naumburg International Cello Competition, Ms. Ni had never auditioned for an orchestra before. One of 99 applicants, she was sent a list of pieces to prepare, including two cello concertos, one by Dvorak and one by Haydn.
"It was really scary," Ms. Ni said. "I was quite nervous, and I remember Mr. Masur made me play through the solo in Brahms's third movement of his second Piano Concerto."
"He wanted it a certain way, wanted it a little slower," she recalled. "He said, 'Imagine you're an older person playing this theme at the end of your day.' "
Born in Shanghai, Ms. Ni began studying cello with her mother, also a cellist, when she was about 7. In 1985 she moved to the United States to study. "I love the sound of the cello," she said.
As associate principal cellist, Ms. Ni occasionally leads the section in Mr. Brey's absence. Describing the role of principal, she said, "Sometimes I relate what the conductor wants to the section; other times I interpret what he wants."
When Mr. Brey was a member of the Cleveland Orchestra, he spent two seasons sitting in the last chair of the cello section. Leading a section for the New York Philharmonic is very different. As just a member of the section, "you're a cog in someone else's musical machine," he said. "Being section leader was a strain on my self-confidence. It took me a full season to grow comfortably into the role."
As principal, Mr. Brey has tried to draw on his past experience of being one of several musicians. "Players in the back of the cello section can feel disenfranchised, isolated from what's going on up front," he said. "I try to maintain lines of communication."
He said he also tried to create the aura of a chamber music group within an orchestra. "Most of what I do has to do with maintaining a sense of ensemble awareness," he said, "unanimity of articulation, phrasing, bowing." 
There are also psychological aspects to his role, he explained, and he tries to unify the group without meddling. "I have to play paterfamilias to the section," he said. "It's none of my business how anybody feels on a particular day except insofar as it affects their contribution to the playing."
Mr. Maazel credited Mr. Brey with giving the section its sense of cohesion and its high quality. "The tone is set by Carter, who's an amazing soloist, has a lovely sound -- technically without peer -- and knows the repertoire as few cellists do," Mr. Maazel said. "With someone like that sitting in the first chair as principal, a standard is set which the others feel they have to meet."
Indeed, Brinton Smith, 33, who joined the Philharmonic last September, said Mr. Brey played a large role in his decision to leave his post as the principal cellist of the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra. 
"He's unique among principal cellists," Mr. Smith said. "His hiring sent shock waves through the cello world. Not only is he good enough to have a major solo career, but he does such an important part. Having a leader everyone can look up to and respect makes such a huge difference in the way everybody feels and works together."

Where Women Made History
The orchestra has four rehearsals for each concert, the last one occasionally open to the public. The cellists are expected to practice their own parts before rehearsals. "The most difficult part of playing is you're onstage with 99 other people, and everybody can hear you," Ms. Ni said. "It can be very embarrassing if you come in a little early."
By the time they reach the Philharmonic, of course, cellists don't have to worry much about making mistakes; they are at the top of their field. Everyone in the section has been playing since childhood and has had extensive training and experience.
Qiang Tu, 38, who joined the Philharmonic in 1995, was taught the cello by his father, who asked a friend in an instrument factory in China to build small cellos for his children. Young Qiang wanted to play the tuba, but his father insisted on the cello. While Mr. Tu did not say so outright, it was clear that he was pushed hard by his father, something he does not want to repeat with his own two daughters. At one point, he had to stop talking because he was overcome by tears.
"I went through tough situations in my whole life," he said. "Everything now I really appreciate. I enjoy my own life even more because of all those tough things."
Mr. Tu made his solo debut at 13 in Beijing, and at 17, he won the Menuhin Prize in Britain as a member of the China Youth String Quartet. "It's part of my life," he said. "You have to love it if you want to do it well."
Ms. Benedetti, born in Austin, Tex., played French horn and bassoon as a youngster because she wanted to be in the band. But she felt especially lucky to be able to take free cello lessons at the University of Texas. "String instruments were scarce in Texas," she said.
In 1967, Ms. Benedetti, now 61, became the second woman to join the Philharmonic (Orin O'Brien, a bassist, was the first in 1966). "I'm in books about the history of music," she said.
Cello was less rare in Oklahoma City, where Nancy Donaruma grew up. In her own home her father played the violin and her mother the piano, and by the time she was in kindergarten, she knew many string quartets. "From the time I can remember, there was always music at my house," she said.
Ms. Donaruma, now 54, played concerts with her father at church and at weddings, and as a child she would watch the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic on television. "Someday," she would say to herself, "I'm going to play in that orchestra."
She did exactly that in 1976 as the ninth woman to join the Philharmonic. "It was a tremendous deal to get into this orchestra," she said.
It is female players like Ms. Benedetti and Ms. Donaruma who paved the way for women like Eileen Moon, 33, who joined the cello section in 1998. Ms. Moon, born in Northern California, started the cello at 10, attending music camp every summer and chamber music parties as a teenager. "It was what I did," she said. "Other people went to school dances and I went to youth orchestra."
Ms. Moon said she was sometimes overwhelmed by her position. "I feel very lucky, very blessed to be here," she said. "It's the New York Philharmonic. I went to Juilliard. It was always the orchestra."
As a result, she said, she lives her work intensely. "It can be rough on your psyche," she said. "Music for me really could never feel just like a job, and I sometimes struggle against that."
"In some ways, I wish I could be more laid back, not about the way I approach the job, but because of the way it comes back at me, the way it affects me," she continued. "It took me a long time to say, 'I'm going to work. I'm going to go to work and I'm just going to come home.' "
Mr. Brey said he felt a similar awe when he joined the Philharmonic. He grew up on the orchestra, traveling to the city from his childhood home in upstate South Salem, N.Y., for the Young People's Concerts.
"This was always my orchestra, my hometown orchestra, just asNew York was my city," he said. "To walk in and sit in the chair that had been occupied by Lorne Munroe and before that by Carl Stern and Laszlo Varga, it was a humbling experience. It was pretty scary that first season."
Mr. Brey, born in Montclair, N.J., came to the cello on his own. His mother was tone deaf, he said; his father was an artist. One of his earliest memories is of being home with the chicken pox and listening to Benjamin Britten after his father took home "The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra," a musical introduction written by Britten. "I'd always liked the sound of strings," Mr. Brey said.
"There was a great cellist who said, 'You don't choose music; music chooses you,' " Mr. Brey added. "At a certain age, I felt I couldn't live without it."
While the cellists play certain pieces over and over each season, they say their performances vary, depending on the music director. Their new maestro, Mr. Maazel, was the choice of the musicians if ever there was one. He was appointed after the orchestra made its preference for him clearly known, despite objections from music critics who called the decision conservative.
So far, the musicians say, so good. While some critics have faulted Mr. Maazel at times for being too much of a technician, the musicians say they appreciate that exactitude, that it makes their work smoother.
"It's easy to see exactly what he wants," Ms. Donaruma said. "It's a pleasure to work with somebody who is so easy to understand."
The cellists also say that they appreciate Mr. Maazel's extensive knowledge of the music and that he himself is a violinist.
"He's very professional, he's considerate of the musicians and he seems to be having a wonderful time," Mr. Bartlett said. "And that is infectious. Everyone seems to be feeding off that."
To be sure, Mr. Maazel said, "I'm just loving the job. This is an orchestra I can really relate to."

Adjusting to a New Leader
Nevertheless, Mr. Maazel has required some adjustment; music directors always do. "You have to get used to their stick technique," Ms. Donaruma said, referring to the baton, "how they say things and how they ask for things, get used to listening to their voice, what they do with their body, things that get communicated that aren't verbal."
"It's mostly personality," she added. "You hope they have some charisma, hope they have some innate musicianship inside their gut. If you don't have that, you're in trouble."
The cellists say Mr. Maazel and Mr. Masur have distinctly different styles. Mr. Maazel is more head, Mr. Masur more heart; Mr. Maazel is more contained, Mr. Masur more emotive. "They're about as different as two heads of corporate companies can be," said Elizabeth Dyson, 32, who started with the orchestra in 1996.
To be sure, there are those who feel a certain loyalty to the maestro who brought them in. "Masur gave me my job, and that's a very special thing," Ms. Moon said. But, she added, "I really enjoy having Maazel here. Maazel is accessible. Very clear."
Mr. Maazel said he has been impressed with the cellists: "I don't think I've ever encountered a cello section with so much talent. It's a very cohesive section. They work well together and have a great sense of camaraderie."
Zarin Mehta, executive director of the Philharmonic, says he likes what he hears. "There is more of a brilliant sound," he said, "a sureness of attack in the orchestra."
The cellists say they like to play a range of material. But they also have their personal favorites. Mr. Brey's is Mozart. "His music is everything that's perfect in art to me," Mr. Brey said. "Perfectly balanced, profoundly moving, funny, sexy. He accomplishes all of that with incredible economy of means."
Ms. Ni loves the Brahms Fourth Symphony. "Every time I play it, I always hear something new," she said. "There's always a line I never heard before."
Ms. Donaruma prefers Beethoven and Mahler. "Some of my biggest thrills have been playing big Mahler symphonies with Bernstein and Mehta," she said, speaking of the conductors Leonard Bernstein and Zubin Mehta.
Some critics have complained that the Philharmonic plays too traditional a repertory. Mr. Bartlett, who is a regular performer with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, said that he understood the need for a balance between modern and classical. "Personally, I prefer to do lots of contemporary music; I think today's composers need and deserve to have their music played," he said. "There are people who would come more, and there are clearly people who would come less."

Have Cello, Will Travel
By the end of July, the Philharmonic will have traveled for a total of seven weeks, including trips to Asia; Italy; Vail, Colo.; and the southeastern United States. The musicians described the traveling as both grueling and glamorous. On one hand, they have to hit the ground running, jumping into rehearsals and performances with little time to recover from jet lag. And many of them miss their families. "I'm always amazed how the orchestra sounds so good when people are tired," Ms. Ni said.
On the other hand, she pointed out, they are seeing the world, all expenses paid. "If I hadn't played cello, I probably would never have been to all these places," she said. "Visiting all these quarters of the world has opened up my being."
There is a more basic aspect of playing for the Philharmonic. It is the way these cellists pay the rent and put their children through school, like any other professionals. "I have used before the analogy that it is sort of like a marriage," Ms. Benedetti said. "Sometimes it works well; sometimes it doesn't; sometimes it's stormy."
"But," she added, "it's extraordinarily pleasing."
Ms. Donaruma chose the cello because it was easier than medical school. But she also became an emergency medical technician and now volunteers a few days a month at her home in upstate Beekman, N.Y. "I think I'm different from the rest of the section because I've reached a point in my life where cello isn't everything anymore," she said.
Despite his abiding passion for the cello, Mr. Brey said there were moments when it failed him. "At times I feel the limitations of the instrument," he said. "I wish often I were a violinist."
Still, the cellists say they feel lucky to be part of the Philharmonic and appreciate the caliber of their fellow players throughout the orchestra. 
"One of the advantages is, after I've been playing pieces all my life, I know my part so well I really get to listen to the other parts," Ms. Benedetti said. "After you've played Tchaikovsky's Fifth 250 times, you have to search for something new. 
"The high level of playing from colleagues is a delight," she continued. "I can hear one cymbal crash that's just crystal clear. That's beautiful."

A Philfest

HEADLINE: Development of Biotech Crops Is Booming in Asia 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHIANG RAI, Thailand, Feb. 16 

 BODY:
Worried about falling behind its global competition, much of Asia is rushing forward with the development and cultivation of genetically modified crops.
 The three most populous countries in Asia -- China, India and Indonesia -- are already planting millions of acres of genetically modified cotton. Several other large Asian countries, including Japan, Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia, are earmarking billions of dollars for private and government-sponsored research on biotech crops. 
 Given that there are already 145 million acres planted with genetically modified crops worldwide, mostly in North and South America, these developments in Asia could pave the way for bioengineered crops to dominate the world's food production. 
"This is a significant development in the acceptance of genetically modified crops," said Nicholas Kalaitzandonakes, a professor of agribusiness at the University of Missouri at Columbia. "This is not only a region where most of the population growth is, it's a region where most of the food growth is."
Aware of food safety concerns, especially among Europeans, most governments in Asia plan to move cautiously before approving the use of genetically modified food crops, which are much more controversial than nonfood crops like cotton and flowers. China for now is holding off on letting farmers plant biotech food crops, though tests are continuing.
But spending on biotech research and development is booming throughout Asia, according to delegates at a biotech policy conference sponsored here by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group.
Malaysia is creating a biotech hub outside Kuala Lumpur that it calls "biovalley." Indonesia is setting up its own industrial park, called "bioisland." Even in Japan and South Korea -- where some consumers have been unnerved by the prospect of genetically modified foods -- there are investors and others spending heavily to develop biotech products.
Experts at the conference said most of these countries must embrace biotechnology or risk seeing their crops lose value in a rapidly changing marketplace that promises a new breed of super crops.
"If they don't employ biotechnology, they're going to be left behind," said Dr. Cho Kyun Rha, a professor of biomaterial sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a conference participant. "They would end up buying the seed from others, and that would be biotech colonization."
China -- which after the United States has the most advanced biotechnology programs -- could come to dominate agricultural production in the region, because it is so far ahead in its research on genetically modified crops.
Already, a majority of the cotton grown in China, the world's leading producer, is genetically engineered to resist pests. Besides rice and tomatoes, China has developed genetically modified corn, tobacco, sweet peppers, petunias and poplar trees.
Other Asian countries, meanwhile, are beginning to release their first biotechnology products. India and Indonesia recently approved the planting of a variety of insect-resistant biotech cotton that drastically reduces the need for pesticides. 
Indeed, biotech cotton is so popular with farmers that a black market has emerged in several Asian countries that have not yet approved the products.
"There's piracy going on," said Clive James, head of the International Service for the Acquisition of Agri-Biotech Applications, an industry-sponsored organization that tracks global plantings of biotech crops. "These farmers think so much of this technology, they will steal it."
The enthusiasm extends beyond cotton. The Philippines has allowed the marketing of foods made with biotech corn, a first for Asia. The Philippines is also the site of the International Rice Research Institute, which is working to use biotechnology to develop "golden rice," a variety fortified with vitamin A. 
Critics of genetically modified crops say these moves in Asia could leave consumers around the world with little choice but to accept them.
"It's troublesome, because these countries don't have the regulatory infrastructure to assess the risks," said Dr. Jane Rissler of the Union of Concerned Scientists, an advocacy group that has been critical of biotech crops.
But in the absence of any solid evidence that genetically modified crops are harmful to humans, scientists in Asia are experimenting on everything from genetically modified corn, potatoes and papaya to biotech mustard and chili peppers. 
Biotechnology advocates in Asia believe that genetically modified crops will increase food production, significantly reduce the use of pesticides and insecticides and even create drought-resistant crops that can grow on land now regarded as non-arable. Farmers' incomes will rise, they claim, with the greatest benefits in the the poorest regions.
China has over 20,000 people employed in government-led research at about 200 labs. Government spending on biotech research has tripled in recent years and could top $1.5 billion for the five years ending in 2005, making China second only to the United States in this area. 
The rest of Asia is now playing catch up. India is conducting biotech research at most of its major universities. Japan and South Korea expect to spend over $300 million a year on biotech research. Malaysia wants to engineer palm oil trees genetically to serve as factories of specialized plastics for medical devices. Vietnam and Singapore, too, are exploring the development of portfolios of biotech crops.
China's enthusiasm is dictated from the top. But both there and in India -- places where small farmers work under the harshest conditions, often suffering from the effects of their own pesticide spraying -- biotech crops have mainly been seen as beneficial.
However, Japan, a major food importer, has been reluctant to accept genetically modified crops, because of concerns about food safety. Opposition in Europe has prompted China to place a moratorium on biotech food crops that had already been approved for commercialization.
Some experts say the world's largest seed and biotechnolgy companies are lobbying in Asia to promote genetically modified crops and to sway regulators and public opinion.
"They fear if they don't succeed there, the future could be a rocky one," said Neil Harl, a professor of agricultural economics at Iowa State University. "So there's this enormous effort under way."
There is a push -- articulated by several delegates at the conference here -- to coordinate regulatory, food labeling and trade policies to ensure the success of genetically modified foods.
"With today's globalization, you can't have some do it and some don't," said Dr. Chen Zhangliang, a professor at Beijing University and one of the leaders of China's biotechnology program, who delivered a fierce attack on biotech critics. "You need to have these issues harmonized." 
Some policy makers also worry that cross-border seed piracy could create legal trade and regulatory disputes. Biotech cotton leaked into India long before the country approved its planting. And pirated seeds are believed to be in wide use today in Thailand and Pakistan.
For many governments in Asia, though, biotechnology appears to be seen as a potential silver bullet for a host of food and agriculture ills, and a means to create new products that could sell for higher prices.
"We are trying to develop the blue orchid," said Sotat Sriwattanapong, who works at Biotec, a government agency in Bangkok. "It doesn't exist in nature. But this may attract the people or the market."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Are Up Sharply; Jobless Claims Also Higher 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
Prices paid to producers in January rose at the fastest pace in more than a decade, pushed up by rising energy and auto costs, the Labor Department said today in a report suggesting more evidence of inflation than expected.
 Overall producer prices climbed 1.6 percent, the largest rise since January 1990, surpassing forecasts of a 0.5 percent increase. This compared with a 0.1 percent decline in wholesale prices in December. 
 Excluding relatively volatile food and energy items, prices rose 0.9 percent, the fastest since December 1998 and also above forecasts of 0.1 percent.
The Federal Reserve and the financial markets will be looking at Friday's report on consumer prices for a more complete picture of inflation pressures.
In today's data, gasoline and home heating oil prices surged as cold weather increased demand and uncertainty over a possible war in Iraq pushed energy prices higher. Gasoline prices rose 13.7 percent; heating oil was up 19.7 percent.
Car prices posted their fastest increase since October 1986, rising 3.5 percent. Automakers cut back on financial incentives in January, pushing up prices.
In other areas, pharmaceutical costs climbed 1.2 percent and capital equipment prices rose 0.7 percent. Food prices were up 1.6 percent.
A report from the Labor Department today showed that the number of Americans seeking jobless benefits for the first time rose by 21,000, to a seasonally adjusted 402,000, in the week ended Feb. 15. Analysts had expected 382,000. Some economists consider claims above the 400,000 level a sign of a deteriorating job market. The four-week moving average, a more reliable gauge, rose to 394,750, an increase of 4,750 from the previous week. 
The Labor Department said it had to estimate jobless claims in states that had difficulty providing data because of the recent blizzard. But it added there was no reason to think that the estimates were skewed or that the total figures would be subject to large revisions. 
In a third report releasedtoday, a crucial economic forecasting gauge declined slightly in January. The Conference Board, a private research group, said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.1 percent, after a 0.2 percent rise in December. Many economists had expected a 0.1 percent rise. 
The Conference Board's chief economist, Ken Goldstein, said: "There's a chance we could be talking about a real recovery, not a jobless recovery, as early as the second quarter. There's a sense that there is forward momentum; it's there. The question is, Is this a mirage?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Decline on 4 Disappointing Reports on Economy

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors already edgy about the economy received new reasons to sell stocks yesterday with the release of four disappointing economic reports. In addition, worries about a potential war with Iraq and what it might do to the economy continued to depress the market. 
 Analysts said that investors were particularly unnerved by a jump in energy prices, fearing that costs will go up even more if there is a war with Iraq. 
 "People are unwilling to invest and make commitments until we get clarity on Iraq," said Brian Bush, director of equity research at Stephens Inc. 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 85.64 points, or 1.1 percent, at 7,914.96. The broader market also pulled back. The Nasdaq composite index declined 3.09 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,331.23. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.03 points, or 1 percent, to 837.10. 
Several disappointing economic reports pulled the market lower. First, there was news that the United States recorded a $435.2 billion trade deficit for 2002, the largest in history, as the weak global economy hampered American exports while imports of cars and other consumer goods reached record highs. 
And the Labor Department reported that inflation at the producer, or wholesale, level jumped 1.6 percent in January, the biggest increase in 13 years, led by a 4.8 percent increase in energy costs. The government also said the number of newly laid- off workers filing unemployment claims jumped to a seven-week high of 402,000 last week, up by 21,000 from the previous week. 
In the fourth report, the Conference Board said a crucial gauge of future economic activity declined in January. The industry group reported that its index of leading economic indicators slipped by 0.1 percent in January from a month ago, to a revised 111.2, which was weaker than the reading of unchanged that analysts had expected. 
"Iraq is essentially a wet blanket over the economy at this point," said Kevin Caron, market strategist at Ryan, Beck & Company. "When you get a slightly higher-than-expected jobless claims number and a rise in producer prices because of oil, there is some concern about the economy." 
Investors have been concerned that a war with Iraq will prompt consumers and businesses to further clamp down on spending, slowing what is already a sluggish economy. 
Target, the discount retailer, fell $1.10, to $26.77, after meeting fourth-quarter earnings expectations but reporting smaller-than-expected revenue. The company said sales at stores open at least one year fell 2.2 percent in the fourth quarter. 
Skechers U.S.A., which makes shoes, dropped $1.91, to $6.09, after it reported a fourth-quarter loss of 23 cents a share, more than the 21 cents that analysts expected. 
Kellogg fell $1.10, to $30.12, after Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded it to neutral from outperform. 
Gainers included J. C. Penney, which rose $1.34, to $19.77, after releasing fourth-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street's forecast. 
"No one is going to make a bet in this market until we think we are close to a resolution in Iraq," Mr. Bush of Stephens said. "That is what you are seeing in the weak volume." 
In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note increased 5/32 , to a price of 100 2/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.87 percent, from 3.89 percent on Wednesday. 
The 30-year bond rose 5/32 , to 108 21/32 . Its yield fell to 4.81 percent, from 4.82 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 22, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The "Hot and Cold" table in Business Day yesterday, listing stocks with large percentage gains and losses on Thursday, misstated the profit forecast for the drug maker Cephalon. While the company said its first-quarter earnings per share would be 20 cents, below analysts' expectations, it did not issue a warning for the full year.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DIPLOMACY; 
Korean Issue Shapes Powell's Asia Agenda

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell departs on Friday for a five-day trip to Asia intended to smooth over tensions with South Korea and build support for a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning North Korea's nuclear weapons program, administration officials said today.
 Though the official purpose of Mr. Powell's trip is to attend the inauguration of Roh Moo Hyun as South Korean's president on Tuesday, he will also stop in Tokyo and Beijing, with North Korea and Iraq at the top of his agenda, officials said. The United States is engaged in an even more urgent effort to get Security Council backing for a resolution endorsing the use of force against Iraq, a position not so far supported by China, one of the five veto-bearing permanent Council members. 
 Administration officials said Mr. Powell would try to reduce some of the differences separating Washington from the three major nations in Northeast Asia on the issue of North Korea. South Korea, Japan and China have urged the administration to engage in one-on-one talks with North Korea as soon as possible.
But administration officials have said they will not talk with North Korea about economic or security issues until it "steps back" from its nuclear programs. The officials have also said they will only meet with North Korea in a "multilateral forum," an offer North Korea has repeatedly rejected.
"There needs to be a way of making clear that the world does care about these matters," said Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman.
Korea experts said Mr. Powell must begin building a consensus among the Asian nations on North Korea -- a first step toward seeking a tough United Nations resolution condemning North Korea's recent steps to develop nuclear weapons. 
That resolution could provide a basis for the United States to seek stronger action by the United Nations -- including perhaps sanctions -- if North Korea resumes ballistic missile tests or begins reprocessing plutonium for nuclear weapons.
"If things go poorly, you need that resolution as a first step to something more," said Victor D. Cha, a Korea expert at Georgetown University. "From a North Korean perspective, seeing a resolution like that, that everyone signs onto, including the Chinese and Russians, would have a powerful effect." 
Just as important for Mr. Powell, officials and Korean experts said, will be to ease tensions between South Korea and the United States that flared during the South Korean presidential campaign last year.
Having Mr. Powell attend the inauguration when he is embroiled in Iraq-related diplomacy will send an important message of respect to Mr. Roh, Korea experts said.
In China, Mr. Powell is expected to emphasize that the United States believes that Beijing can do more to pressure North Korea, American officials said. 
"We give the Chinese some credit for doing something," a senior administration official said. "But we think the point has to be made again and again and more clearly to the North Koreans, at a high level, that they are endangering their relations with the world."
Highlighting the continuing tensions on the Korean Peninsula, a North Korean fighter plane swooped over the Yellow Sea off the South Korean west coast for two minutes today, raising the question of whether the flight was timed to precede Mr. Powell's arrival on Monday.
After six South Korean jets scrambled to chase the plane back to North Korean territory, the South Korean Defense Ministry called the flight a "provocation," although officials also acknowledged that the incident might have been a chance foray.

HEADLINE: Daimler Is Upbeat on Chrysler, With Some Ifs 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler said today that further recovery at its Chrysler unit would help the group improve profit this year, but that this assumed stable economic conditions in its main markets. 
 The carmaker, two-thirds of the way through a three-year turnaround plan at Chrysler, declined to put a figure on its goal, citing the degree of political and economic uncertainty. "DaimlerChrysler plans to achieve higher earnings this year than in 2002," the company said. "However, a precondition for this anticipated increase is that conditions remain stable in the most important markets." 
 Georg Stuerzer, an analyst at HypoVereinsbank, said, "This is quite a clear statement, given the current danger for giving outlooks, and it is more than many investors had expected." 
Volkswagen earlier this week offered no outlook after posting a 10 percent drop in 2002 profit. 
Daimler said last year that it might meet an adjusted operating profit goal later than 2003, the date set two years ago. The goal is 8.5 billion to 9.5 billion euros ($9.2 billion to $10.3 billion at current exchange rates). 
Daimler, which makes cars, trucks and buses, said it aimed for revenue of 151 billion euros ($163 billion) this year, up 1 percent from 2002, and 163 billion euros ($176 billion) in 2005, with the biggest gains in Asia.
The Chrysler unit posted fourth-quarter operating profit today of 77 million euros ($83.27 million), implying slowing momentum from previous quarters. 
Chrysler reiterated a goal of an operating profit of two billion euros for the year, as it continues to cut costs to offset weak demand. It also said it was counting on new models to help revive its fortunes, after the business broke even sooner than it had predicted. 
The overhaul in the United States includes a 20 percent cut in Chrysler's work force, price savings from suppliers and lower costs at the Mercedes unit and its Japanese partner, Mitsubishi Motors.

Suit Made a Class Action
NEWARK, Feb. 20 (Bloomberg News) -- A federal judge granted class-action status today to a lawsuit accusing DaimlerChrysler of fixing prices on Mercedes-Benz cars in the New York area. 
Judge Alfred M. Wolin, in United States District Court here, ruled that customers who bought or leased new Mercedes-Benz vehicles at 27 New York-area dealers from 1992 to 1999 could proceed with a group case against DaimlerChrysler. The company denied the charges and said it might appeal the class certification.

HEADLINE: Slump Aside, Trade Deficit Hits a Record 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Aided by a surge in December, the trade deficit easily reached a record last year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, a sign that economic growth around the world remains even weaker than it does in the United States. 
 The value of American goods and services exported to other countries declined for the second consecutive year, as Europe, Japan and South American all cut back on their purchases even though the dollar was losing value. Imports rose, with those from China leading the increase, sending the trade deficit to $435.2 billion in 2002, up from $358 billion in 2001, the report said. 
 The size of December's deficit -- $44.2 billion, up 10 percent from November -- surprised analysts and was among a handful of disappointing economic reports released yesterday. The Standard & Poor 500-stock index lost 8.03 points, or almost 1 percent, to close at 837.10. 
Since the start of the year, "we had a string of hopeful data," said Ethan Harris, chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers. "We're going to see some of that strength fade now."
The number of people filing initial claims for jobless benefits rose last week to the highest level since the end of last year, the Labor Department said. A survey by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve suggested that a nascent manufacturing recovery might be slowing. According to the Conference Board, a research group in New York, its index of leading indicators, intended to forecast the economy's near-term movement, dropped slightly, its first decline since September.
In the one sign of economic strength, the Labor Department said the prices that companies received for their goods jumped in January. The report provided more evidence, economists said, that the weak growth was unlikely to cause deflation, a sustained decline in prices of the sort that has recently afflicted Japan.
Since the recession in this country appeared to end in late 2001, the economy has lurched through one cycle after another of hope-inducing growth followed by disappointment. With companies still working through the excesses of the 1990's bubble, and the fear of an Iraq war now compounding public uncertainty, the strong periods have yet to last long enough for executives to add many new workers.
"We got off to a surprisingly good start this year," said Maury Harris, chief North American economist at UBS Warburg. Now, however, "we've got this environment of heightened caution," he said.
The end of the decade-long expansion has caused the dollar to lose about 15 percent of its value relative to the euro since late 2000. But even if the United States seems more vulnerable than it did in the late 90's, it remains economically stronger than its closest rivals, and the currency decline has not been large enough to lower the trade deficit.
Instead, the current account deficit, which includes profits on investments as well as trade in goods and services, was equivalent to about 5 percent of the American economy last year, its largest share ever, according to UBS Warburg.
"The U.S. has a 100-pound pack on its back that it's hauling around -- the global economy," Mr. Harris of Lehman Brothers said. "It's a big demand on an economy that's not all that strong to begin with."
The decline in exports was broad based in 2002. American companies sold less industrial equipment, fewer telecommunications services, less meat, less newsprint, less tobacco and fewer books to othercountries than they had in 2001. 
At the same time, foreign companies increased their sales of consumer items in the United States -- including oil, television sets, appliances, wine and baked goods -- to offset a decline in the sales of products like chemicals and aircraft engines.
American computer makers particularly struggled to keep up with foreign rivals. While computer exports fell 12.6 percent, to $9.2 billion, imports jumped 27.6 percent, to $16.2 billion. 
Over all, the United States had its biggest trade deficit with China, followed by the European Union, Japan and Canada. 
Most economists consider large trade deficits to be unsustainable. Eventually, they say, the dollar will probably decline by enough to make American exports more affordable. 
That would help manufacturing industries -- which have cut two million jobs in the last three years -- compete with foreign companies, Mr. Harris of UBS Warburg said. But it would probably also lead to an increase in inflation and interest rates that could prevent economic growth from reaching the pace it had in the late 90's.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
In Jersey City, Apartments Where Soap Was Made

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
Along the Hudson River in Paulus Hook, one of this city's oldest neighborhoods, a new enclave of high-rise apartments and office buildings is taking shape where a soap and toothpaste factory once stood. 
 Several residential projects are also under way elsewhere in Paulus Hook, including 1,000 rental and condominium apartments recently completed, under construction or about to rise. The 105-unit Pier House, a condominium developed by Trammell Crow Residential of Atlanta, is filling with owners, and Metro Homes of Hoboken recently began work on a 32-unit condominium called Liberty Point. 
 The latest components in the 24-acre redevelopment area once occupied by Colgate-Palmolive, the toiletries company, are twin 37-story rental buildings nearing completion with 648 apartments. Fisher Development Associates of Purchase, N.Y., is developing the $100 million project, called Liberty Towers, with Northwestern Mutual Life of Milwaukee, among other partners. 
The apartment towers are rising next to the 1.5-million-square-foot office building that Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, is developing and will mostly occupy on one of the three former Colgate parcels it owns. The Goldman Sachs tower, which at 792 feet and 42 stories would be New Jersey's tallest building when completed as expected next year, will join three office structures totaling 3.3 million square feet in the redevelopment area.
Three million more square feet of office space is planned and four other housing developments, smaller than Liberty Towers, are under way or planned on the former Colgate property.
The 35-block Paulus Hook area juts into Upper New York Bay, and part of it is included on the New Jersey and National Registers of Historic Places. It is known for its 19th-century brownstones and brick row houses, some predating the Civil War. Nowhere else in Jersey City, said Robert Cotter, the city's planning director, "does an Old World neighborhood sit cheek by jowl with a new one." 
The neighborhood was where the area's first permanent white settler, Michael Paulsen, a Dutch trader, built his home in 1633 and started trading with the Communipaw Indians. It was also the site of a Revolutionary War battle.
Mr. Cotter said Liberty Towers and the Goldman Sachs building were among a small group of "point towers" in the Colgate redevelopment that "will mark the waterfront's western shore, balance the Jersey side of the Hudson with Manhattan and serve as an entrance to New York Harbor."
The neighborhood offers ferry and PATH service to Manhattan as well as light-rail service along the New Jersey side. Brian Fisher, a partner with his father, Lester, in Fisher Development Associates, developers of Liberty Towers, said he hoped that those amenities, as well as the attractions of waterfront living and views, would lure tenants and defy the slack rental market when leasing starts next month. In the last 18 months, rents along the city's waterfront have fallen by 10 to 20 percent, according to the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City. 
Fisher Associates, alone or with other partners, has overseen several developments in New Jersey, including a 300-unit residential building in Hoboken. 
To maximize views, the Manhattan architectural firm Gruzen Samton designed the rental towers so their inside facades curve away from one another at their north and south ends, while their outside faces follow a zigzag pattern. The towers, 100 feet apart, sit atop an eight-story base.
"This way there are views from all four sides of the buildings, which look past each other as well as the Goldman Sachs building," said Jordan L. Gruzen, a design partner for the project.
The studio-to-two-bedroom rentals have 685 to 1,190 square feet and high ceilings. Many also have floor-to-ceiling windows or terraces. 
The base will house the lobby, 24,000 square feet of retail space, seven floors of parking for 800 cars and a pool and health club. Other amenities include a business center and a waterfront park that will be open to the public. 
Brian Fisher said monthly rents would initially be $1,600 to $3,150 for the apartments; penthouses will cost more. He said the partners also own a site south of Liberty Towers, closer to the water, where they plan an eight-story residential building, safeguarding tower residents' views of the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and Manhattan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Liberty Towers apartments are the latest to be developed on the old Colgate-Palmolive factory site in Jersey City's Paulus Hook section. (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times) Map of Jersey City, New Jersey highlighting Paulus Hook: A portion of Paulus Hook, a Jersey City neighborhood, has historic designation.

HEADLINE: Nissan Settles Bias Suit by Minority Buyers 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The finance unit of Nissan Motor has reached a tentative settlement with black and Hispanic car buyers who said that the company discriminated against minority customers by charging them higher interest rates.
 Under the terms of the settlement, the carmaker's finance unit, the Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation, will offer preapproved loans to hundreds of thousands of current and potential black and Hispanic Nissan owners, and will limit how much it raises the interest charged to car buyers above the company's minimum acceptable rate. The finance unit will also contribute $1 million to America Saves, a nonprofit program that tries to help low-income people save and build wealth. 
 The settlement will also result in the payment of $5,000 to $20,000 to the 10 people named in the class-action lawsuit, which was filed in federal court in Nashville. Other car buyers wishing to recover money will still be able to sue N.M.A.C. separately. The finance unit denied any liability or wrongdoing in the settlement.
Lawyers involved would not comment on the proposed settlement, which is subject to approval by Judge Todd J. Campbell of United States District Court in Nashville. A hearing on the settlement is scheduled for Monday.
In the lawsuit resolved by the settlement, the plaintiffs contended that car dealers were more likely to increase, or mark up, the interest rate charged to car buyers who were black or Hispanic. Typically the markup is shared by the lender and the dealer, according to court documents. The plaintiffs also said that the average markup for black and Hispanic car buyers was greater than that for white buyers with similar financial backgrounds.
Nissan's finance unit contended that markups are common and are an important revenue source for car dealers. The company asserted in the proposed settlement that it used a "risk-based pricing system that uses higher rates for higher-risk applicants."
The plaintiffs did not accuse the company of racial bias. Lenders typically do not know the race of car buyers. The Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation determines its interest rate based on a consumer's credit rating, but the company allows car dealers to tack on additional percentage points, and dealers could be biased. The plaintiffs argued that the credit policies and dealer decisions had a disparate impact on blacks and Hispanics. For example, buyers in a higher credit tier may face lower markups, and whites are more likely to be in a higher tier. 
Similar lawsuits have been filed in several states nationwide and it is unclear whether the Nissan settlement will pave the way for similar deals in those cases. The defendants in those other suits include the finance arms of Ford Motor, General Motors, Toyota Motor and DaimlerChrysler, as well as Bank of America and others. In its court filing, N.M.A.C. asserts that it has only 2.5 percent of the market for retail contracts from car dealers.
Under the settlement, for five years the Nissan finance unit will limit the size of the markup to three percentage points above the company's minimum interest rate for buyers in a given credit tier. The markup for longer-term finance agreements and for used vehicles could be no more than two percentage points.
The unit will also set up a program for current customers who are black or Hispanic, and will offer preapproved car loans, with no markup, to at least 50,000 such people over the next five years. 
The company will also screen enough potential black and Hispanic car buyers to offer 625,000 such buyers preapproved markup-free loans over the next five years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A class-action suit filed in Nashville contended that black and Hispanic car buyers were often charged higher interest rates by Nissan dealers. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Seducing the Governors 

 BODY:
After Congress failed to create a national health care plan, Medicaid became the default solution to the crisis of the growing number of uninsured Americans. Expanding Medicaid was a success in terms of meeting a critical need. But the price is now staggering strapped state governments. 
 The Bush administration is responding with an offer of modest help, essentially a loan against future Medicaid payments -- but there is a catch. To get the aid, states must agree to radical changes in their Medicaid plans, which will eventually take the federal government off the hook for some -- and perhaps much -- of its share of the costs. At bottom, Washington wants to limit its long-term responsibility for the only kind of health program many Americans can afford. And it's planning to bribe the governors to go along. This is outrageously unfair. Any federal aid should be made available to all states, even those that want to maintain the current structure of their Medicaid programs. 
 Medicaid was originally intended mainly for poor children and the disabled, but most states have expanded it to include the families of the working poor or near-poor and elderly people who could not afford to fill in the gaps in their Medicare coverage. It grew, almost without notice, into the largest health insurance program in the country. It now covers more people and spends more money than Medicare. The federal government picks up from 50 percent to 77 percent of the tab, depending on a state's per capita income, with state revenues paying for the rest.
Some states are already cutting back on Medicaid in order to save money -- ramping down their already low payments to hospitals and nursing homes, and lopping off people or benefits they added in better times. By one count, about a million low-income people could lose Medicaid coverage under cutbacks already adopted by states or proposed by their governors.
The federal government should be trying to find ways to keep people who would otherwise be uninsured from falling out of the Medicaid program. It makes sense to give states more flexibility to require co-payments, spread their limited resources among a wider group of beneficiaries and pursue cost-saving efforts like encouraging people to use cheaper home health care instead of nursing homes. What Washington should not do is try to sneak out of the federal obligation to support the system. That's what a critical part of the Bush proposal amounts to. Participating states would receive more money than usual for the first seven years, then the sum would drop below normal for the next three years. In the end, the states would be left with a capped annual lump sum that might not rise fast enough to meet need in times of recession.
Most governors are near-frantic with budget worries right now, and some of them might calculate cynically that they will probably not still be in office in seven years when federal aid starts dropping. But the current expanded Medicaid system does not deserve to be dismantled, even over the long run. If it really wants to help, the administration could give Medicaid a much larger infusion of money by simply providing prescription drug coverage for all Medicare recipients, thus relieving Medicaid of paying those costs for the elderly poor.

HEADLINE: A Developer Back From the Brink 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY 

 BODY:
From the helicopter landing pad above the 55th floor, not even the circle of mountaintops peeking through the brown smog diminishes the view from Torre Mayor, the tallest building in Latin America.
 For Paul D. Reichmann, it must be a sweet sight, signifying his return to the heights as a real estate developer from the depths of financial distress. Along with his brothers, Mr. Reichmann once realized some of the most outsize real estate visions of recent decades before suffering some of the business's most devastating losses in the early 1990's. 
 The risks Mr. Reichmann took in pursuit of those visions cost him, and others, dearly. He pierced the vertical horizon of the Toronto skyline and set new standards for efficiency in building. He built the four towers of the World Financial Center in New York, breathing life into Battery Park City. 
He went to London and, in 1988, started building Canary Wharf, a hugely ambitious project on the eastern edge of the city, and there his career seemed to end. Poor timing amid the global economic downturn of that era and inadequate transportation left much of the project without paying tenants. Loans came due, and Mr. Reichmann's whole empire crumbled.
"Who were his peers?" asked John E. Zucotti, a former first deputy mayor of New York City who later worked for Mr. Reichmann at Olympia & York, once the world's largest developer. "He said, 'I have a vision, and I'm ready to write a check with a letter of credit behind it.' That's very rare in the development business."
"The biggest weakness," said Mr. Zucotti, now the co-chairman of Brookfield Properties, which descended from Mr. Reichmann's O.& Y., "was perhaps he believed in himself so well that he failed to recognize that the world changed around 1990."
In the Mexico City coda to this story, success is back within Mr. Reichmann's reach.
At 732 feet, Torre Mayor -- meant to evoke Templo Mayor, the religious center of the ancient Aztec world -- eclipses the next tallest building here, the 52-story, 702-foot Petroleos Mexicanos building. But height is merely a starting point. The construction materials and methods are of the highest caliber and expense, which is still uncommon here. The building, almost complete after nearly a decade of costly false starts, is intended as a catalyst for urban renaissance along La Reforma, the wide boulevard where demonstrators hold their political protests almost daily.
In recent days here, Mr. Reichmann has been seen shuffling through the soaring glass lobby, nodding to the construction and maintenance workers and asking questions. He wears dark suits and patternless ties, a yarmulke and tennis shoes. There are bags under his eyes, and he walks with a hunched back.
His re-emergence here as a speculative entrepreneurial developer is complemented by continuing involvement in Canary Wharf, which is now booming, and new footholds in real estate markets in the United States. Torre Mayor is a new epilogue to the story of a self-effacing, patient man who long operated at the outer fringes of the confluence of boldness, timing and luck necessary to succeed in the commercial real estate market.
Mr. Reichmann changed, though, partly because the nature of the real estate business has changed, according to people who have dealt with him from his early days through his re-emergence as a player. 
The contrast is most evident in the structure of his holdings in the United States and Europe, where he has used publicly traded companies to rebuild his portfolio.
"It is more cautious; it is more conservative," said Vinay Kapoor, the chief executive of IPC U.S. Income REIT, a real estate investment trust that is publicly traded in Canada and invests alongside Mr. Reichmann in commercial properties in the United States. "That does not mean that Paul will not look at opportunities and take risks like he did in Mexico."
The publicly traded concerns provide a distribution of risk, but they also require far more disclosure than the closely guarded deals Mr. Reichmann made in the past, when only his brothers and his bankers, if anyone, were privy to his dealings.
"He is still very enthusiastic about the projects he does and has passion, but the world has changed," Mr. Kapoor said. "There aren't developers now like there were in the 1980's."
With his brothers Ralph and Albert, Mr. Reichmann started a floor and tile business in Toronto in the 1950's, parlaying it into a real estate empire that built First Canadian Place, that city's tallest skyscraper, at 72 stories, or 951 feet. In 1988, he completed the four office towers of the World Financial Center.
But Mr. Reichmann then spread his capital into other types of investments, even as he sought to recreate the city-shifting success of the World Financial Center on the docklands three miles from London's traditional financial center, the City. Olympia & York spent $3.5 billion on Canary Wharf, a tract of land then difficult to reach by mass transportation.
Eleven banks took control of Canary Wharf, and they froze the development process. In the spring of 1992, the Reichmanns put Canary Wharf under the protection of a British bankruptcy court, disclosing more than $2 billion in debts to banks around the world. They made bankruptcy filings for sundry operating units in the United States and Canada with total debt of $14.9 billion.
Books were written about the Reichmanns, chronicling their rise and fall.
But while Albert and Ralph retired, Paul Reichmann started investment partnerships.
With Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia; CNA Insurance, controlled by the Tisch family; and Franklin Mutual, Mr. Reichmann organized a consortium that bought Canary Wharf in 1995 for about $:720 million, including $:420 million in equity, eventually turning the development into a publicly traded company in London. He now serves as chairman and holds about 7 percent of the company's shares.
The company estimates that about 42,000 people now work at Canary Wharf, most of them in the financial services business. Of the development's total of 14 million square feet, completed or under construction, 11.5 million are owned by the Canary Wharf Group.
And with the financier George Soros, Mr. Reichmann came to Mexico City in 1993 with three developments in mind. Centro Alameda, a 194,000-square-foot mixed-use public-private venture in the historic downtown, was eventually sold to the city for a public plaza. About 30 acres in the southwestern Santa Fe area were eventually resold as raw land. Mr. Soros dissolved the partnership in 1995.
By then, even Torre Mayor seemed ruined. Mr. Reichmann purchased the 1.7-acre site for $25 million, including relocating existing businesses, in 1994 -- a time when the North American Free Trade Agreement was opening borders and attracting companies and investors. But then, from December 1994 to April 1995, the value of the peso fell 45 percent.
The project stalled, and the money already spent was simply gone. But Mr. Reichmann was not in debt. There is no such thing as a construction loan here. Buildings are developed with cash, and loans are put in place only when a tower is proved to be profitable, or at least existent.
But persistent marketing to international companies seeking to consolidate their offices has helped salvage the project, as did, paradoxically, the recent downturn in the United States economy, which made quality materials available at less expensive prices.
All told, the tower has cost about $250 million, and completing the leasing at profitable rates will be a challenge, brokers here say.
"He needs a lot of guts to do something like that, the size of that," said Victor Manuel Lachica Bravo, president of Cushman & Wakefield de Mexico, a real estate services concern. "But nobody thought the economy was going to be so weak."
Mr. Reichmann has sold about 30 percent of Torre Mayor to private investment funds in the United States, and he has secured a $90 million loan from Scotia Bank using Torre Mayor as collateral.
Asked what he hoped would be his legacy, Mr. Reichmann said through Mr. Kapoor that he had not thought about it, offering as proof the fact that he has not named his buildings after himself.
"Hopefully, in each city, they will last a long time and be meaningful for the city," he said through Mr. Kapoor.
In the United States, through his partnership with IPC, a Canadian real estate investment trust, he has bought interests in 1.35 million square feet of office space in Philadelphia, Cleveland and Lexington, Ky.
With the other two Mexico projects abandoned -- sold at a modest profit instead of gambled upon -- Mr. Reichmann now spends much of his time in Britain, where Canary Wharf is 80 percent complete. Current annual rents are around $65 to $80 a square foot, about $8 less than for rents in the City. It is also responsible to public shareholders, leaving Torre Mayor as the last of Mr. Reichmann's big gambles.
"Maybe it's tempered, but he's still capable of believing in himself," Mr. Zucotti said. "To lose a fortune of that size and dimension and come back from it is truly remarkable."

HEADLINE: Our New Hydrogen Bomb 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

DATELINE: MESA, Ariz. 

 BODY:
To understand how we might bolster our national security aside from invading Iraq, I'm on a General Motors test track here in Arizona, driving the coolest car you've never seen.
 It's called Hy-wire, and it's a one-of-a-kind prototype: a four-door sedan fueled by hydrogen, capable of speeds of 100 miles an hour, whisper-quiet, and emitting no pollution at all -- only water vapor as exhaust. It looks like a spaceship, with glass all around and no pedals or steering wheel. 
 Jeff Wolak, the engineer who travels with Hy-wire and mothers it, explained that it is drive-by-wire, controlled by electronics and computers rather than cables and hydraulics. To accelerate, you rotate the handgrips. To steer, you move the grips up or down. 
Then Mr. Wolak tells me to drive the $5 million prototype. He is in the passenger seat and picks up what looks like a computer game console that he rests on his lap.
"It's a second set of controls with an emergency brake," he explains brightly. "We only have one of these vehicles, and we don't want to risk it getting in a crash."
And he hadn't even seen me drive. 
On the vast track, the Hy-wire zipped about flawlessly. It turns sharply, brakes smoothly and accelerates easily -- all almost noiselessly. It's all you would expect of a $5 million car. And if a driver crosses to England, he could press a button and the driving controls would whirr over to the right front seat. 
Likewise, each driver of a family car could have a different steering mechanism. "It could be a joystick for the 20-something generation who are used to computer games, or a steering wheel for the older set used to a Cadillac," said Timothy Perzanowski, a G.M. engineer.
In short, hydrogen fuel cells are not necessarily a distant dream. Toyota, Honda and BMW also are churning out hydrogen prototypes. General Motors is talking about having the Hy-wire in showrooms by 2010 and selling a million hydrogen vehicles by 2015. 
"We see fuel cells as the first technology that has come along in 100 years that has the potential of competing with the internal combustion engine," said Scott Fosgard, a G.M. official involved in hydrogen cars. "We're doing this because we're going to make a boatload of money."
Mr. Fosgard says that eventually, hydrogen cars will have significant advantages: "What does it cost in New York for a parking space? Maybe $500 a month? Well, imagine if the parking garage paid you, because while it's parked there it's producing electricity that is sold back to the grid." 
This may be pie in the sky, of course. For example, it's true that hydrogen vehicles can generate electricity while parked, but the cost of producing it might be prohibitive.
History is littered with other energy technologies that fell flat: synthetic fuels, biomass, nuclear fusion, solar, electric vehicles. Hydrogen cars still face technical hitches, as well as the central challenge: how to cut costs. Carlos Ghosn, the head of Nissan, has joked that fuel cell cars would carry a sticker price of about $700,000.
Moreover, getting the hydrogen can be a problem and can produce greenhouse gases. Hydrogen does not exist on its own but is locked up in water and fossil fuels. The goal is to use wind energy to pluck hydrogen from water in the ocean, but in the near term it's more likely that the hydrogen will come from natural gas. 
The bottom line is that President Bush was dead right last month to offer $1.7 billion to boost hydrogen technology, although it would help if the White House also promoted high-mileage hybrid cars for the present. The government could also do more, by deregulating commercial power supply by fuel cells and by encouraging fleet purchases of hydrogen vehicles. 
What does any of this have to do with Iraq? 
Hydrogen cars are a reminder that there is more than one way to ensure our supplies of energy in the years ahead, even if invading Iraq and investing in hydrogen address the issue on very different time horizons. Nonetheless, I have to say that waging war seems a reflex, pushing toward a hydrogen economy a vision.
As Mr. Fosgard of G.M. put it only half-jokingly: "I don't want to say that this car will eliminate war, but we might not have wars for energy anymore. We'd have to find different reasons to go to war."
