HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Don't Worry, Be Ready: Chicken Soup for the Anxious Soul

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: EASTCHESTER, N.Y. 

 BODY:
WHAT does Tom Ridge want from us?
 He counsels us to live yellow in an orange world. But it is not so simple. The homeland band blares dirges one day, easy listening the next. "Don't be afraid," was last week's mood-altering statement from Mr. Ridge, the secretary of homeland security. "Be ready." 
 No wonder so many see Mr. Ridge as the boy who cried duct. But then there are those citizens trying to answer the call -- confusing as it may be -- to get ready for the unthinkable, indefinable, whatever.
Eastchester has Vicki Ford. A local councilwoman, Mrs. Ford commands a citizens' group aiming to whip this Westchester County town into shape.
She is compiling a disaster preparedness booklet with important phone numbers, a map for quick evacuation and a checklist of items for a "Grab-and-Go Ready Kit," with everything from tissues to a signal flare.
In the glass showcases at the town clerk's office, she has replaced artifacts commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Village of Tuckahoe with a display of ingredients for the prepared household: bottled water, batteries, flashlights, blankets, toothbrushes, Swiss Army knife, hand gel and, of course, duct tape. Next month, there will be a one-week course here in first aid, biological and chemical hazards, CPR and more.
There may eventually be neighborhood captains. "I think each four-block area should have an individual they can look to for information," Mrs. Ford said.
This is a whole new world anda whole old world wrapped in one. Mrs. Ford, 65, said her mother was a "blackout warden" during World War II, who inspected their neighborhood in St. Paul, Minn., after air raid sirens sounded to make sure no lights were visible. She saved tin cans for the war effort, as well as bacon drippings, which contained glycerin, used in making explosives. Later, her stepfather, a retired military officer, had a demonstration bomb shelter in the basement.
Civil defense has become emergency management, a true service-economy label, and there are early signs it is becoming a hot commodity on the suburban landscape of soft targets.
If McMansions offer a room for every mood, and S.U.V.'s allow you to traverse every terrain, a smattering of emergency management can help you weather any ill wind, whether from Al Qaeda or El Nino.
Terrorism is the immediate impetus, but purveyors of preparedness are selling it as chicken soup. Whatever's ailing you, it can't hurt.
That's why Dick Breining, a Morgan Stanley financial adviser in New Jersey, was one of 31 people Thursday night at the first of a nine-part emergency preparedness course sponsored by the Paramus Office of Emergency Management. "I want to know what's going on," he said. "I want to protect my family, my home, my neighbors."
KNOWLEDGE may be an antidote to anxiety, but a little bit of emergency preparedness is a scary thing. The highlight of Thursday night's class was a long video of house-tossing tornadoes and hurricanes. Terrorism was hardly the only concern.
"I have a gas pipeline down the street from my house," said Tim Murphy, a salesman in the import-export business. "If it blew up, what would happen? If a plane going into Newark explodes and parts come down, who would I call? You have to be prepared for anything."
This is boot camp for post-9/11 suburbia. The course teaches about search and rescue, fire suppression and emergency communications equipment, among other subjects. The idea, promoted by President Bush, is to form Citizens Corps Councils, which can help the professionals when the going gets tough.
There has hardly been a stampede to join Ridge's Regiment. In Middletown, N.J., where so many victims of 9/11 lived, just 20 people volunteered to take an emergency management course.
"You teach them how to use a hammer and saw and put out a fire," said the local emergency coordinator, Charles Rogers. "You run into so many people today who don't know how to do a doggone thing."
Most people have volunteered only to worry, although about 60,000 people have signed up with citizen councils around the country.
But fatalism is still trumping preparedness. Even, and perhaps especially, among the professionals.
Come what may, said Steven Mehl, the emergency management director in Paramus: "I'm going to do the best I can. And if that's not enough, that's it."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: KOREAN PENINSULA; 
North Korea's Need for Electricity Fuels Its Nuclear Ambitions

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ONJUNG-RI, North Korea, Feb. 16 

 BODY:
The restaurant receptionist was shivering. The waitresses wore long underwear. Then, during a dinner of spicy dumplings and cold noodles, the lights went out three times.
 "North Korea's No. 1 problem is electricity," Kim Young Il, a South Korean businessman, said, sighing, as the gas flames of a Korean barbecue burned blue into the Saturday night gloom. 
 "We try to deal with goods that can be produced without power like sun dried fish," he said, as the lights flickered back on. "Because there is no heat in hotels, I generally only travel in the country from May to October."
Behind the standoff between North Korea and the world over its nuclear weapons crisis is a power crisis. 
Almost a decade ago, North Korea agreed to stop construction of Soviet-designed power plants that produced plutonium that could be used for nuclear weapons. In return, a United States-led consortium was to build three nuclear power plants designed to be proliferation proof. Although the first plant under the agreement was to be ready this year, the project is years behind schedule.
The deal collapsed last fall after North Korean officials were said to have admitted to an American envoy that they were cheating on the accord and pursuing a second secret nuclear weapons program. Just as winter started, the United States ended fuel oil deliveries to North Korea that had been stipulated under the agreement.
"The U.S. stands between us and electricity," said Kim Dae Sung, a 35-year-old park guide, voicing a government-approved view that most of North Korea's shortcomings are the fault of the United States. Bitter that she never knows whether she will watch television after work or read by candlelight, she said, "Why do the Americans keep making problems with electricity?"
To visit North Korea today is to visit a country that has regressed into a preindustrial past.
Electric wires go from house to house, but at night entire villages disappear into darkness. During the day, residents trudge through the snow, carrying stacks of firewood on their backs. Without the power to mine coal or the fuel to deliver it, most rural households have reverted to cooking and heating with wood.
North Korea has become a nation of walkers and bicyclists as there is little gasoline for cars and buses. The railroad station here features a huge portrait of Kim Il Sung, the founder of this Communist state, with an inspirational slogan. But pedestrians use the tracks as a walkway, because no electric trains have run through here in years. Near here, the lighthouse at Kosong harbor is no longer lighted at night.
"The country was fully electrified before the crisis began in the 1990's," said Timothy Savage, who surveyed North Korea's energy needs in 2000 for the Nautilus Institute for Security and Sustainable Development, a California-based group. "They have appliances, radios, televisions, and in some cases refrigerators." 
But because of a lack of maintenance, North Korea's hydro and fuel oil plants were working at only 30 percent of capacity, and 30 percent of production was lost as a result of leakage, the Nautilus survey found.
The survey calculated that this nation of 22 million people was limping along on 2 gigawatts of energy, less than the amount of power consumed by an American city of one million people. 
"Energy is at the root of all of North Korea's economic problems, including the famine," Mr. Savage continued, referring to severe food shortages in the mid-1990's that killed as many as two million people, or 10 percent of the population.
Without power, electric pumps could not irrigate fields, electric threshers could not thresh grain and factories could not make fertilizer or parts for North Korea's ancient fleet of tractors. 
Last year, the United Nations World Food Program helped to feed about one-third of the population here. But two of the largest donor nations, Japan and the United States, have suspended food shipments for North Korea, partly because of the nuclear weapons program and partly because of the invective heaped daily on both countries by North Korea's state-controlled media.
Calling for "desperate measures," North Korea's director of energy, Kim Jae Rok, was quoted this week in The Sunday Telegraph as saying that his nation now plans to build four nuclear power plants.
"This will enable us to meet the urgent need for electricity supplies in our country," Mr. Kim was quoted as saying. 
Partly because of energy shortages, the number of South Korean companies interested in investing in North Korea has dwindled. The number of new projects approved by the South Korean government fell to 3 last year, from 13 in 1998. 
Here at the Mount Kumgang resort project, easily South Korea's largest investment in North Korea, the Hyundai Asan Corporation solved the energy problem by importing three 1,000-kilowatt generators and diesel fuel to power them.
"Sometimes only two or three days a week, you see lights in the village," Kim Young Hyun, the resort manager, said of Onjung-ri.
Even Pyongyang, the nation's showcase capital, has been subject to blackouts, forcing people to climb stairs in high-rises and to store water in case water pumps stop.
"Energy supplies are very unreliable," said Lee Sang Man, a South Korean economist visiting here. Power shortages once closed for seven months a factory that Mr. Lee had invested in and was overseeing. The factory produced electric light bulbs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: North Koreans carrying wood recently near Mount Kumgang. Lacking electricity, most rural households now heat and cook with wood. (Pool photo)

HEADLINE: Departing Chief of L.I.R.R. Sees Progress and Concerns 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The Long Island Rail Road is entering a new and uncertain era. It is merging with Metro-North, riders face proposed fare increases as high as one-third, another shipment of new cars is to be put into service, and now its president is leaving and a successor is being sought.
 Kenneth J. Bauer ends his three-year stint as chief of the railroad, the nation's largest commuter line, on March 3 to become chief financial officer at Railworks Corporation, a private transportation-services company in White Plains. 
 He is leaving to generally favorable reviews. 
"I want to thank you for making a difference," one passenger, Joan Nemarich, said as Mr. Bauer made a farewell appearance Thursday night at the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council in Manhattan. "You put the emphasis on putting the customers first."
But the railroad is well known for its glitches and hitches, so there were also complaints about a track fire that shut down Pennsylvania Station for hours on Feb. 14 and the widespread delays after the Washington's Birthday blizzard.
"This winter has been unbelievably long and arduous," Mr. Bauer said. But he added that the arrival of the new M-7 electric cars would enable the railroad to better withstand future winters. "The reliability should be a lot better," he said.
On a typical weekday, the railroad provides 290,000 rides, connecting Nassau and Suffolk with Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The system has about 6,000 workers.
Among his successes, Mr. Bauer pointed to last year's on-time performance of 94.7 percent, a record. That was achieved despite the railroad's antiquated fleet and lack of spare cars. Three-fourths of the trains are 33 to 35 years old and are overdue for replacement, but improved maintenance helped keep them running, Mr. Bauer said.
A big headache for the railroad has been correcting the problems in the 134 cars and locomotives of its new diesel-electric bilevel trains. They suffered from structural cracks, air-conditioning that was too cold, recordings that announced the wrong stations and brake hoses that kept separating during last week's snowstorm.
The bilevel cars were designed and ordered before Mr. Bauer took over, and he was determined to avoid a replay with the M-7 all-electric trains that will replace most of the rest of the fleet.
M-7 prototypes underwent grueling tests, as the railroad hoped to detect flaws and make corrections before going into full production. Four M-7 trains, about 40 cars, are now in service, and the rest of the 678-car fleet will be phased in at the rate of a couple of trains each month for the next few years.
If Mr. Bauer's testing strategy works, the railroad should be running even better after he is gone, with its fleet modernized from one of the oldest in the nation to one of the newest. Topping Mr. Bauer's list of unfinished business is the "East Side Access" plan to bring the railroad into Grand Central Terminal, and the extension of the railroad's track system. "The railroad has not grown since 1898, and look what's happened to Long Island," he said.
But getting money for these and other projects is a major hurdle, especially with the stumbling economy, Mr. Bauer said. He hopes the federal government will pay half the costs but conceded, "That's going to be tough to do."
As for the merger, he said some functions, like purchasing, might be done better. But the trains of the two systems are not mechanically interchangeable, and the labor contracts at the Long Island are more costly, he said.
Mr. Bauer also wondered whether the sole aim of the merger was to save money, adding, "You don't want to hurt either railroad."

HEADLINE: THE VIEW/From Stratford; 
What Lies Beneath? 300 Years

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
FOR the last 12 years, Gerald Sawyer of Stratford has been conducting archeological digs relating to African slavery throughout New England and New York. He has taken part in Mayan digs in Guatemala, Mexico and Belize, and at ancient sites in Northern Ireland and Scotland. 
 Now, however, Mr. Sawyer finds himself working closer to home. 
 During the last few weeks, he has been leading dozens of local history buffs and archeology students on a search for artifacts under the floors of two rooms at the oldest house in Stratford. 
The goal of the dig is to find artifacts that can help piece together the puzzle of what life was like for the dozen different owners of the saltbox style house that was built by the town's first shipbuilder, Benjamin Beach, around 1690. 
Owners of the house not only included shipbuilders and merchants, but also blacksmiths and clergymen.
The project is part of an effort to transform the house, known as the William Perry Homestead, into Stratford's first visitors and tourism center. The house, named after a merchant who owned it in the mid-1800's, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Turning the house into a visitors center has recently gained approval from several town commissions. Local historians and town officials envision the project as a gateway to the Historic District and town center.
Mr. Sawyer, an adjunct professor of archeology at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain and at Brooklyn College in New York, said conducting a dig inside a home presented a rare challenge. 
"This is really an amazing opportunity to conduct a dig at a place that still exists," he said. "Most digs are out in the open field when don't know that we'll find much of anything."
Mr. Sawyer said there had been some intriguing surprises. Artifacts, like a small Native American tool that could be a thousand years old, and pieces of pottery, plates and handmade nails were uncovered beneath the parlor and kitchen areas.
"It's allowing us to do two important things: to look at a house that has been standing for nearly 300 years, and gain a better understanding of how a house changes over that period of time," he said.
"It's also helping us figure out how these artifacts ended up underneath the house. Were they deposited there during the life of the house or before, and if so, how and why? 
Christopher Collier, the state historian, said: "It's an interesting approach that is not done too often. But these historic houses went through many alterations and this is what needs to be done to piece together the puzzle of not only who lived there and how they lived, but what kinds of people roamed those grounds long before that." 
With the floor boards removed revealing crude, long and sturdy floor beams made of chestnut tree trunks and mounds of dirt below, it may seem hard to imagine wealthy shipbuilders and merchants from previous centuries entertaining guests in the front parlor room.
"This kind of dig can add to the understanding of not just the town's history, but of the state's history as well in so many ways," Nick Bellantoni, the state archeologist, said. "By digging underneath the actual house, items can be found that provide vital information about the social histories of the families who lived there, and also about the histories of peoples from long, long ago." 
On recent Saturdays, more than 25 men and women, their faces covered with white paper masks, were coated with the dirt and grime that comes from hours of digging with shovels and picks several feet under floor boards.
They said discovering fragments of pottery, sea shells, nails and animal bones made it all worthwhile.
"It's hard work, but I love history and the possibility of finding something hundreds or even thousands of years old is fascinating to me," said Stephen Winchell, 16, a junior at Bunnell High School in Stratford. "I'm really having a good time and have found some pieces of pottery and oyster shells."
The town has owned the house for about two decades, but it has been vacant since 1997, when it was last used for apartments.
Mr. Sawyer said among the biggest surprises were the large number of butchered animal bones discovered, and the Native American tools that were probably used to scrape the hides of deer and other animals. 
He pondered whether the tools were brought into the house by Native Americans, or the owners, or their guests, or whether they were left in the ground long before the house was built.
Mr. Sawyer said such questions would have to be answered in the laboratory during the next few months, adding that it may be impossible to determine how some of the items got there or how old they are.
Randy Wills, 29, of Rocky Hill, who has worked on archeological digs in Mexico, Italy and Spain, said working on a dig inside an old New England home "allows us to literally peel back the layers of history and find all kinds of historical items that were left behind."
Pointing to part of a newspaper from 1931, he said it revealed some truth in the cliche about history repeating itself: the page told of the economic crisis still facing the nation following the big stock market crash of 1929.
Mr. Sawyer said the experience was like solving a mystery.
"You have a number of clues, and when you get them all together you let the clues tell you the story of the house," he said. 
The story will not be complete, Mr. Sawyer said, until he returns in the spring to lead a dig outside the house, in the well and in the backyard.
"Those are traditional areas where people from the colonial era threw out their garbage, so we expect to find a lot more about the families' histories when we do the outside dig later on," he said. 
The Stratford Town Historian, Lewis Knapp, said what struck him was looking out the windows of the house and watching cars coming off Interstate 95 racing past a grassy green area where colonial town events were once held.
"It intrigues me to think that when the house was built no one could have possibly imagined it would still be here in the 21st century, and that as people dug under the floor boards there would this gigantic turnpike with cars speeding right by every second," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: At the William Perry Homestead, a group searched for artifacts in dirt removed from the house. Above, a mummified rat found under the floor boards, along with a tool and pottery. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Hood: Jobs for the Poor 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
STEVEN SANCHEZ, a shy 22-year-old from the Bronx, raised on welfare, with a ninth-grade education, was doing nothing when his older sister said: "You can't just be hanging out. Come to Greyston. You can get a good job there."
 Greyston is a cramped factory in rough southwest Yonkers that hires unskilled workers to make cakes in flavors like whiskey pistachio, Venetian wine and dense chocolate named lotus-in-the-mud. The products are sold in specialty-food departments in Bloomingdale's and Neiman Marcus and at Manhattan restaurants where they are priced at $10 a slice. The bakery also makes brownies, which are used in Ben & Jerry's ice cream, and what Zagat calls the best cheesecake in Westchester. 
 Greyston is, as well, an experiment begun began 20 years ago by an American Zen master. Its mission: to hire the lowest of the low -- the homeless and felons and former drug addicts -- teaching them to work and giving them a livelihood. In the process, the bakery aims thto make a profit and to do it all with style, with flair. 
Improbably, it seems to be working.
"I had a whole vision -- housing, child care as well as the bakery," said Bernard Tetsugen Glassman, a Zen master from Brooklyn and a former aeronautics engineer who wrote handbooks for a NASA flight to Mars before taking up studies to be a Buddhist priest. "But the bakery was the most concrete, and I hoped it would have spiritual value, in helping people to see the interdependence of life."
Today, the Greyston Foundation, which includes the bakery, is one of the largest private providers of low-income housing in Yonkers. It runs a day care center open to the community and a home with a medical clinic for impoverished people with AIDS. Also, in partnership with a neighborhood Episcopal church, it has restored the rundown but historic Philipsburg Hall to elegance, while turning the upper floors into subsidized apartments for artists.
In April, a new $9.4 million bakery is scheduled to open , with four times the capacity of the current one. Designed by Maya Lin, the architect for the Vietnam Memorial in Washington, it was financed with municipal bonds, bank loans and $1 million from the Environmental Protection Agency to cover the reclamation of the polluted lot or brownfield on which it is situated. 
"I wanted to make a great bakery, top of the line," Mr. Glassman said. "And I wanted to do it working with folks our society thinks are throwaways."

'We Will Hire Anybody'
Wednesday is open-hiring day at Greyston. "And we seriously mean open hiring," said Barbara Wood, who oversees training and counseling at the foundation. "We have a policy that we will hire anybody from the neighborhood. We don't check on prison or drugs. We don't ask for resumes or references."
The applications are numbered. When a job opens up, the person at the top is called. New hires may be felons, people who don't speak English, drug addicts or those without job experience of any kind -- and they often are.
When Mr. Sanchez got a call to fill in on the night shift, he showed up on time, did the job and did not skip out early. He did not start fights or push people around. The next time he was called, he went in again. At Greyston that was enough to make him stand out. 
In October, he got a chance on the day shift. That meant getting up at 6:30, five days a week. His friends, who either sold drugs or did nothing, objected.
"They be calling me up," he said. "But I tell them I can't go out. I got to get up really early."
He started at $5.50 per hour. Every two weeks he was evaluated for attendance, punctuality and attitude; after each satisfactory evaluation, his hourly pay rose 25 cents. In January, after three months, he was hired permanently, at a salary of $7 per hour with benefits and two weeks' paid vacation.
Mr. Sanchez, it seems, is succeeding. The vast majority of new hires do not. Four out of five are gone in a week or two, Ms. Wood said. A few start fist fights or are unduly argumentative and are fired, she said, but most disappear as soon as they get their first paycheck. Many return when it is spent, asking for another chance. But by then, Greyston will have moved on to the other applicants. 
"Some people are worth working with," said Crystal Williams, 34, a soft-spoken bakery supervisor who came to Greyston as the homeless mother of two sons. "And some people aren't. You can't help everybody; that's what I've learned here. But there are some people you can help. That's my goal to help those employees."

Zen Master and Maverick
Even in the rarefied company of Zen Buddhist masters, Mr. Glassman -- or, to use his religious title, Roshi Glassman -- is known as a maverick. Very few teachers of Zen, a famously inward-directed religion with a tradition of monastic meditation, get involved with antipoverty efforts. Let alone with conservative Republican mayors, federal low-income housing grants and poor African-American Christians whose initial response was unalloyed suspicion.
"Bernie had a dream,"' said Angelo R. Martinelli, a Republican who was the mayor of Yonkers from 1974 to 1987 and an early supporter of Mr. Glassman who says he was responsible for bringing him to Yonkers. "To build a company that would make a profit and do good works."
Mr. Glassman, born in Brooklyn, became an aeronautical engineer for McDonnell Douglas in 1959, where he wrote handbooks for the flight to Mars scheduled in 1974 (and which finally took place in 2001.) He and his wife, Sandra Jishu Homes, studied Zen Buddhism with Taizen Maezumi, one of the first Zen teachers to settle in the United States.
"What Zen brings is a realization of the interdependence of life," said Mr. Glassman, who left Greyston, though he is still on the board, to create the international Zen Peacemaker Order, a faith-inspired peace and social action organization. "We all have different works to do. With Zen, you do whatever you do the best you can. Phil Jackson was an athlete; he brought Zen to his basketball coaching. I'm from a very liberal Jewish family. Social service was something my family was very involved with. So I brought that to Zen."
He left McDonnell Douglas, completed studies to be a Zen master and opened a small monastery in Riverdale, sending some of his students to the San Francisco Zen center, which is famous for its cooking, to learn to bake. Back in the Bronx, they opened a little cafe and sold cakes to nearby specialty-food shops, to support the monastery.
And under a different Zen master, things might have continued that way: with the high-end cakes supporting the more-or-less high-end spiritual seekers. 
But Mr. Glassman, according to those who know him, has a way of pushing when life threatens to get comfortable. 
"He had a good thing going," said Julius Walls Jr., the chief executive of the Greyston Foundation for the last seven years who met Mr. Glassman through the cocoa business he used to work in. "He had a wonderful mansion overlooking the Hudson. And he turned his world upside-down."
Mr. Glassman said the issue "that grabbed the Zen students was the plight of the single-parent, homeless family."
"We decided we would start working with single-parent families," he said.
In the late 1980's, at the founding meeting of Social Ventures Network for socially minded corporations, Ben Cohen of Ben and Jerry's agreed to buy brownies from Greyston for fudge-brownie ice cream. "That's what got it to take off," Mr. Martinelli said.
Mr. Glassman wanted to hire the homeless to bake and apply the profits to build the Greyston Family Inn, a subsidized long-term residence for homeless families. But first he had to figure out how to make satisfactory brownies in large quantities. 
"They made mistakes," Mr. Martinelli said. "Believe me."
The factory's landlord reneged on a handshake deal. Residents of southwest Yonkers rallied successfully to block the sale of a vacant public school to renovate for the inn. "They were not welcomed at all," said Mr. Martinelli. "It was fear. They heard it was Zen Buddhist. Bernie was very, very shaken and downhearted. He said, 'I come to Yonkers and this is what I get.'
"But they learned a lesson. They had no black people on the board. They brought in people from the neighborhood."
Under Charles G. Lief, the departing president and a real-estate lawyer, Greyston now runs 175 units of subsidized housing, acquired with money raised through grants, foundations and the government. Zen and the art of luxury baking, along with Mr. Glassman himself and celebrities like Ellen Burstyn and Bonnie Raitt have given it the sheen of glamour that is so useful in attracting private donations.
After 20 years, Greyston has become a major player in the civic life of Yonkers, and not just for the poor.
To the Yonkers business community, Greyston is a real business," said Steven Whetstone, the city's commissioner for planning and development. "It works very diligently with an eye on the bottom line. I think there's a lot of respect for that. They're creating jobs. They're adding a lot to what we're trying to do: redevelop downtown Yonkers."

Intangible Advantages
Mr. Martinelli said every organization in Yonkers made sure to include Greyston officials on its guest lists for ground-breakings, ribbon-cuttings, anniversaries and holiday parties.
"They are loved today and you know why?" he said. "When they go, they bring their cakes and believe me, there is no better cake. Take the opening of the new public library. What do they serve? Greyston's lemon mousse cake and chocolate mousse cake, and those cakes are heaven."
The luxury cakes are, perhaps, not strictly necessary, Mr. Walls said. The bakery could probably produce more standard doughnuts, for example, and still adhere to its mission of employing the unemployable while making a profit.
But there are certain intangible but real advantages to producing Westchester's best cheesecake in a factory staffed by the once-homeless and imprisoned, he said. It boosts the employees' morale. It makes Yonkers proud. It means that there are always superb snacks around the workplace. And though he does not exactly say this, it gives him moments of unmitigated glee.
"Most of our customers had zero awareness of what Greyston was," Mr. Walls said. "They just thought we made great cakes. We don't tell them at first or they'd have a bias against us. Poor people eat doughnuts, right?
"As soon as they become aware of our program, their faces drop. Chefs at upscale restaurants say: 'You've got to be kidding! THOSE people! Are making THESE?"
Until 1998, the factory was running in the red. Mr. Walls called a meeting with all factory workers.
"I said: 'We need to make a profit or we're not going to be a success and you're not going have a job anymore. What do you need to do that? How can we reduce waste? How does each action impact the production?' And they thought, 'Wow, they care about what I think.' We talked for a day and everybody got to share. It got personal. It went from pure traditional business conversations to 'Why am I here and what do I want?'
"People said jaw-dropping things. One janitor was in a homeless shelter and sat by the phone all day to get our call and ironed his pants for the interview by putting them between two mattresses. People said they'd been in prison for drug dealing and stealing. They said: "I need to make money. I've got to keep this job."' 
Employees worked overtime. Waste was reduced. The factory made its first profit that fiscal year and has been running in the black and expanding, producing $4.5 million of baked goods today.
Greyston offers its employees unusual amounts of practical supports, like subsidized housing and day care, and counseling for personal problems and referrals for mental-health counseling, drug rehabilitation and education, from G.E.D. to college and trade school. For those who seek it out, there is also, by many accounts, emotional support.
"When I had my G.E.D. tests," Ms. Williams said, "Julius called and said, 'Are you ready?' He marked his calendar. He called that night and said, 'You thought I forgot, right?' "
When she passed in October, Mr. Walls and Mr. Lief sent letters congratulating her. She still carries them in her purse.
"This is love work," said Mr. Walls, who is from Bedford-Stuvesant in Brooklyn and who once created his own chocolate bar, Sweet Roots, to sell in African-American neighborhoods. . "We believe in these people. Hell, I grew up in the projects. I'm not doing this for the money. I saw what was going on here and I got geeked on the energy of love. People here sincerely believe it."
Now that she is a supervisor, Ms. Williams says she gives pep talks from her heart. She knows how repetitive and grueling the work is even for those who have advanced beyond the cleaning detail: lifting 100-pound bags of flour and sugar, wheeling 250-pound bowls of brownie mix, moving heavy baking pans from ovens to cooling racks. The pace is fast. There is also the difficulty of handling the routine of a job for the first time
"I remind them that I'm just like them," Ms. Williams said. "I know when they're tired and stress-up and like 'I can't take it anymore.' I try to keep their spirits up when they're arguing and fussing."
She would pull Mr. Sanchez over, she recalled: "I tell him: I know your friends are saying: 'Don't go to work. Come over. Hang out.' I tell him: 'Don't let them distract you.'
"One girl, I talked to her every day. I said: 'You're not here to make friends. You're here to support your two girls."'
Her path, from homelessness and helplessness to becoming Greyston's first female night supervisor, was difficult, she said. "The guys wouldn't pay me no mind," she said. "They thought I was just a woman."
But after long talks with Ms. Woodand Mr. Walls, she gained confidence. For months, at supervisors' meetings, she sat far in the back. Then, she began to get there early and take a seat up front. Now, she said, she always sits in the very front. Her seat is sacrosanct, she said. "This is my seat at the table."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Play Finds Time Is An Enemy

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: CROTON FALLS 

 BODY:
SURELY there are still Janie Blumbergs and Harriet Cornwalls out there, but does anybody care?
 It has been more than 20 years since "Isn't It Romantic," Wendy Wasserstein's popular breakout play, made these two best friends emblematic of feminist issues among bright, career-driven, upper- and "very upper" middle-class women on their own in Manhattan, pushing 30 and, alas, single. 
 It's anybody's guess why the Schoolhouse, which tends to avoid the mainstream, especially a mainstream from years gone by, is having a go at this play -- and a slow go it is.
Too overexposed to remain a stock staple and too recent to revive, Ms. Wasserstein's play now seems a tepid rehash of ethnic stereotypes (Janie is Jewish; watch out: a pushy mother lurks), and issues that have either become more complex or just plain non-issues. 
"Isn't it Romantic" has aged and none too flatteringly. Funny for an agenda play, it was once considered original in its exploration of identity, relationships and values. It's not that living is easier, society more expansive or conflicts better resolved these days. Indeed, it's all quite worse, but so inseparable from a wrecked economy and a panicked nation that the concerns of these privileged young women of the 80's could hardly be less consequential. Should Janie marry the doctor who calls her "monkey"? Should Harriet marry the man she has been dating for two weeks, now that she has broken off with a married lover who calls her "beauty"? 
Although Ms. Wasserstein's slickly glib style sounds formulaic and ineffectual here, the playwright's sense of the absurdity of alternatives is a saving grace. Still, there is little a director can do to move the play along.
The task of the director, Mary McGinley, is alleviated by the effervescence and quick wit of the classy Sarah K. Lippmann as Harriet and aggravated by the tedious Janie of Kate Sandberg, who appears more controlled and blase than unkempt and dizzily smart as the character is meant to be. Ms. Lippmann is especially endearing and poignant when she observes how tiresome it is to have to "work at everything," relationships, in particular. As Marty, who spares nothing in trying to land Janie as life partner, Benjamin Bauman's sweet affection is so genuine, his performance so sensitive, that Janie seems quite the fool for turning him away. The causes of feminism, self-fulfillment and independence are ill served by such oddly imbalanced casting. Then there is Charles F. Wagner IV who plays Paul, Harriet's smarmy fling who matter-of-factly sets the parameters of their relationship, no questions asked, no strings. The man is a creep. How is it that Mr. Wagner's layered performance suggests, emphatically, that there is far more complexity in Paul than is customarily acknowledged? The tally for a cast of eight: three surprises, (two good, one bad ) one splendid turn (Ms. Lippman); the others will do.
Paradoxically, Ms. Wasserstein writes plays of contemporary concerns that date quickly, perhaps because they are of the moment. Her work is often vastly entertaining at the expense of depth, settling for a smattering of valid perceptions ("It doesn't take strength to be alone; it's much harder to be in love with someone"). 
Characteristically, the quest for commercial appeal wins over passion and risk, which may be just why Ms. Wasserstein is the most popular and visible female playwright in decades. As this Schoolhouse staging, and the enemy, time, prove glaringly, a pop playwright needs to be presented with all the trimmings. Pizzazz and glamour are essential for maintaining the illusion of substance.
"Isn't It Romantic" by Wendy Wasserstein. Schoolhouse Theater, 3 Owens Road, Croton Falls.Through March 9. Tickets: (914)277-8477.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kate Sandberg as Janie, left, and Sarah K. Lippmann as Harriet. (Ron Marotta)

HEADLINE: Tough Times for the State Animal 

BYLINE:  By STACY LU 

DATELINE: ALLENDALE 

 BODY:
VALERIE BORNSTEIN still sounds wistful when she talks about the 12.7-acre horse boarding farm that her family once owned here. "My parents bought the property in 1945," Ms. Bornstein recalled. "In about 1955 we had a horse and then sometime around 1970 or so we added another 16 stalls. In Bergen County, people who bought a horse got a boarding stable. We always had a huge waiting list. We bred thoroughbreds, one a year." 
 As the stables grew, however, so did the town around them, until the farm was an agricultural oasis, abutting train tracks, set amid ranch houses and near a shopping strip. After the death of her father and repeated complaints around the neighborhood about dust and noise from the stables, Ms. Bornstein and her mother sold the land to a developer in 1999. They received $2 million and one of the townhouse condominiums to be built there, with an appraised value of $425,000. The town had already rezoned the area, to settle a suit brought by a developer. 
 The decision to sell was made reluctantly, Ms. Bornstein said. 
"You've brought back a lot of memories," she said to a reporter. "I was thinking about all the backyard horses there used to be. This town's changed a lot." 
These are turbulent times for horse owners throughout New Jersey who are facing ever-tougher economic and environmental obstacles. Medium-size and smaller farms that board horses and give riding lessons are being forced out in some counties because of restrictive zoning, development and neighborhood complaints. The recreational horse owners who keep animals in their backyards have virtually disappeared in some areas; some refused to comment for this article for fear of alerting neighbors that horses were being kept nearby. 
The New Jersey horse industry is old and proud, one of the most active and developed in the nation. It encompasses races, breeding, horse shows, rodeos, clinics and trail rides as well as recreational and handicapped riding and 4-H programs that are one of the few areas of growth in the industry. The largest livestock-based agricultural industry in the state, it employs nearly 6,000 people and generates $650 million in annual revenue, according to the state Department of Agriculture. More than six million people attend horse races and other events in the state each year. New Jersey is also home to the United States Equestrian Team, based in Gladstone. The state animal is, in fact, the horse.
Still, the number of horses is decreasing. A 1988 survey by the Department of Agriculture counted 60,000 equine animals - horses, mules, ponies and donkeys - while 49,000 were counted in 1996. Equine-related acres in the state numbered 120,000 in 1988; in 1996, there were 81,000, a loss of 33 percent. (The department is considering a new survey for next year, and the 1996 data are the latest available.)
The background is familiar: The most densely populated state in the nation, New Jersey has lost half its farmland since the 1950's. State agricultural statistics show that the number of dairy farms alone has fallen by more than half, to 250 in 2001 from 584 in 1987. 
Much of the land once devoted to farming is taken by new housing, attracting newcomers who are often intolerant of the dust, noises and smells that are part of keeping horses. 
Complaints from just two people about one farm can create a lot of problems, said Margie Margentino, who oversees the state's 4-H program.
"I'd rather smell a little horse odor than when the ChemLawn people come and spray the lawns," she said. "When I was growing up we all had horses in our backyard. It didn't matter if you had half an acre or two acres. We all had horses. We didn't have odor, noise problems or any of that stuff." 
Vikki Karcher Siegel, owner of Snowbird Acres Farm in Long Valley and a director of the New Jersey Horse Council, an industry group, blames immigrants from urban areas.
"They like the rural atmosphere, but then they try to change it to be the city," she said. They like the look of horses, "but they don't want flies, they don't want manure, they don't want a loose horse running in their yard, which of course is going to happen."
Most good barns do not problems with flies, she said, or with manure. "We deal with it because we wouldn't want the horses to suffer," she said. ""We're not doing anything that will seep through to the aquifer."
Some townships have worked hard to keep their horse farms, believing them to be economically viable ways of maintaining open space.
Dianne Gallets, township administrator of Washington Township in Morris County, said the county had preserved 4,231 acres on 63 farms under the state's Farmland Preservation Program. Under the program, established in 1983, farmers can sell or donate easements for development of their land to the state or a county agricultural development board, municipalities or nonprofit organizations. The sale price is based on the difference between what a developer would pay for the land and what it is worth for agriculture.
Morris County was the first to be approved for the program. These days there are many horse farms in the area, and few neighborhoodcomplaints.
"The horse farms keep the area looking country," Ms. Gallets said. "I think the people around here appreciate having areas of open space where they can just ride by and peek at the horses munching away."
The preservation program isn't for every farmer, however. James Fairclough, who has won world championships with the United States Equestrian Team and owns a 197-acre farm in Newton, said the preservation program in Sussex County did not offer him enough to make it worthwhile to sell his development easement. "I can cut mine into mini-farmettes and get three or four times that value," he said.
Though he plans to try again to sell his easement under the preservation program, Mr. Fairclough said: "At some point I'm going to get stepped out or pushed out. As a horseman you don't want to have your farm in the middle of a growing urban world. You want to have that peace of mind."
Ms. Siegel said of the preservation program: "On the surface it seems like a great idea, and if you need quick money, it's wonderful. But if you plan to stay, it doesn't make sense." She said that if restrictions made farming impossible, a farmer's children "aren't going to want to pay taxes on something they can't use."
According to a survey published last September by the Rutgers Equine Science Center, those in the horse industry say that, after the health of their animals, their biggest concern is the cost of doing business in the state, including property taxes and the cost and availability of farmland.The Equine Science Center is planning a meeting next month that it is calling a horse industry summit to discuss many concerns that showed up in the survey.
The economy, of course, has not helped. Dale Welk, general manager of Garden State Horse Sales based in Hanover, Pa., which handles large auctions, said prices of standardbred horses of lower pedigree had declined. However, the buyer base in New Jersey has not decreased as it has in other states, Mr. Welk said, and more horses are on the market, which could explain some of the price decreases. 
Outstanding racing horses seem to fetch top dollar no matter what the economic outlook. Dr. David Meirs, a semiretired veterinarian who raises standardbred horses at Walnridge Farm in Cream Ridge, said: "Buyers are going to say, 'To hell with the stock market, I did better with my racing stables last year.' Of course, it's more fun to go to the races than to watch your stocks every day."
The market for pleasure horses has different pressures. Karl Bauer, who breeds quarter horses and runs a training center in Pompton Plains, said horse sales had declined in recent years except for the very lowest-priced horses. "A lot of the horsemeat companies have closed down, so now we have an overload of very cheap horses that may have problems, whether they're lame or just bad attitude horses," he said. "So these horses are selling to the public, and that's hurting the market." 
In 2002 Governor McGreevey eliminated the state's supplement to thoroughbred racing purses, which had been as high as $18 million in 2001, significantly cutting the purses for the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park thoroughbred tracks. 
Chris McErlean, vice president and general manager of the Meadowlands Race Track, said: "You need sustained, incremental growth to get people to buy and race horses. But we feel we're racing too many days to sustain the level of purses we have right now, and that affects the quality of horses that we have, which affects the people who bet. Less money, lesser horses, less betting; it's kind of a vicious circle." 
Another big concern is environmental regulations. This spring the state is expected to announce how it will enforce new federal regulations on how agricultural operations that keep animals in close quarters handle waste. The rules are expected to require farms that keep a large number of animals to follow nutrient management plans. That includes evaluating what the animals are eating and their manure, conducting soil testing and proper fertilization, and adapting a manure disposal plan. The new rules are also expected to cover more smaller farms but to allow them to police their own handling of waste by using a checklist. 
Fines for violating a permit may range from $1,000 to $50,000 a day for each violation, with the amount depending on the farmer's conduct (was the violation willfull, for example?) and the seriousness of the effect on the environment.
Dr. Stephen P. Dey, a veterinarian who is a member of the state Board of Agriculture, said: "Farming is not making very much money as it is. To have this added on them, they're understandably concerned."
An industry that plays such a large part in the state's livelihood, full of centuries-old traditions and passionate animal lovers, is most likely to find ways to adapt, at least in the short term. Though the bigger farms are decreasing, anecdotal evidence suggests that the number of small operations on plots of three to five acres is increasing, particularly in mid-Jersey and South Jersey. 
"Monmouth County is losing farmland just as much as any other county in the state," said Richard Obal, an agriculture agent with Rutgers Cooperative Extension. "But there has been an upward growth in the number of farms that list equine, or horses, as their No.1 one use of the land."
Much land that was devoted to field crops like corn and soybeans now produces hay and forage crops to supply horse food. The county has about 11,500 horses, more than any other county in the state, and the number of horse farms there jumped to 1,250 in 1996, from 860 in 1988.
Though breeding and racing account for most of the industry's revenue, the number of horses kept for pleasure and sport in the state is increasing compared with those kept for racing.
Children seem to be just as fascinated with horses as ever, even when they don't have direct access to them. There has been a statewide increase in 4-H education events, like the Horse Quiz Bowl and the Model Horse Show, where the children, most of who don't have a chance to ride, paint and make equipment for plastic horses. 
"The pleasure horse industry and the youth development projects and the state 4-H office have become very strong," said Lynn Matthews, an equine specialist in the state Department of Agriculture. "The kids today are the future of agriculture, and to maintain a viable agriculture, we have to keep them interested." 
Bob Allen, who has a 30-acre farm in Moorestown that has been in operation for 40 years, says he teaches riding to about 250 students a week. 
"We've found our business has increased at least 10 percent with a lot of new homes being built," he said. "They're not apartment buildings, they're million-dollar homes, and those people are affluent enough for them to get involved in the horse industry and to teach their kids."
Mr. Allen's farm, which used to be surrounded by other farms, is the only one left "in the middle of a cute little town," he said, adding that though he welcomed the new business he felt isolated. 
Marianne Washienko, owner of Sport Horse Saddlery in Wyckoff, says her shop does more business now withparents than with farmers, a change she enjoys. "I can't tell you how many kids come in here," she said. "I can't tell you how excited and enthused they are about horses."
Others manage to buy large spreads, refusing to let a grand old way of life die.
Lisa Marie Post bought a horse farm on almost 20 acres in Perrineville three years ago and transformed it into the Chestnut Ridge Equestrian Center. She keeps 23 horses, 12 of which she owns and uses for lessons and shows.
Ms. Post jokes about buying "the last nice horse farm in Monmouth County" but says Millstone Township is doing its best to maintain the area's rural character. A piece of land abutting her farm was recently sold to a developer, and the township helped ensure a buffer zone of more than an acre between the Post farm and the new housing. She also had a few horse lovers on her side.
"One of the board members, his daughter took riding lessons here, so he was helpful making sure that everybody was happy," she said. "And the builder's sister rides horses, so he understood the flavor of the township."
Ms. Post has confidence in the future of her farm as well as her township. "I grew up in a suburban area and wound up doing this," she said. "People will always be interested in horses and always will want to ride. As we become more technical and mechanized, it's more and more important for people to get out and be with these animals, spend more time with nature. 
"I look at it this way: It's your goal and your job to pass this on so it doesn't die."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Hold Those Millionaire Farewells

BYLINE:  By JON SHURE; Jon Shure is president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, which conducts research on state issues.

 BODY:
AS momentum to raise the state income tax on those making more than $500,000 a year appears to grow, we are being warned: tax them more, and well-off New Jerseyans will up and leave the state. 
 Just imagine caravans of Lexuses and Mercedes-Benzes jamming the highways, with cases of Perrier and Grey Poupon strapped to their roofs in an upscale version of Oklahomans fleeing the Dust Bowl. Garden State emigres will abandon homes, friends, relatives and jobs rather than pay the extra two or three cents a dollar being proposed as a levy on part of their income. Better this than helping to lessen the effect of cutting programs and services in the face of a huge budget shortfall. 
 Taxing the most productive citizens out of New Jersey will leave the poor and middle classes to battle over crumbs while tumbleweeds blow down the avenues of Millburn and Alpine and squatters take over McMansions across the former wealth belt. 
That's what the scare scenarios say will happen. But does that really make sense?
Well, no, and there is proof. It turns out that the Internal Revenue Service keeps track of what it calls state-by-state migration data (and you thought it just collected taxes). Conveniently enough, the statistics go back to 1989, making it easy to see if New Jersey's last income tax increase, in 1990, caused the outflow that one would expect if state income tax rates played a big role in where people choose to live.
If today's doomsayers are right, there must have been a big spike in departures around 1990. But there was not. Indeed, when the income tax increase was in effect, the number of tax filers leaving New Jersey actually decreased, to 90,863 in 1993 from 106,712 in 1990. And when income tax cuts were phased in over three years, little changed. The number of departures decreased to 88,575 in 1994, increased to 91,714 in 1995 and then decreased again, to 90,520, in 1996.
In fact, in every year that data are available except two, if the number of people leaving the state went up so did the number coming in, and vice versa. This suggests that larger forces, like regional or national economic conditions, were at work.
Maybe examining where people who leave New Jersey go will reveal the role of taxes. Fed-up folks might choose New Hampshire, the nearest state with no income tax. But they don't. Year after year, only about a half a percent of people leaving New Jersey go to the Granite State.
What about Florida? It too has no income tax, and the weather is much nicer than in New Hampshire. People do go there -- but as many or more go to New York, where taxes are higher than in New Jersey. Florida and New York, along with Pennsylvania, are far and away the top destinations of people leaving New Jersey, accounting for about 60 percent of those who go. The other end of the scale remains pretty constant too: every year, North and South Dakota vie to be the least-favored destination for people leaving New Jersey.
The I.R.S. also tabulates income figures. Do they prove that rich people are just a tax hike away from folding their tents? Not hardly. 
The average income of New Jersey residents moving to New York is always higher than that of those who go to Florida or Pennsylvania. And, without fail, average incomes of everyone saying hello to New Jersey are higher than those saying goodbye. This would seem to make perfect sense, since a lot of people heading out are fixed-income retirees. But if income tax rates were the factor that some say they are, those numbers would certainly look different. Clearly, people choosing New Jersey are in their peak earning years, and an increase or decrease in the marginal state income tax rate doesn't influence their decision. 
Sure, some will go if the income tax rises. But a mass exodus or even a noticeable trend? It's just a myth.
The realities are these: Proposed tax increases would affect less than 2 percent of taxpayers. The pennies more per dollar they would pay are more than offset by what they have received back from state and federal tax cuts. 
Myths have a certain appeal, but in the end, reality is more compelling.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Genteel Nostalgia, Going Out of Business 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
The store's front window told the story, all of it. 
 There was a blue crocheted shawl and framed needlepoint art of a lighthouse, two white hand-knitted baby sweaters and a handful of cream-colored antique bowls -- all reminiscent of a time when New Yorkers wore handmade clothes, drank more tea than lattes, and played with rag dolls. 
 But alongside these markers of an older, perhaps gentler New York, the store window had a new sign, more modern and increasingly familiar: "Going Out of Business."
The New York Exchange for Woman's Work, founded 125 years ago so that Civil War widows could earn a "proper" living by selling their hand-knitted scarves and mittens, will close at 149 East 60th Street in Manhattan on Friday. The model for dozens of similar enterprises across the country, the exchange survived the Great Depression, two world wars, and the 1970's economic crisis by selling everything from liquor and lingerie to crab cakes and sweaters for dogs. 
But now, high rent and overhead, coupled with tough economic times and a waning taste among consumers for handmade products, has forced the exchange to close.
"It's a shame," said Carmen Debono, who lives around the corner from the exchange and goes in once a month to shop. "It has the small-town feel." Yet even as she sifted through mittens for her children, ages 3 and 5, and tried on a woolen hat for herself, she also wondered aloud how the store had made it so far. 
The exchange was founded in 1878 by Candace Wheeler, an interior designer, and Mary Atwater Choate, a prominent New Yorker who also founded Choate Rosemary Hall, the preparatory school. Its first home was in the Choate parlor at 108 East 31st Street. The Civil War had made widows of a number of well-off women who needed to earn a living but who were too genteel to leave home for work. So the women baked and knitted to ward off poverty and sold their products through the exchange. 
Staying afloat by selling cookies and smock dresses was not always easy, though. Over the years, the exchange remained in business by using loans from the wealthy husbands of the women on its board and posting signs in Central Park advertising the store. 
The exchange made its name -- and some of its fortune -- with its restaurant, which opened in 1919 at its old site, 541 Madison Avenue. The restaurant sold bittersweet chocolate cake and home-baked crab cakes, codfish balls and wedding cakes. It became a place to eat well and inexpensively and to be seen. In 1934, after Prohibition ended, the exchange opened another famed spot, the Crinoline Bar, which served sidecars and Manhattans to women wearing gloves. 
Given its famous founders and Manhattan location, the New York Exchange for Woman's Work was the standard for exchanges across the country by the end of the 19th century, according to Kathleen Waters Sander, the author of "The Business of Charity: The Woman's Exchange Movement, 1832-1900." At least 75 similar exchanges had sprouted up in cities from Boston to San Diego by 1900. Only about a half-dozen of those exchanges will be in operation when the one in Manhattan closes. 
"You can't run a shop based on the small profits you make from selling smocks," Ms. Waters Sander said. 
So nostalgia is on sale now at the New York exchange. On a recent visit to the dimly lit ground-floor store, imitation Raggedy Ann dolls were slumped on the shelves with tags announcing 20 percent off their $87.50 price. Antique doll furniture and sterling silver sugar tongs were half off. A wooden Noah's Ark complete with Noah, elephants and zebras priced at $195 was 50 percent off -- as was a hand-crocheted "huggie coaster" that wraps around a soda can. It was $2.50. 
"It's nothing in our consignors' pockets, and our pockets," Dawn Miner, the store manager, said, adding that some consignors chose not to lower their prices. 
The store takes 40 percent of what an item is sold for and gives 60 percent to consignors, who number around 450 and now also include men. Consignors submit tax forms showing they have low incomes or other financial hardships to qualify for having their merchandise sold at the store. The shop's board members would not give the names of their consignors, citing rules of confidentiality. 
Among the things that killed the exchange are the simple laws of income and outgo. The store's monthly rent is about $11,000; tax returns for 2001 show that the store made about $275,000 but had only $115,000 left after paying consignors and buying merchandise. And that was not enough to cover the almost $308,000 a year needed for the rent and salaries for a staff of seven. 
Beyond that, the business of the handmade has changed, according to Catherine Dinehart, the store's former manager. When she began in 1989, she would meet with 20 prospective consignors twice a week. By the time she left about a decade later the number had dwindled to four or five consignors. 
"As the expenses of doing business have gone up so have the expenses of making things," Ms. Dinehart said. Materials like yarn for knitting have increased in price, she said. But it has been hard to pass that on to consumers. 
"One woman said, 'Your things are so expensive. I can get them at the Gap,' " said Manie Van Doren, a board member and a member of the well-known New York family. "What she didn't realize is that they're handmade."
The exchange tried to increase revenue by selling machine-made merchandise that fit with the illusion of the handmade, like handbags by the designer Vera Bradley -- but that meant spending money before earning it, Ms. Miner said. 
"The necessity for the handmades is not there," Ms. Miner said. "People are looking for a bargain.'
Another negative factor was the move from Madison Avenue to Third Avenue in 1991, changing the store's clientele from high-level executives and international tourists to neighborhood residents and workers from Bloomingdale's across the street, Ms. Dinehart said. Squeezed now between a pizzeria and a gourmet deli on East 60th Street off Lexington Avenue, the exchange doesn't get as many shoppers for its stock, ranging from wool sweaters for Upper East Side dogs, knit by Bolivian women, to a handmade door pillow declaring "Home Sweet Penthouse." 
The beginning of the end may have come in 1979, when the restaurant was required to become a for-profit establishment. It closed instead, ending an era of famous codfish balls and steady revenue for the exchange. 
The Brooklyn Women's Exchange at 55 Pierrepont Street is also struggling, said Grace Gutman, president of its volunteer committee. The store has cut back on buying machine-made merchandise and has brought in Brooklyn authors for book signings. Ms. Gutman said the 150-year-old shop also does well by being in a residential neighborhood with young families who shop for handmade baby clothes and toys. 
To survive, the exchanges must market themselves as a good cause, Ms. Waters Sander said. "Unless the exchanges get that message out there, they're just another shop on the block," she said.
But a recent visit to the store revealed that, worthy cause or not, shoppers were bargain hunting. Elizabeth Barbour, a retired housekeeper, admitted that the "Going Out of Business" sign brought her into the store. "I came in to see the Vera Bradley bags," she said, smiling. "But they were all gone."
Another shopper, dressed in a full-length fur coat and carrying a Bloomingdale's bag, asked if the crocheted stuffed animals were really 20 percent off. They were. 
"They're flocking in to buy everything we have," Ms. Miner, the store manager, said. "Too bad this wasn't happening a couple of months ago.'

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DIPLOMACY IN THE EAST; 
Powell Seeks Asian Support for New U.S.-Backed Resolution

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
Saying that the United States is entering into a period of "intense diplomacy" on Iraq, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he had urged Japan's leaders to help the United States lobby members of the United Nations Security Council to support an American-sponsored resolution on Iraq.
 Mr. Powell made his comments following a series of meetings on Saturday night with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi and Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi on the first leg of a five-day swing through Asia that will take Mr. Powell to Beijing later today and then to South Korea on Monday. 
 "We hope that the prime minister and foreign minister, because they have been supporting our efforts, will continue to support those efforts," Mr. Powell told reporters this morning. "I hope that once they see the resolution, they will find it the appropriate thing to do to show support for that and to contact members" of the Security Council.
American officials say that Mr. Koizumi has emerged as a potentially important ally for the United States in winning support from fence-sitting members of the Security Council in joining the United States and Britain's campaign to win passage of a second resolution endorsing the use of force to disarm Iraq.
Though Japan is not among the Security Council's 15 members, American officials contend it maintains good relations with several of the 10 nonpermanent members of the Council, in large part because of its foreign aid commitments. One of the countries Japan is thought to have particularly good ties with on the Council is Angola. 
"Japan, I think, has the potential to be very helpful in that effort," a senior State Department official said. 
But it remains unclear just how far Japan will be will to go to support the United States on Iraq. Though Mr. Koizumi has suggested that Japan would be willing to support the use of force to disarm Iraq, he has also indicated he would prefer that the United States first receive Security Council backing. 
In Japan, as in much of Europe, opinion polls show that the public opposes war with Iraq without United Nations backing.
American officials said they are hoping that Japan, in addition to lobbying members of the Security Council, will support military action against Iraq by providing fuel and warships. 
Japanese ships are currently assisting the United States in naval operations in the Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea as part of Operation Enduring Freedom, but Japanese officials have indicated that they will need a vote of the Japanese Parliament to authorize the use of those ships in a military action against Iraq.
Mr. Powell said he also discussed strategies for resolving the standoff with North Korea with the Japanese leaders. Though Japan has urged the United States to talk directly with the north, Mr. Powell said that Mr. Koizumi and Ms. Kawaguchi agreed with the Bush administration that those talks should take place under the aegis of a "multilateral forum." 
The United States has proposed inviting North Korea to a meeting involving 8 other nations and the European Union. That would include the five permanent members of the Security Council -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- plus South Korea, Australia and Japan. 
However, Pyongyang has rejected that idea, demanding that the United States meet with North Korea alone. Mr. Powell said the Japanese had offered another proposal for a forum, but declined to describe it. 
"It is not just a U.S.-D.P.R.K. problem," Mr. Powell said, referring to North Korea's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. "That's what happened last time when we thought the problem was solved."
Mr. Powell also said that the United States was prepared to assist North Korea economically if it permanently abandons its nuclear weapons programs. Mr. Powell is expected to announce a continuation of American food aid to North Korea, which had ended in December, when he visits South Korea for the inauguration of the new president, Roh Moo Hyun, on Tuesday. 
"You can't eat plutonium," Mr. Powell said. Referring to North Korea, he added, "As long as you pursue those technologies, those who can help you grow the things that you can eat and develop an economy that will assist your people, can't help you."

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
Biotech: Golden Egg Or Wrong Basket?

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
SINCE 1995, when Governor Pataki committed the state to developing biotechnology on Long Island, the state has poured $95 million into turning the Route 110 area into a hot spot for the life sciences industry.
 One beneficiary has been a drug development company called OSI Pharmaceuticals, the anchor tenant of an incubator, a 53,000-square-foot building built by the state in 2000 on the campus of Farmingdale State University. OSI, which has a cancer drug now in the final stage of clinical testing, is often cited as a brimming-with-potential biotech company that represents the region's future. 
 The starting date of that future, however, is uncertain. Like most biotech companies, OSI fared poorly last year. The company posted a net loss of $218.5 million, more than 10 times its revenues. 
"People expect biotech companies to lose money," said Colin Goddard, the company's chief executive. 
OSI's troubles were not unusual for the industry. The Amex Biotechnology Index, a group of 17 stocks, dropped 40 percent in 2002, its second consecutive year of decline. Local biotech companies got not a single dollar in venture-capital investments in 2002, down from $3 million in 2001, according to Ernst & Young. Most analysts are not expecting this year will be much better.
Despite a $11.5 billion budget deficit, the Pataki administration continues to spend to develop a biotech sector on Long Island. A few weeks ago, administrators at Farmingdale State received notice from Albany that work would soon begin on a second $20 million incubator building in the fledgling biotechnology park.
A third and smaller incubator, as yet unbudgeted, is planned for the Farmingdale campus. When built, it will complete what is envisioned as a huge petri dish on the Suffolk-Nassau border, nurturing as many as 35 biotech start-ups.
"Scientists have a herding instinct, and you see biotech companies clustering together," said Bruce Stillman, the director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, which maintains close ties with the Farmingdale incubator. "Until you have a few of them inthe cluster, you don't see any. Instead of coming to Long Island, they go to New Jersey."
But could the state have put all its eggs in the wrong basket? 
Local business leaders and government officials say that regardless of current circumstances, the industry will one day generate thousands of new, high-paying jobs. Thomas R. Suozzi, Nassau's county executive, has cited biotech as central to the county's future, and on Tuesday he will deliver his State of the County address from Cold Spring Harbor Lab. 
"It can take 10 years or more, and more than $100 million, to get a new drug approved and on the market," said James A. Hayward, the chief executive of the Collaborative Group, a biotech concern in Stony Brook, and former chairman of the governor's task force on Long Island incubators. "But when the drug hits the market, the payoffs can be truly enormous."
Dr. Stillman said that the state's investment in infrastructure in Farmingdale had kept companies like OSI on Long Island and had also prompted other companies, including Forest Labs of Manhattan and Icon Laboratories of Farmingdale, to lease over 100,000 square feet of vacant retail space within walking distance of the incubator and convert it to laboratory use.
In general, incubators provide lower-cost laboratory and office space, specialized support services like water filtration and disposal of contaminated sewage, easy access to the resources of the surrounding campus, even a social calendar. 
Industry leaders say incubators also contribute to the impression that a region supports biotech development.
"When you see the incubators go up, and you hear the governor talk about biotechnology when he gives a speech on television, you feel the region is serious about attracting biotech companies," said Ron Cohen, president of the New York Biotechnology Association and a biotech entrepreneur in Hawthorne, N.Y. 
Incubators are especially prized in biotechnology because many start-ups struggle along for years without products to sell, burning investor dollars.
"We are in desperate need of that second incubator," said Greg Blyskal, the manager of the Broad Hollow Biosciences Park, which houses the incubator on the Farmingdale State campus. "We have been approached by half a dozen biotech companies looking for space. If we don't have space for them on Long Island, we run the risk that they'll move somewhere else."
OSI pays about $23 a square foot for space in the incubator and provides some maintenance services; Immuno-Rx and Helicon Therapeutics, its much smaller co-tenants, pay about $17 a square foot. Mr. Blyskal estimated that such space would cost $40 to $50 a square foot on the commercial market, and it is in short supply.
While tenants clearly benefit from subsidized space and convenient services, the host university benefits as well, advocates say. When an incubator opens, it attracts entrepreneurial tenants and integrates them into campus life. The tenants can enrich the overall academic environment by teaching courses, hiring faculty members for their special projects or long-term consulting arrangements and employing students as entry-level lab technicians. 
So far, none of that has happened at Farmingdale State. University officials say the reason is because the school lacks a biotech program, though in September it plans to introduce one for undergraduates, with an emphasis on manufacturing processes, officials said.
Advocates like the Long Island Life Sciences Initiative, a year-old consortium of regional biotech and related businesses, say that constructing incubators and other services for small biotech companies will allow the region to compete credibly with other leading biotech centers like northern New Jersey; Cambridge, Mass.; Research Triangle Park, N.C.; and San Francisco.
Proponents say the state's investment will allow the region to capitalize more fully on research advances made at institutions like Cold Spring Harbor Lab, the State University at Stony Brook, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and North Shore-Long Island Jewish Hospital.
In addition to the two incubators in Farmingdale, the Pataki administration has allocated $35 million for genome research at Cold Spring Harbor Lab, $16 million for biotechnology and electronics research at Stony Brook and $4 million for an magnetic resonance imaging center at North Shore-L.I.J.
The decision to anoint biotechnology as the region's technological forte, and to turn Farmingdale State into the academic nucleus able to attract investors, scientists and technical workers from around the world, was made mainly behind closed doors early in the Pataki administration, part of a $1 billion plan to manage technological growth throughout the state.
For Long Island, Governor Pataki pushed the life sciences ahead of various other technologies with equal or stronger claims on the economic future, including software engineering and wireless communications.
"The decision was made out of the governor's office, and not on any broad-based consensus" among business and political leaders, said Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. 
"In terms of anyone doing a comprehensive analytic examination, in terms of which technology would ultimately be more economically beneficial to the region, I have not seen any such study," added Dr. Koppelman, who participated in Dr. Hayward's incubator task force. "I had the impression it all came down amore or less unilaterally from Albany. Everyone seemed to accept it. The attitude on Long Island is that anything that comes from Albany is good. If it's money, you accept it."
Four calls to the governor's office for comment were directed to the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency, and were not returned. 
Since the policy's implementation, regional business, political and academic leaders have in general coalesced in support. Many recall participating in an unsuccessful effort a decade ago to convince Governor Pataki's predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, to take similar steps to stanch an exodus of scientists, trained assistants and intellectual property from the area's research institutions.
Much of the support on Long Island has been in terms of articulating an economic rationale for the governor's policy. In November the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group, published a report in Business LI, its monthly magazine, that depicted a rosy economic future for biotech on Long Island.
The report, which was sponsored by Farmingdale State, cited biotechnology as one of the "high-wage industries likely to spearhead Long Island's economic growth for the reasonable future." 
Pearl Kamer, the association's economist and the report's author, said, "It is clear that the sector has already become a major engine of growth on Long Island."
Joseph Scaduto, the executive director of Long Island Life Sciences Initiative, said: "Those of us who work in biotech are actually going to improve the quality of life. We are trying to cure disease here."
But the number of Long Island biotech companies that meet Mr. Scaduto's descriptionis actually rather small. A regional economic study released last year by the New York Biotechnology Association, which has its headquarters at Stony Brook, showed that Nassau and Suffolk are home to 23 biotech companies, employing some 4,000 people.
The numbers become much larger when the industry is redefined to include companies that make vitamins, cosmetics and medical devices. Using this extended definition, Dr. Kamer, the economist, estimated in her November report that in 2001, biotech companies supported some 34,800 additional jobs in service and supplier industries, creating a payroll approaching $967 million.
Biotech advocates say that despite the industry's current doldrums, biotech is likely to rebound, and the region's biotech investment is likely to pay off handsomely down the line. "Biotech by nature has a much longer road to profitability" than many other industries, said Robert Sturm, the managing partner for Long Island technology practices at PricewaterhouseCoopers office in Jericho.
"Investors are pretty tight with their wallets right now," he added. "When investors are prepared to take long-term risks, you'll see biotech coming back."
