HEADLINE: Arts Groups Balk at Dancing To McGreevey Tune on Budget 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the largest arts organization in the state, Lawrence Goldman was among a handful of leaders in the arts recently invited to Governor McGreevey's office on the day before the governor went public with his proposed budget. Mr. Goldman knew that being summoned to Trenton could mean only bad news, but no one in the room knew how bad until the governor told the group that he would recommend eliminating all state funds for arts.
 The governor's plan would disband the state Council on the Arts and its 17 employees, discontinue $18 million in grants to 700 arts groups after this year, eliminate the state Historical Commission and $4.1 million in grants to historical sites, and stop giving $10 million a year to the state's Cultural Trust, a program established under former Gov. Christie Whitman to help arts groups build up endowments to carry them in tough fiscal times. 
 If the Legislature adopts the plan, New Jersey will become the only state in the nation without an arts council, thereby risking the loss of $2 million in federal grants. 
Once Mr. Goldman and his colleagues recovered from their collective shock, the next message from Governor McGreevey, according to Mr. Goldman and others at the meeting, was something to the effect of "now go out there and turn up the volume as loud as you can."
It is this mixed message that has many in the arts community questioning whether they can take Mr. McGreevey at his word -- either his latest word on these cuts or his word from last summer, when he appeared before dozens of arts organizations and promised to be the next arts governor.
"Two weeks ago, New Jersey was esteemed in this nation as one of three or four of the most enlightened states as far as arts funding goes," Mr. Goldman said. "Now, in one blow, we are the poster boy for the idea that as soon as the going gets tough, the arts are the first to go." 
Many New Jersey artists are wondering if the governor is counting on the state's vocal and well-organized arts community to serve as a pawn, forcing the Legislature to come up with money, possibly in the form of a tax increase.
"He's telling us, 'I cut your funding, now you go out and help me,"' said John Pietrowski, the artistic director at Playwrights Theater of New Jersey in Madison. "So we have to do the dance he's asked us to do, and for an artist, it's humiliating. We're creative individuals and don't like to be told how to dance."
A spokeswoman for the governor, Ellen Mellody, attributed the move to the state's overall budget difficulties.
"It's hard to justify hanging a picture on the wall when you can't put food on the table," Ms. Mellody said. "The budget crisis in New Jersey is the most severe it's been since World War II, and the governor has been forced to cut programs that are near and dear to his heart."
She called Mr. McGreevey "an ardent supporter of the arts."
Because of the state's financial woes, most arts organizations said they had expected cuts in line with the 10 percent to 15 percent reductions in other departments, or maybe even as much as 50 percent, as was the case 12 years ago in the last fiscal crisis. But no one expected complete elimination.
"He is telling the people that his value of the arts is zero, not 20 percent, not 10 percent, but zero," said John McEwen, executive director of the New Jersey Theater Alliance. "And this was after he repeatedly said he supported the arts."
Even Secretary of State Regena Thomas, whose department oversees most of the state's arts, history and cultural programs, said she was shocked at the severity of the cuts. As the arm of government most heavily involved in grant programs, the State Department stands to suffer the highest percentage of reductions, with the governor proposing to cut 109 grant programs in all. The department would lose $42 million of its $47 million budget. 
"Other departments were hurt; we died," said Ms. Thomas, who added that she spent the Sunday night before that fateful Monday meeting at the governor's mansion earlier this month begging him to reconsider his recommendations. As a member of the governor's cabinet, however, Ms. Thomas says she understands that the state, which is facing a $5 billion budget deficit, cannot spend money it does not have.
"I'm going to do the best I can to support the governor," said Ms. Thomas, who has told members of the arts community that she will be available to "hold their hands" but not much else.
"At the end of the day, we want to be considered as doing the right thing," she added. "We're treading water. Until I am drowned, I will continue to do so."
Kimber Craine of the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies holds out a ray of hope for survival of the state arts council, especially in a state as culturally rich as New Jersey.
"It hasn't happened in the past," Mr. Craine said. "And given the past history, I think it would be very difficult. The arts have tremendous grass-roots support, these agencies are really very tiny, and eliminating them wouldn't make a dent in the state budgets." 
Two other states, however, are considering similar moves, the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies says. The governor of Missouri has recommended zero financing for that state's arts council, and a legislative panel in Arizona is considering a similar reduction. 
Ms. Mellody said Governor McGreevey had invited members of the Legislature to meet with Treasury Secretary John McCormac to "show him where the money can come from" for programs they want to support.
A decade ago, after Gov. James J. Florio cut the arts budget in half, to $10 million, about 20 arts organizations went out of business and 20 more were severely compromised, according to Ann Marie Miller, executive director of ArtPride New Jersey, a statewide arts advocacy group. This time, with a proposal for no state funds, and with a weak economy, Ms. Miller predicted that hundreds of arts, history and cultural organizations could end up closing.
In addition, arts advocates argue that the effect of the proposed cuts on the state budget is minuscule, with arts funds representing less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the overall state budget. Moreover, they point out, the governor would be eliminating one of the few resources that provide revenue streams to the state. (Also being axed in the governor's proposed budget are the Motion Picture and Television Development Commission and the statewide local tourism program.)
"From an economic point of view, it is a completely illogical move," said Sharon Harrington, the chairman of the State Council on the Arts. She pointed to a recent Rutgers University study that found that arts and cultural institutions generate $1 billion in revenue and $27 million in tourism and entertainment taxes annually for New Jersey. 
"It's disrespectful of our heritage," Ms. Harrington said.
Although it is the largest single donor to the arts, the state is hoping that the private sector will pick up the slack. But large foundations, corporate and private donors have also lost assets in the current economic climate, and in many cases that has already meant has meant reduced contributions to the arts. 
An exception, the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, will slightly increase its donations to New Jersey arts this year, with $4.4 million in grants slated. After the state, it is the largest contributor to the arts in New Jersey. Like other foundations, it says the value of its portfolio has decreased, by 20 percent in the last year, according to David Grant, the executive director. But rather than cut arts contributions, the foundation has reduced its support in areas like education and the environment.
Mr. Grant says it is unrealistic to expect the private sector to fill the void left by the state's retreat.
"We were feeling that the arts groups were already under stress and needed us even before this devastating news last week," he said. "We're already filling a gap, but we have no more money to fill."
The state Council on the Arts was established in 1967 as an outgrowth of the National Endowment of the Arts, created by Congress to ensure that every state had an agency to distribute federal funds for the arts to local institutions. Today, all 50 states and 9 territories have arts councils. By eliminating its arts program, New Jersey risks losing matching grants from the national endowment, which last year awarded more than $2 million to arts organizations in the state.
With an air of uncertainty surrounding their future, arts organizations throughout the state are moving cautiously with plans for theater seasons or exhibition schedules.
Mary Sue Sweeney Price, director of the Newark Museum, is anticipating layoffs and more pressure to charge admission to the museum, which now operates on a pay-what-you-wish system. The museum receives about 25 percent of its budget from the state, based on a contractual commitment from the Legislature to support the museum after the 1967 riots. Crediting the museum not only with educating more than 500,000 people a year but also with aiding the rebirth of downtown Newark, Ms. Price said she feared the governor's plan would hurt the cities the most.
"In Newark in particular, the momentum is going to be impacted when the arts are shackled in this way," Ms. Price said. "We are the wealthiest state in the union. It is inconceivable to me that we are not going to support our arts." 
Not ones to sit on their hands, members of the arts community have sprung into action in the last three weeks to fight the proposed cuts. ArtPride, which received 1,500 e-mail messages within the first 24 hours of the governor's announcement, is organizing an editorial and letter-writing campaign. Demonstrations and marches are being planned for the months leading up to the Legislature's vote on the new budget, which must be in place by July 1.
"The governor has sent a message to us that the arts don't matter, that they are expendable and that the public is going to let this slip away," Ms. Miller said. "My response is, 'You're wrong and we want to make sure you know it."'
The day after the governor presented his budget, Jeffrey Norman, the vice president of public affairs at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, appeared on stage before a performance of "Some Like It Hot" in Prudential Hall to ask the audience to help fight the proposed cuts. Other theaters throughout the state are planning similar entreaties to their audiences.
"Anyone who comes here knows we hardly ever make curtain speeches," Mr. Norman said in an interview later. "But now we have to be vigilant. When do we stop devaluing the arts?"
The Performing Arts Center, which last year received $1.4 million from the state, will also call on its board members -- heavy-hitters like Raymond Chambers, an owner of the New Jersey Nets; Arthur F. Ryan, chief executive of Prudential; and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean -- to reach out to their friends in Trenton.
"Often times the messenger is as important as the message," Mr. Norman said. "These are people who, when they speak, people listen. They're communicating with politicians on a regular basis, so for them to say on the side 'Hey, I care about the arts' is an important message."
Governor McGreevey, himself a frequent member of the audience at the Performing Arts Center and at the New Jersey Symphony, posed recently with his wife and daughter before a wall of paintings in the State House. The photograph was to be used for the next phase of the advertising campaign called Discover New Jersey Arts. Given the recent turn of events, the governor's spokeswoman said, the ad has been placed on hold.

HEADLINE: Croatia Waiting for a European Balkans Plan 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Croatia's application to join the European Union has challenged Western Europe to devise a strategy for admitting countries from the Balkans, which after a decade of wars were all promised membership one day.
 The Croatian prime minister, Ivica Racan, submitted the application on Friday during a visit to Greece, which holds the European Union's rotating presidency for the first half of this year. 
 Greece has urged its fellow member states to increase development assistance to its Balkan neighbors.
But calls from Athens for additional commitments from the European Union have met with resistance in Brussels and other Western European capitals, where some policy makers still question the decision last year to let 10 countries -- mostly former Communist states -- join the European Union in 2004. 
As the United States cuts back its commitments across the volatile Balkan peninsula, the European Union is under increasing pressure to develop more detailed plans for economic and political development than its current promise that all southeastern European countries can join eventually if they reform.
Croatia's application will be put aside for now. But the Greek foreign minister, George Papandreou, said it would stimulate debate on the broader questions involved, which will be the focus of a European Union summit meeting in Salonika, Greece, in June.
"This is a sign of the growing bond between the E.U. and the southeastern part of Europe," Mr. Papandreou said after meeting Mr. Racan. 
But officials from other member states were less enthusiastic. Even though Croatia is economically more advanced than Romania and Bulgaria, which are already candidates for European Union membership, it still has much to do to convince the outside world that it has overcome the nationalist legacy of its war of independence from Yugoslavia. 
"When they hand over the application for membership, they should also consider handing over some war criminals," a European diplomat said.
Some Balkan policy makers are concerned that a growing focus on the region's problems, from cooperation with the United Nations war crimes tribunal to the prevalence of organized crime, is distracting officials from addressing underlying economic and political issues that make these problems worse.
"Why should it be a question of focusing on one or the other?" said Alex Rondos, Mr. Papandreou's chief adviser. "Surely you can do both. The more reassuring Europe is, the easier it will be to deal with war crimes issues and other problems." 
In an effort to remind European officials that there is more to Croatia than its location and turbulent recent history, Mr. Racan submitted his official one-page application with an accompanying multimedia CD-ROM. Along with facts about the country, there were also pictures of its scenic Adriatic coast and its most famous athletes. 
The title, "RE: member Croatia," reflects a widespread sense in the Balkans that these countries have disappeared off Europe's radar screen now that they all have democratically elected governments and that open hostilities have ceased.
Aid from the European Union, which has run into billions of dollars since conflicts ripped apart Yugoslavia in the early 1990's, is scheduled to taper off in the next few years, even though the region's recent comparative stability is far from entrenched. 
Noting this fact, reports from several international research institutes have emphasized the need to increase financial assistance and to develop better incentives to encourage reforms alongside existing penalties for noncompliance.
"There's an understandable feeling in the Balkans that you only get money out of the E.U. if you start a war or you're already a candidate for membership," said a senior European Union official. "We have to do something to dispel that but we can only work with what's available."
Five Balkan presidents are meeting next month to develop a common negotiating position for the summit meeting, but with European attention focused on Iraq, major policy changes are unlikely.
"The problem," one European diplomat said, "is that the Balkans are now in the hands of middle-ranking bureaucrats who aren't decision makers and don't cut it analytically."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Raising a Glass (and Doing Some Math)

BYLINE:  By TED LOOS 

 BODY:
FOR students at Harvard Business School, accustomed to number-crunching and case studies, it may have sounded like the ultimate field trip: three days at "Cakebread U." in the Napa Valley.
 Over their winter holiday break, 10 aspiring M.B.A.'s -- all members of the school's Wine and Cuisine Society -- headed west with five friends. Jack Cakebread, the founder of Cakebread Cellars, a winery in Rutherford, Calif., had promised an introduction to the wine industry, complete with tastings and fine meals. 
 Mr. Cakebread held forth on the romance of the grape, but also on bottling and cellars. A "meet the experts" panel featured two vice presidents of American AgCredit bank, who talked about loans. 
"I expected it to be more on the wine appreciation side," said Vikram Punwani, 27, a member of the class of 2004. "But we got a lot more than that. Jack's idea was to really show us the business side in depth."
Cakebread U., which convened for the first time last month, grew out of the proprietor's hobby. For five years, Mr. Cakebread has been traveling -- to Harvard, Yale, the University of Pennsylvania, Duke, Columbia, Northwestern and elsewhere -- to deliver seminars at business schools. The idea, he said, "is to entice these brilliant young people to come into the wine business."
The notion to reach out to business schools came up during a conversation in 1997 with Chuck Palombini, president of Kobrand, the company that distributes Cakebread. "At the time, the dot-commers were riding very high," Mr. Cakebread recalled. "Hundred-dollar bottles of wine were fairly frequent, and there was a great interest in wine all over."
While he does not have an M.B.A. himself, Mr. Cakebread is a member of the Napa Valley's old guard. He started his own winery for $2,500 in 1973, after running his father's auto repair shop and working as a photographer. His wines now sell for $30 to $100 a bottle.
Even in a slow economy, Mr. Cakebread's wines sell out every year. His business-school seminars have been almost as successful.
"Other than celebrities like Jack Welch, Jack's one of the top draws," said Mark Zmijewski, the deputy dean of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.
Mr. Cakebread, now 73, is still the chairman and chief executive of Cakebread Cellars. But several years ago, he decided he wanted to cut back on traveling, including the trips to deliver his business seminars. "I'm sitting on the plane one day," he said. "And I thought, 'Why don't they get their young bones out to my university?' "
For students, Mr. Cakebread's entrepreneurial history appears to be just as appealing as the age-old allure of wine. '
"He puts himself out in front of his product," said Aliceson Robinson, 24, also from the class of 2004.
Mr. Cakebread said he might do four programs a year, all by invitation. The next session, for students from Yale and Duke, will start on March 10. The students pay for transportation, lodging and tuition, which is $295. Mr. Cakebread said the fee did not cover all his costs.
In January, Mr. Cakebread began the class with a guided tour, a primer on how wines are made, and a panel of experts on marketing, sales, distribution and finance.
"The second day was really fun," Mr. Punwani said. "We split up, and they gave us some barrel samples. We had to blend them together and design our own wine."
After coming up with a blend -- Mr. Punwani's group named theirs Meadow Merlot -- they had to devise a business plan.
Mr. Cakebread is no softie. He found the plan of one group lacking, and said so.
"We asked how they were going to finance it," Mr. Cakebread recalled. "They said, 'Borrow $5 million from Cakebread Cellars. We'll also use Cakebread Cellars' winemaker, and its distribution system.'
"I told them: 'I think you guys failed this one. Try again.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: It was some work and some play for members of Harvard Business School's Wine and Cuisine Society at a three-day seminar at Cakebread Cellars in Rutherford, Calif. (Susan Ragan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Twilight Of the CD? Not if ItCan Be Reinvented 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
TONIGHT in Manhattan, rock stars, divas and rappers will descend en masse on Madison Square Garden, arriving at the Grammy ceremonies in a parade of glamour and attitude. But the excitement they create will only mask the growing anxiety in the recording industry about the future of its fundamental product, the CD, which is threatened with the same obsolescence that it long ago foisted on the LP and then the tape cassette.
 Introduced in the United States 20 years ago, the CD is losing its allure. From 2001 to 2002, some 62.5 million fewer of them were sold -- a decline of 9 percent to 649.5 million, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Online swapping of songs is growing at a crippling rate, forcing almost every corner of the music industry to try to divine exactly what role, if any, the CD will play in a future dominated by Internet delivery and competition from popular new technologies like the DVD. 
 Most analysts and industry executives agree that selling music online is the future. But they say it will take at least two years for companies to devise a business plan for it that makes financial sense. In the meantime, the CD will remain the biggest source of revenue for both music retailers and recording companies, who will try to squeeze as much profit as they can out of each and every sale. 
As a result, the CD is being rethought, repackaged and, in some cases, repriced. 
Experiments to resuscitate this ailing product are growing. In January, Bon Jovi created a compact disc, with eight previously unreleased songs, exclusively for Target stores. Priced at $6.99, it was intended to help bolster sales of other Bon Jovi albums, including the newest, "Bounce."
Best Buy, the No. 1 electronics chain in the country, is selling prepaid cards good for 10 downloads that allow consumers to create compilations to play either on discs or on computers. And last year, the Interscope recording label gave a DVD to the first million buyers of "The Eminem Show" as an incentive to buy the CD.
All this is happening as the economic underpinnings of the CD continue to deterioriate, endangering the music business altogether. With the rising popularity of online music, much of it available free, technology-wise teenagers, the industry's most voracious buyers, can easily use CD-burning technology to make bootleg copies and sell them at school for as little as $1.
Companies are showing signs of cracking. Two industry veterans have recently lost their jobs: Thomas D. Mottola, the head of Sony Music Entertainment, which lost more than $132 million last year; and Jay Boberg, president of MCA Records. The music retailer Wherehouse Entertainment announced in January that it was filing for bankruptcy protection, partly because of lackluster sales. And the EMI Group, based in London, the only major music company that is not a part of a media conglomerate, is struggling with debt and is believed by analysts to be considering merger prospects.
"Large companies tend to wait until they feel pain to act," said Dan Hart, chief executive of Echo, a recently formed consortium of retailers that hope to sell music online. "Now they feel pain."
DOUG MORRIS, chief executive of the Universal Music Group, said: "We are definitely in the middle of a transition. It was always a packaged-goods business, but that is changing. We are slowly moving forward."
Compact disc sales have slipped for several reasons, not all of them related to piracy or online music swapping. Critics complain that there is a dearth of blockbuster acts these days and that those with hits, like Britney Spears, often have short-lived careers. And with the average price of a compact disc at $14.21, they contend that music is simply too expensive for frequent purchases.
But Hilary B. Rosen, chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America, countered that a recent study by the association found that only 3 percent of the consumers polled said they were buying less music because prices were too high.
Still, there is no question that other activities are taking up listeners' time, thanks to the growth of electronic games and multichannel cable and satellite television. Perhaps most threatening is the popularity of the DVD, which emerged in the mid-1990's. By 1999, DVD players had gained mass-market appeal, and they now cost as little as $50, about the same price as a portable boom box. In some retail stores, DVD sales have surpassed those of CD's.
"The DVD is moving into the bedrooms of the next generation of young kids," said Gary L. Arnold, senior vice president for entertainment at Best Buy, which announced in January that it was closing 107 stores. The next generation of young people has no affinity for the compact disc. For them, he said, "it's about gaming and PlayStation."
TO thwart online swapping, several music companies, including Sony and Universal, have experimented with copy-protected compact discs, much to the ire of paying consumers, who complain that they cannot listen to some of those discs on their computers. The industry does not use a standard copy-protected format, so consumers do not know what kind of disc they are buying. Fearing a consumer backlash, the industry has slowed down those copy-protection efforts.
Software makers are trying to come up with alternatives that address the needs of both consumers and recording companies. At a recent music conference in Cannes, France, Microsoft said it had developed technology to allow music companies to record two sets of identical songs on a compact disc, one that could be played on a home or car stereo and the other, called second session, that could be copied to a personal computer. The second-session songs would have limitations, perhaps barring consumers from sharing files or copying songs onto another disc.
Recording companies probably placed too much hope on super audio CD's, which are said to have superior sound compared with regular CD's. The technology, introduced two years ago, has not taken off because super audio CD's cost nearly four times as much to buy as regular CD's -- and they require a special machine to experience the full impact.
And super audios, championed by Sony and Philips, are not alone in offering sound quality that surpasses that of the typical CD: a dueling new technology in DVD audio, supported by Panasonic and Pioneer, is setting up a battle reminiscent of the VHS-Betamax wars.
Until all these new technologies are sorted out, recording companies and retailers are betting on promotions and marketing deals to increase sales. Bruce Kirkland, a member of Bon Jovi's management team, said the album that Bon Jovi put together for Target had also increased sales of the "Bounce" album in its stores. In the first week of the promotion, Target's share of the market for "Bounce" for all retail stores jumped to 26.1 percent from 15.9 percent, he said.
"I think the onus is on the retailers to take care of this because the recording companies always shoot themselves in the foot," Mr. Kirkland said.
Mr. Arnold of Best Buy said he believed that DVD's could well replace the CD in the future because they play not only music but also video images. In the last 12 months, sales of DVD's have surpassed those of compact discs at Best Buy, he said.
But before they can become a new industry standard, he added, they will have to more adeptly meld music and video.
 MUSIC distributors and retailers, battered by the slump in compact disc sales, are embarking on their own efforts to give consumers more and easily accessible music. Last month, six music retailers, including major outlets likeBest Buy, Wherehouse and Tower Records, said they would form the Echo consortium to sell music on the Internet through their retail Web sites. As recently as a year ago, that would have been unthinkable, as retailers and music companies were at odds about how best to tackle online distribution.
In another joint effort, Anderson Merchandisers, one of the largest magazine and music distributors in the United States, bought technology from Liquid Audio, an online music pioneer that distributes 350,000 songs through retailers, in the hope of exploiting the growth in digital music.
"It has not been the norm that retailers should be the ones helping us rethink our business," said John Esposito, president of United States distribution for the Warner Music Group. "But retailers are telling us the current model does not work."
Best Buy has been one of the most active retailers in this regard. It recently began testing a program in 30 stores that allowed consumers to buy a card with a preset value that could be used to buy downloads to a computer or disc. Scott Young, vice president for digital distribution at Best Buy, said the experiment had had limited success and was under review. 
Mr. Hart of Echo said retailers would primarily seek to sell downloads over their Web sites that consumers could call up from their homes. But as well as selling digital downloads, partners of Echo are likely to explore several options, including the use of store kiosks where consumers can make personalized compact discs.
Such a venture, like any in the digital music world, is fraught with risk. In 1999, Sony Music Entertainment tried a similar strategy but consumers did not respond, analysts said.
There are, of course, other problems facing distributors and retailers, most notably acquiring the rights to distribute whole catalogs of music online. The music companies faced that issue early on, when starting their own Web sites. Competing companies declined to offer all their music on both PressPlay, a joint venture of Sony Music and Universal Music, and MusicNet, which was formed by Warner Music, EMI and BMG. It took months for them to begin sharing music, leaving consumers disillusioned and frustrated. 
For all of these ventures, companies will still have to grapple with why consumers would pay for music they can easily get free. One major retailer, according to a music executive, has suggested to several recording companies that it might put a cap on the price of any compact disc it sold in its stores. Only a store like Wal-Mart would have the strength the pull that off, he added.
"I think the biggest problem is, the industry doesn't know how to get started and take steps where you get an incremental gain," said Phil Leigh, a digital media analyst at Raymond James & Associates in Tampa, Fla. "If compact disc sales continue to drop and there is no increase in online sales, then artists will be mad and your bosses are mad, too. There is an old expression that pioneers are the ones with arrows in their backs. The one thing executives don't get paid for is rocking the boat."

SUBJECT: MUSIC INDUSTRY (91%); MOVIES & SOUND RECORDING SECTOR PERFORMANCE (90%); RECORD REVENUES (90%); RECORD INDUSTRY (90%); POP & ROCK (90%); ENTERTAINMENT & ARTS (90%); RECORD PRODUCTION & DISTRIBUTION (89%); ELECTRONICS & APPLIANCE RETAILING (89%); HIP HOP CULTURE (89%); RAP MUSIC (89%); RETAILERS (89%); MUSIC STORES (89%); RADIO TELEVISION & ELECTRONICS STORES (87%); CONSUMER BEHAVIOR (77%); INTERNET AUDIO (74%); INTERNET & WWW (74%); ACTORS & ACTRESSES (73%); MARKET RESEARCH (72%); RETAIL MERCHANDISE MANAGEMENT (70%); PERSONAL DEBT (67%); EXECUTIVES (67%); DISMISSALS (67%); INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (66%); BUSINESS PLANS (66%); LAYOFFS (63%); PREPAID CARDS (63%) MUSIC; INDUSTRY PROFILES; COMPACT DISCS; CONSUMER BEHAVIOR; CONTAINERS AND PACKAGING; MARKETING AND MERCHANDISING; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; COPYRIGHTS; RECORDINGS (AUDIO)

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
What Should America Pay to Protect New York?

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AS ominous as the recent nationwide terror alerts are, New York City officials hope there is a silver lining.
 The confusion that has ensued may help the state's lawmakers and officials bolster the case they have been trying to make for months: that the city remains vulnerable and that the federal government is not doing enough about it. 
 Most of last year's debate in Congress over homeland security focused on how to rearrange the federal government to respond to terrorism. Now, lawmakers will be consumed with the thorny task of deciding where federal money for homeland security will go, as cities complain that previous promises have not been met. 
"We took a hit here for America," said New York's police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, referring to the World Trade Center. "As far as protecting for the future, so far we're going it alone."
The Democrats say the 2003 spending bill recently approved by Congress and signed by the president shortchanged the national homeland defense budget by as much as $9 billion. Up to now, according to the United States Conference of Mayors, cities have already spent more than $2.6 billion on homeland security since Sept. 11, 2001, without receiving any federal money for the effort.
Among officials in New York and the District of Columbia -- the cities that the F.B.I. said were specific targets -- the fear is that members of Congress will now be so focused on getting a share of the pie for their districts and states that they will not give enough to the places where the threat is perceived to be greatest.
"You know how things work in Washington," one New York official said. "If you give money to New York, then people in Wyoming will want the same, even though the biggest terror scare they'll experience is when Tom Ridge announces another color code change."
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York did not put it so bluntly. "It is a national problem," she said, "but there is no doubt that New York needs more than anywhere else." (On the other hand, her critics have noted that her own proposals include money for upstate communities like Poughkeepsie as well as New York City. Her office says the money would be used for security.)
Although Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg are Republicans, New York's heavily Democratic delegation in Congress finds itself in a grim position, marginalized by Republican leaders in both houses and down two seats as a result of last year's redistricting. Not only that, a stereotype of New Yorkers as greedy and pushy still seems to persist in Washington.
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, seemed to echo that sentiment last year when he said New York politicians were engaged in a "money-grubbing game" for demanding federal aid to help New York rebuild.
But Amy Call, a spokeswoman for the Office of Management and Budget, said that President Bush is mindful of New York City's situation, and that he followed through on his pledge to provide the city $20 billion in disaster relief aid after the terrorist attacks. 
Still, New York does bear a larger part of the continuing security burden than anyplace else. Additional security in New York during the recent terrorism alert is expected to cost the state alone at least $1 million a week. This comes during a city and state fiscal crisis that many New York officials attribute in large part to a recession induced, or at least deepened, by the terrorist attacks.
Mayor Bloomberg's administration says it expects the 2003 budget plan recently approved by Congress to provide the city with only a fraction of the $900 million that it requested for domestic defense programs.
The list of what the city says it needs is long: $100 million to train the Police Department, Fire Department and other local "first responders"; $200 million to enhance counterterrorism programs and protect landmarks like the United Nations, the New York Stock Exchange and the Federal Reserve Bank; $187 million to improve security at places like police precinct stations and hospitals; $189 million for emergency response equipment; and $223 million to improve emergency communications in high-rise buildings, tunnels and the subway.
Meeting those needs is not all that New York City officials insist they have to worry about. The 2003 federal budget plan sets aside $3.5 billion in counterterrorism money for police and fire departments nationwide. But Democrats point out that a large chunk of the money is drawn from existing law enforcement and public safety programs that largely benefit big cities like New York.
"They're robbing Peter to pay Paul," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from New York. But Brian Roehrkasse, a Department of Homeland Security spokesman, responded that the package allows local governments more flexibility in how they spend the money.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Europe's Highs and Lows Depend on Where You Stand

BYLINE:  By NIALL FERGUSON; Niall Ferguson, a professor at the Stern Business School of New York University, is author of the forthcoming book, "Empire: The Rise and Demise of the British World Order and the Lessons for Global Power" (Basic Books).

 BODY:
"DE haut en bas" -- from high to low, or from the lofty to the lowly -- is a signature phrase of French culture. The Parisians seem to know better than anyone else in the world how to look down their noses, but when President Jacques Chirac of France poured his scorn on the governments of Eastern Europe last week, he did so from a greater than usual height.
 "Their behavior is rather irresponsible and not very polite," Mr. Chirac declared, referring to the leaders' support of the American position on Iraq. "They missed a good opportunity to keep quiet." 
 "De haut en bas," indeed. On one side, somewhere up in the Euro-stratosphere, was the president of France, one of the European Union's six founding members. Among those far beneath his gaze were the 10 Eastern European countries that technically remain mere "candidates" for membership in the European Union next year. 
And beat this for Gallic hauteur: "If they wanted to diminish their chances of joining Europe, they could not have found a better way." 
That an expression of support for the United States could provoke such an intemperate French reaction says as much about the European past as it does about European attitudes toward the future of Iraq. For centuries Western Europeans have tended to regard their Eastern neighbors with a mixture of indifference and contempt. 
If Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, delighted to find American backers in Warsaw, Prague and Budapest, makes a distinction between "new Europe" and "old Europe," Mr. Chirac sees only "haute europe" and "l'europe-bas" -- high Europe and low Europe.
In one respect, this West-East divide is based on reality. Economically, the East has long lagged behind the West, since the countries with an Atlantic seaboard discovered the joys of ocean-going commerce. As long ago as 1870, per capita incomes in Western Europe were more than double those in the East. 
History has only widened the gap. Ever since the 18th-century partition of Poland by Austria, Prussia and Russia, the Eastern Europeans have continually found their interests ignored, sacrificed or simply trodden underfoot by the wealthy West.
The prime example is the fate of Czechoslovakia in 1938 -- sold out by the Western Europeans at Munich and gobbled up by Hitler the following year. But Munich is only one chapter in a long and sorry history. 
The French love to remind the world of their sufferings in the wars of the 20th century; rather illogically (since the European Union has little to do with conflict prevention) they see the preservation of peace as the main reason for the European Union.
Yet as heavy as French casualties were in World War I -- some 3.4 percent of the prewar population -- the proportionate losses of some Eastern European countries were higher still. In the case of Serbia, for example, the figure was 5.7 percent. Romania fared as badly as France. What's more, many Eastern European countries became embroiled in the war involuntarily, as provinces of the Russian, Austrian or German Empires.
The Poles had repeatedly tried to throw off the Russian yoke, long before it took a Communist form. But time and again -- in 1830, for example, and again in 1863 -- the Western Europeans simply looked the other way. In the end, the Easterners were freed in 1917 and 1918 not by Western action but by the collapse of the empires that ruled them. 
After World War I, the Eastern Europeans sought to band together to preserve their independence with alliances like the Little Entente binding Czechoslovakia, Romania and Yugoslavia in 1920. But without serious Western European military commitment, the Little Entente was about as much use against Hitler as duct tape against a dirty bomb.
The difference between East and West was even more marked in World War II. Needless to say, the French went down with scarcely a fight in 1940: mortality amounted to less than 1 percent of the prewar population. But Eastern Europe bore the brunt of total war. In Poland, nearly 19 percent of the prewar population died. In Yugoslavia the figure was close to 11 percent.
One explanation for this large difference was that in Eastern Europe defeating Hitler was left to an equally callous totalitarian regime and its Communist allies. By 1944 it was Stalin's turn to treat the Eastern Europeans as vassals. Apart from Austria and Greece, half a continent was consigned to nearly a half-century of misery behind the Iron Curtain. When Soviet tanks rolled through Budapest, Prague and Warsaw, the silence from the Western capitals was deafening. It is clear that if Mikhail S. Gorbachev had changed his mind and crushed the 1989 risings in the Eastern bloc, the Western Europeans would have done little more than murmur. 
The strangest element of last week's fracas and, in fact, of the whole trans-Atlantic rupture, is that the Western Europeans, especially the French, have the most reason to be pro-American. After all, an Anglo-American decision to treat vanquished France as one of the victors in 1945 gave the French their seat on the United Nations Security Council. Jean Monnet set about rebuilding France and uniting Western Europe with American blessings and dollars.
The world had become a very different place by the late 1980's, when the current generation of Eastern European leaders came of age. Those who dreamed of freedom found little support from the leaders of France and Germany, who were all too ready to be conciliatory toward the Communist regimes in the name of detente. It was Ronald Reagan, not Francois Mitterrand, who urged Mr. Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall, just as it was Thatcherite conservatives, not German trade unionists, who rallied to the banner of Solidarity in Poland. 
Nonetheless, Americans should not make the mistake of assuming that the "new" Europeans will be uncritically pro-American. That would be to fall into the French trap of equating "new" with deferential.
There is, in fact, no shortage of popular opposition in Hungary and the Czech Republic to an Iraq war: 82 percent of Hungarians oppose it, and 47 percent of Czechs. There is also generally more support for reformed Communists in the former Eastern bloc than for advocates of the free market.
As they prepare to join the European Union, the Czechs, Hungarians, Poles, Slovenes, Slovaks and Balts are singing not "Ode to Joy," but something more like "Won't Get Fooled Again." They understand how the European Union works: as a system of agricultural protectionism and income redistribution which transfers resources from rich Germans to poorer Europeans (especially farmers). With incomes ranging from a half to a quarter of the European Union average, the Easterners would be crazy not to want to join.
But when it comes to security, Eastern Europeans look not to the European Union but to the American-led NATO. It is no coincidence that the three countries who first lined up against France last week are the new recruits to NATO: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Nor is it surprising that the countries who followed their example a few days later were the "Vilnius 10," all of whom have applied to join NATO.
Whatever the French may say, more than one club is worth joining in Western Europe. That is why the days of "high" and "low" Europe may be ending. So profoundly has Europe been changed since 1989 that the Rumsfeldian old-new distinction is now much closer to the mark.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Welfare Wars; 
Are the Poor Suffering From Hunger Anymore?

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
THE Bush administration and Congress are giving almost every poverty program the once-over, pushing changes that will affect everything from Medicaid to housing assistance. But two programs are receiving unexpected scrutiny: food stamps and subsidized school lunches.
 Advocates for revamping those programs argue that both of them too often serve people who don't need help, and that even among those who do need help, food stamps can encourage dependency. 
 In tough economic times, limiting food aid could be a politically unpopular move. Americans typically do not regard free food as a form of welfare, and other attempts to limit it have met with mixed reactions. 
In 1981, President Ronald Reagan proposed cutting lunch portions and famously tried to have ketchup classified as a vegetable. Both ideas died after a storm of protest. (He was partly successful in reducing federal subsidies to middle-class students.) And one of the most contentious provisions in the 1996 law that overhauled welfare -- denying food stamps to noncitizen immigrants -- was largely repealed last year, with White House support.
Nevertheless, many Republicans including Representative Bob Goodlatte of Virginia, the chairman of the House Agricultural Committee, say it is now important to reconfigure the food-stamp program, which he contends is rife with fraud and ripe for innovation. There is also rising criticism from conservatives outside the administration that food programs encourage recipients to overeat.
"We are feeding the poor as if they are starving, when anyone can see that the real problems for them, like other Americans, is expanding girth," said Douglas J. Besharov, director of the American Enterprise Institute's Project on Social and Individual Responsibility. 
Food stamps are facing the most significant changes. Earlier this month, the House passed legislation with White House support that would give states more autonomy. Up to five states would be allowed to administer the programs as they saw fit, almost free of federal standards, in exchange for a freeze on financing from Washington.
Under current law, any family with an income that falls below 130 percent of poverty level is entitled to food stamps; a family of four can get as much as $465 a month, but the average grant is $185 a month. And unlike welfare, no time limit exists on how long they can collect. While the Agriculture Department says it does not track how long participants stay in the program, the conservative Heritage Foundation says its analysis of government surveys shows that half stay for extended periods, longer than eight years.
The White House says the new legislation would give states the ability to streamline disparate poverty programs. And conservatives outside the administration say food stamps have become an escape hatch for those who can, but will not, work. 
"Food stamps and cash welfare are two halves of a whole," said Robert E. Rector, a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation. "All the things about cash welfare that discouraged work and marriage, and encouraged long-term dependence, apply identically to food stamps." 
But opponents say Congress and the administration are using the rubric of flexibility to disguise a move to cut costs.
"Right now if the economy goes down, the federal government picks up the cost," said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal Washington research group. "Under a block grant, states would get a set amount and if there are a bunch of layoffs locally the state is stuck with the bill. And if it doesn't want to pay, it can cut back on what it spends. Over time you squeeze down on what the federal government spends for the poor."
The Bush administration is also trying to tighten enforcement of the National School Lunch Program. In its budget, the administration proposes to enforce the income eligibility rules for free meals more strictly. The program has grown from serving 7.1 million lunches in all of 1947, the first year it operated, to serving 28 million students a day at a cost of $7 billion a year.
STUDENTS are eligible for a free lunch if their households earn only 130 percent of poverty level. Other children are eligible for heavily subsidized lunches if their family's income falls below 185 percent of the poverty line, or $33,400 for a family of four. The Food and Nutrition Service, which administers the lunches, estimates that as many as a quarter of children getting free lunches may come from households with incomes too high to qualify.
The administration says enforcement is a matter of fairness. "Because the information collected for school lunch eligibility is also used to allocate a wide array of federal, state and local education dollars," the budget proposal read, "errors in certifying children for school lunches can lead to a diversion of funds away from the lowest-income schools." 
In recent pilot programs in which families were asked to document household income, approval for free lunches fell by 21 percent and by 8.8 percent for reduced-price lunches. There is no estimate on how much might be saved through tighter enforcement, but the department says savings will be plowed back into other nutrition programs.
Food advocates counter that new barriers will discourage poor families from applying, and that in any case, few middle-class students are freeloading. "If it is anyone, it is people marginally above the line," said Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. "It is not like you have Donald Trump's kids getting lunch."
While the Bush administration is fighting these battles, some on the right are venturing an even more delicate justification for revamping the food programs: obesity. 
In a new book, Mr. Besharov, for example, criticized the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC, which provides generous food packages and nutritional counseling to seven million low-income women and children. Republicans and Democrats have praised the 30-year-old program, and the White House's new budget proposes increasing its financing by $43 million, to $4.77 billion. 
But WIC packages, Mr. Besharov says, are heavily tilted toward high-calorie foods like enriched fruit juices, cereals and peanut butter. School meals, too, he says, are heavy on starches and meat. He advocates more money spent on nutrition education -- and on fresh fruit and vegetables. 
Advocates of the poor acknowledge that obesity is a problem, but say that Mr. Besharov's formula is too simple. 
"Hunger in the U.S. is not what it was 40 years ago," concedes Jim Weill, president of the Food Research and Action Center, an advocacy group based in Washington. "Poor people are rarely hungry for 25 days a month, but resources are such that they are hungry for at least a few days." 
According to self-reported census data, 33 million Americans live in households the government identifies as "food insecure," because they occasionally miss meals and feel hungry. "The result of this insecurity," Mr. Weill said, "is that poor households can engage in binge eating and rely on high-caloric foods." 
But in that language may lie a lesson. No longer are advocates for the poor discussing "hunger," with its dire implications, but "insecurity," a more nuanced, less compelling justification for help. If conservatives have got food advocates to concede this much, perhaps they have already won Round 1 of the battle.

HEADLINE: Policy Shapers, Well Known and Little Known 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
The cast of officials who help to shape President Bush's environmental policies spans a wide range, from a former New Jersey governor whom environmentalists see as their closest ally to a former Colorado attorney general who was a protege of James Watt, the Reagan-era interior secretary.
 It also includes figures little known to the public, like James L. Connaughton, the chairman of Mr. Bush's Council on Environmental Quality. A Washington lawyer whose practice focused on environmental matters, Mr. Connaughton now acts as Mr. Bush's top White House adviser on the environment, and is a coordinator whose job in part is to referee disputes among the federal agencies. 
 Christie Whitman, the former governor turned administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is the best known among the group, in part because as early as the mid-1990's, her reputation as a rising star in the Republican Party earned her frequent mentions as a potential vice presidential candidate.
Mrs. Whitman has frequently been overruled by more conservative voices in the administration, most notably over policies on global warming, but she has dashed speculation that she might resign in protest, saying she remains proud of Mr. Bush's environmental record. More recently, she has begun to call attention to fights she has won. For example, she has said that she headed off an effort by others in the administration that could have led to a much broader scaling back of Clean Water Act protections for wetlands.
Gale A. Norton, the interior secretary, worked under Mr. Watt early in her career, and like him is an ardent champion of the view that the wisest use of public lands includes using them to extract natural resources. As interior secretary, she oversees one-fifth of the territory of the United States -- including, as she pointed out in an interview, the land that produces one-third of the country's energy. She has been the administration's most outspoken advocate for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.
Unlike her mentor, however, Ms. Norton is also an outdoors enthusiast, and she portrays herself as both a conservative and a conservationist.
"We think we can get beyond the minimum standards enforced by punishment if you actively involve people in becoming citizen stewards," Ms. Norton said. "We really want to see people active in helping our public lands and in encouraging conservation on private lands."
The principal players include several others, among them Ann M. Veneman, the agriculture secretary. Ms. Veneman oversees the Forest Service, whose policies on road building, fire prevention and logging have been at the center of several disputes. Another important figure is John D. Graham, a senior official of the Office of Management and Budget with responsibility for federal regulations.
Though less visible than the others, Mr. Graham has wielded increasing influence by scrutinizing environmental regulations to ensure that the benefits they bring can justify their cost to the American economy. A former Harvard professor, Mr. Graham is seen by environmental groups as a particular threat because his arguments have in the past provided an intellectual rationale for the weakening of environmental regulations.

HEADLINE: Power and Leadership; 
The Real Meaning of Iraq

 BODY:
The debate over Iraq has exhausted everybody. Many people now think an American invasion is inevitable; many more are desperate just to get whatever happens over. There's nothing less satisfying than calling for still more discussion.
 But that's right where this page is. More discussion is the only road that will get the world to the right outcome -- concerted effort by a wide coalition of nations to force Saddam Hussein to give up his weapons of mass destruction. We need another debate. Another struggle to make this the United Nations' leadership moment. 
 Right now, things don't look promising for those of us who believe this is a war worth waging, but only with broad international support. The United States has an invasion force in place, and the military's schedule seems to demand that it attack within a few weeks before spring brings on withering desert heat. Washington has some support among other nations, but many of them are newcomers to the world of high-stakes diplomacy and few have much to offer in the way of troops or financial support. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, America's only strong and consistent ally among the world's other major military powers, is facing fierce opposition at home and ridicule abroad for his allegiance to the Bush administration. Turkey, another important ally, held out for more money as it considered whether to allow American invasion forces on its soil. The size of the Turkish demands made the anti-Iraq forces look less like a serious coalition than a diplomatic version of "Let's Make a Deal."
Saddam Hussein, meanwhile, has been skillful at providing the pretense of progress to international inspectors without seriously cooperating. Iraq has drawn the United Nations into a game of find the handkerchief, in which the burden is on the inspectors to track down mobile laboratories or sniff out hidden weapons. All this puts an enormous weight on what Iraqi behavior Hans Blix, the chief U.N. inspector, chooses to stress -- whether he dwellson Iraqi resistance or points to areas of cooperation. In the United Nations, the equivalent of a C-minus for effort on a Blix report can be taken as an argument for peace, while a D-plus can be seen as a call to war. The inspectors should never be put in the position of deciding international foreign policy.

A Case for Action
While the possibility of Mr. Hussein experiencing a last-minute conversion seems minuscule, there is one quick way to test whether it's possible. Iraq has Al Samoud 2 missiles, weapons it built at great expense and effort. Mr. Blix has already stated that they are too powerful, able to travel too far to fit under the limits set by the United Nations after the Persian Gulf war. On Friday, Mr. Blix told the Iraqis to start destroying them by March 1.
This week the Security Council should reaffirm Mr. Blix's order and tell Mr. Hussein he must get rid of his missiles immediately, or outside forces will do it for him, with the support of the international community. That clear message would resolve the most frustrating problem for those who want the United Nations to nail down its position as the arbiter of world crises -- how to get France and its supporters to define their own bottom line rather than simply criticizing Washington's.
Saddam Hussein is nobody's hero in this story. Although many Americans are puzzled about why the Bush administration chose to pick this fight now, it's not surprising that in the wake of Sept. 11, the president would want to make the world safer, and that one of his top priorities would be eliminating Iraq's ability to create biological, chemical and nuclear weapons. Of all the military powers in the world, Iraq is the one that has twice invaded its neighbors without provocation and that has used chemical weapons both on its military foes and some of its own restive people. North Korea may be a greater danger, but North Korea has not been told by the United Nations to disarm and stay disarmed. And, although the administration is careful to steer clear of this argument, the very fact that North Korea has the international community in a bind is a cautionary tale for making sure that no other despotic governments run by irrational adventurers get hold of nuclear arms.

A Game of Chance
Many foreigners, and large numbers of Americans, wonder whether this administration is capable of dispassionate judgment as it relentlessly pushes for war. All too often, American officials have undermined their own case by demonstrating reckless enthusiasm for a brawl, denigrating allies who fail to fall in line or overstating their case against Iraq, particularly when it comes to a link between Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda. But to his credit, President Bush worked hard to achieve the unanimous support of the Security Council for Resolution 1441, and more broadly to make his case before the United Nations and the world. This may be an administration intent on making war, but so far it has also shown itself willing to give the United Nations both time and space to make up its mind.
It seems clear to us that the United Nations should enforce its own orders and make Iraq disarm, even if that requires force. But in the end, sometime in March, the United States may have to decide whether it should do the job on its own.
When that happens, the arguments on both sides are sure to be couched in the highest moral principles. But the real calculations will be entirely about the odds of succeeding. If military victory over Iraq is swift, and if it can be accomplished without extensive casualties toAmerican soldiers or Iraqi civilians or damage to neighboring countries or the area's oil fields, Mr. Bush's popularity will soar. If occupation forces unearth proof of a large nuclear program, stockpiles of terrifying biological weapons and real evidence of serious collusion between Saddam Hussein and international terrorists, many of the international leaders who are riding the crest of anti-Americanism now will start looking very foolish.
But things could go terribly wrong, very quickly. The war could be brutal and protracted, especially if Mr. Hussein unleashes biological or chemical weapons against Israel or American troops. He may also succeed in setting fire to his oil wells, or disabling those in neighboring countries, crippling the world economy. And if he is destroyed, there is every possibility of a vicious struggle for the lucrative spoils among the disparate clans and ethnic groups in Iraq, drawing in Turkey, Iran and others. In the chaos, the weapons of mass destruction Americans went to war to eliminate could wind up being ferried out of Iraq and sold to the highest terrorist bidder. And just as the American military's presence in Saudi Arabia during the gulf war precipitated the growth of Al Qaeda and Sept. 11, the long-term occupation of Iraq will create resentment in the Muslim world that could lead to more, not less, terrorism.

The Long Haul
All those risks, we repeat, are worth taking in the context of a broad international coalition, and some might even be diminished if the world acts together. The country is still traumatized by the discovery on Sept. 11, 2001, that we live in a world of unimaginable danger. Some of our traditional allies knew that already, from long and terrible experience. Some are still trying to face up to it. But the rational response is to work together to make the world safer, not to ignore obvious dangers in hope that the likely will not become inevitable.
Our own guess, when we calculate the odds in Iraq, is that the war is likely to go well in the short run, but that the long run will be messy, difficult and dangerous. If America acts virtually on its own, it is hard to imagine either the Bush administration or the American people having the staying power to make things right. Washington may be counting on Iraq's oil revenue to pay for rebuilding the country after the war, but the oil wells could be damaged in the fighting. It seems certain that an administration that will not give up tax cuts to pay for the war itself is not going to inflict economic pain at home to pay for the cleanup. And while Americans have always shown themselves willing to risk anything, even their own children, for a critical cause of high purpose, their support for this particular fight is thin as a wafer and based on misapprehension that Iraq is clearly linked to terrorism.

Our Bottom Line
When all the odds are calculated, people will have their own particular critical concerns that add weight to one side of the scale or the other. For some, it is the belief that rogue nations can be deterred -- a certainty that if they use their worst weapons, the United States and its allies will pay them back, double. While the evidence that Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons in battle with Iran, and against his own Kurdish population, is strong, the fact that he has not used similar weapons in other situations, including the gulf war, suggests that deterrence should not be dismissed.
For others, the bottom line will come down to saving face. The United States has assembled its forces for invasion,and to back down now, many argue, will be to show a weakness that will encourage our enemies. We don't think the world's only surviving superpower should be making war to avoid embarrassment.
Our own overriding concern runs in the other direction. The United States is, and seems likely to remain, a nation whose military might and economic power so outstrip any other country that much of the world has begun comparing it to ancient Rome. The test now is whether we will find a new way to exercise our power in which leadership, self-discipline and concern for the common good will outweigh our smaller impulses. An invasion of Iraq that is not supported by many traditional allies, or those powers that we need to be allied with in the best possible future, will send a message that we can do whatever we want. But it is not going to make the rest of the world want to root for us to succeed. The real test of American leadership is only incidentally about Iraq. It is whether we will further split the world into squabbling camps, united only by their jealousy of our power, or use our influence to unite it around a shared vision of progress, human rights and mutual responsibility.

HEADLINE: Governors, Hurting Financially, Ask Washington for Assistance 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Leaders of the National Governors Association, experiencing fiscal problems unmatched since World War II, cried out today for help from the federal government as they opened their winter meeting here.
 Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky, a Democrat who is chairman of the association, said that even after making cuts in many programs, states still faced a $30 billion gap between their revenues and their spending commitments this year. Governors, he said, anticipate a shortfall of $82 billion in the coming fiscal year, which starts in July for most states. 
 Since most states are forbidden to run deficits, Mr. Patton said, they have begun to cut services, and some have raised taxes, even as President Bush tries to stimulate a sluggish economy by cutting federal taxes.
"When states stop spending and increase taxes," Mr. Patton said, "it goes directly counter to the administration's effort to stimulate the economy by increasing spending and cutting taxes."
Explosive growth in health costs are a major reason for the states' fiscal problems. Mr. Bush recently asked Congress to revamp Medicaid, to give states more freedom to limit costs, benefits and eligibility for some recipients. 
Gov. Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho, a Republican who is vice chairman of the association, said, "I am encouraged by the administration's proposal to reform Medicaid and give states more flexibility." Mr. Kempthorne said federal officials had invited governors to "help design the reforms," suggesting that the administration would not insist on all the details it set forth in the last three weeks.
Mr. Kempthorne advocated two changes that would give states more fiscal relief than anything proposed by Mr. Bush. Medicaid is financed jointly by the federal government and the states, so, for example, if Idaho cuts state Medicaid spending by $1, the federal Treasury saves about $2.
Governor Kempthorne said that if states find ways to save money in Medicaid, they should be allowed to keep the federal money that would otherwise have been spent on their Medicaid recipients.
In addition, Mr. Kempthorne and other governors said the federal government should, through Medicare, assume the entire cost of providing health care to low-income elderly people on Medicaid. More than six million people are eligible for both programs. 
Governors said their fiscal problems had forced them to freeze or cut many programs, including spending for schools, colleges and prisons. 
Governor Patton said he had prematurely released 900 felons from state prisons, reduced services for some Medicaid beneficiaries and cut the state budget for elementary, secondary and higher education.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
An Audience for 31 Years of Fulminations

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Updating the age-old question about a tree falling in the forest, if no one ever listened to or quoted George Steinbrenner on his critical comments about his players, would anyone miss them?
 In his 31st year in Major League Baseball, Steinbrenner has commanded everyone's attention this winter by resurrecting a tactic he employed regularly before the Yankees ran off four World Series championships in five years. He has singled out one of the Yankees' star players for criticism. 
 This is not a new act. Derek Jeter is not the first player who cashes Steinbrenner's hefty paychecks to feel the sting of the owner's public barbs. But winning had deprived Steinbrenner of a target for his act as Phineas T. Bluster. Hence, the overreaction to his Jeter jaunt. 
It is something like this era's hitters. They have grown up without pitchers throwing inside to them and are therefore unaccustomed to those pitches, so when the exception to the rule fires a high hard one, or even a middle hard one, the batter takes offense and instantly lashes out at the pitcher by screaming at him or charging the mound.
Jeter has had a charmed career, playing shortstop for the Yankees only during their current championship era. He is too young to have experienced the verbal abuse Steinbrenner heaped upon his predecessors, Reggie Jackson, for example, in 1981, and Dave Winfield throughout his nine years in New York.
Not that they and their fellow targets refrained from reacting to Steinbrenner's criticism, but when they did, they were in the early stages of his practice. In 2003, this Steinbrenner shtick is old. It should be ignored.
If Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, saw that his attacks were disappearing into a verbal void, he might abandon them and develop a new act. The problem is, players won't ignore his comments because they gain widespread dissemination. 
This veteran of the Steinbrenner era knows that the news media find him and his comments irresistible. One obscure moment from Steinbrenner's Yankees history is telling.
On Dec. 6, 1983, baseball executives and owners were gathered in Nashville at the winter meetings. Steinbrenner wasn't there yet, but his arrival was eagerly anticipated. 
Billy Martin was the reason. Uncharacteristically, Steinbrenner had procrastinated about Martin's managerial future, and the baseball world was waiting to learn what he would do. Speculation was rampant that Yogi Berra would replace Martin. If it happened, it would be Martin's third departure as the Yankees manager in less than six years.
Word of the estimated time of Steinbrenner's arrival spread throughout the press corps, whose members began massing in the lobby well before he was expected to walk through the revolving door of the Opryland Hotel.
Given Steinbrenner's routine, it was virtually certain that he would say nothing about his manager when he arrived. Yet no one left the lobby.
The plane was delayed, but the large group of reporters waited and waited and waited. Nothing was going to budge them. They waited this long; they would wait longer. Finally, shortly before 10 p.m., Steinbrenner walked through the revolving door. He went to the desk to get a key to his room -- he had been checked in -- and as soon as he turned to walk away from the desk, he was mobbed. Without pausing for even an instant, he walked through the crowd and said: "I'm not going to have anything to say. I'm too tired. I've had a rough day."
Nothing would have been lost then if no one had waited for Steinbrenner, and nothing would be lost now if no one listened to Steinbrenner's criticism of his players. 
Jeter initially said he would not respond to the owner's remarks, then changed his mind. He responded first nationally to The Associated Press, then held a news conference on Monday.
Not everyone has been overcome by the Steinbrenner-Jeter exchange, hanging on their every word.
"It's crazy," a longtime Yankees fan said. "It's nothing. It's a nonstory."
But plenty of people are still listening.

Hollow Words of Confidence
As long as people are paying attention to George Steinbrenner, on the other hand, they should note what he said about Joe Torre's job as manager: "He's as safe as any manager in baseball."
Now that statement should make Torre feel pretty good, right? Well, maybe not as good as his three-year, $16 million contract -- he's in the second year. But since the manager likes his job, he should welcome Steinbrenner's words. On the other hand, recall these famous last words uttered by Steinbrenner.
Speaking about Bob Lemon before the 1982 season: "There will be no change this year. I wouldn't care how the team is doing."
Lemon was fired 14 games into the season.
Speaking about Yogi Berra before the 1985 season: "Yogi will be the manager this year. I said the same thing last year; I'm saying it again this year. A bad start will not affect Yogi's status."
Berra was fired 16 games into the season.

Umpires vs. Computers
In one of a series of meetings today, umpires will have a briefing on the results of a study made by their lawyers and independent scientists of the QuesTec computerized system by which baseball says it will evaluate umpires and their ball-and-strike calls. The umpires intend to fight that plan.
"The difference between this year and last," Larry Gibson, one of the umpires, said, "is last year umpires suspected the system wasn't reliable; now they know it isn't reliable. It's not against technology. It's bad technology."
But some umpires believe there are worse problems than QuesTec. "QuesTec is a machine," Jerry Crawford, the last president of the old union, said. "They were looking for accountability. They're using that as an outlet for accountability."
What concerns Crawford more, he said, is the absence of a relationship between the umpires and baseball officials.
"No matter which side you're on," he said, "you have to have a relationship with baseball. If you don't contact them, you won't have any relationship. Whatever the relationship was between baseball and Richie Phillips, Richie always maintained contact no matter what the situations were."
Phillips was the old union's lawyer and chief negotiator. He lost his position when a dissident faction of umpires, dissatisfied with his leadership, won a certification vote. The leaders of the new union thought they would have a more harmonious relationship with baseball officials, but it hasn't worked out that way.
The relationship is as contentious as it ever was under Phillips.
"You have people you're supposed to be dealing with and I don't think right now the leadership is dealing with them," Crawford said.
The final meeting on today's schedule is aimed at trying to bring together the two groups of umpires: the 45 union members and the 23 nonmembers.

Miller Is a Candidate
Billy Martin, Whitey Herzog, Dick Williams? Walter O'Malley, August Busch Jr., Charles O. Finley? Marvin Miller, Bowie Kuhn?
How many of these managers, owners and executives, if any, will be voted into the Hall of Fame when the results of the voting by the newly constructed veterans committee are announced Wednesday?
These eight candidates are among the 15 on a composite ballot of nonplayers. The players ballot has 26 candidates. Any candidate who receives 75 percent of the votes cast will be inducted into the Hall next summer.
Miller, who made a huge impact on the game as the players' labor leader, is the most intriguing one on the ballot because in the 20 years since he retired as executive director of the players association he had never been considered for the Hall.
Assuming all 84 voters cast ballots, 63 votes will be needed for election. Of the 58 Hall of Fame members on the committee, 41 played after Miller became the union chief. If all 41 voted for Miller, either because of his impact or what he did for their bank accounts, he would need 22 other votes from the remaining 17 Hall of Famers, who include four managers who benefited economically from Miller's efforts, and 26 other committee members.
Miller at one time scoffed at the thought that he would one day be in the Hall of Fame, but he has acknowledged since being nominated that he would be delighted to gain entry.
