HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
British Businessman Seen In Formal Bid for Hotel Chain
Hugh E. Osmond, a British businessman who made a fortune running pizza and pub chains, is planning to make a formal offer this week for Six Continents, the world's second-largest hotel chain, that values the company as high as $9 billion, people involved in the talks said.
 A formal offer from Mr. Osmond would likely flush out other interested parties. The Hilton Group, a British company that owns the rights to the Hilton brand outside the United States, is considering its options, including buying some hotels from Mr. Osmond should his bid succeed, a person close to the company said. Hilton could also team up with a private equity firm to start a counteroffer. Page C3. 

Lifetime Magazine Faces Dire Odds
Emboldened by the successful translation of Oprah Winfrey's television show into a magazine, Carole Black, left, president of Lifetime Entertainment Services, and Cathleen P. Black, president of Hearst Magazines, are betting that Lifetime Television's position as the No. 1 basic cable channel will allow Lifetime magazine to find a place in the very crowded world of women's magazines. C8.

Pony Adds to Its Maverick Image
Pony, a brand that cultivates a provocative image, will promote its athletic footwear and apparel by using performers like Jenna Jameson from movies made by Vivid Entertainment, a leading producer of pornographic films. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.

Broadband Companies Cheer Ruling
Cisco Systems, Juniper Networks and other makers of broadband equipment look forward to a new wave of buying after a ruling last week by the Federal Communications Commission that retained many rules that govern local telecommunications markets but that exempted high-speed Internet services. C2.

Coca-Cola to Market Payroll Cards
Coca-Cola is expected to announce today that it will market payroll cards to restaurants, hotels and entertainment companies. A Citigroup unit will issue the cards, which can be used like debit cards to shop at retailers and to obtain cash at A.T.M.'s. C2.

Customer Service at a Price
Companies that once offered customers incentives to handle transactions using self-service technology are taking matters a step further, charging extra if they choose to speak to an agent. New Economy. C5.

Questions About Google Acquisition
People who follow Weblogs, the online journals, are curious about what Google, the leading search engine, expects to gain from its recent purchase of Pyra Labs, creators of the Blogger service. The combination of Pyra and Google seems unlikely on the surface. Google helps people find information online, while Blogger helps them publish it. C5.

If There Is a War, Radio Is Ready
Radio program directors are planning to adjust their playlists if the United States goes to war with Iraq, adding more patriotic tunes and songs right for the moment, for example. C8.

Sales of Cigarettes Online Hit Snags
Online sellers of cigarettes have been in an enviable position -- until recently. As states steadily raised cigarette taxes in an effort to balance budgets and curb teenage smoking, more and more consumers turned to the Web, where cheap cigarettes abound. But such bargains may not be so easily found in the future, some analysts said, as states like New York prepare to outlaw online tobacco sales, while others like California crack down on cigarette buyers who do not pay excise taxes from online purchases. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C7.

Some New Incarnations of Snow
As the residue of a recent snowstorm lingers in the Northeast, it may seem odd that inventors keep trying to perfect the manufacture of artificial snow. But they do, and not just the stuff used at ski resorts. Patents. C11.

Korea to Expand Inquiry of SK Group
The South Korean government said that it planned to expand its investigation into Korea's third-largest conglomerate, the SK Group, a day after a leading company official was arrested. C3.

A heading in the Business Digest column on Monday about the prospects for Lifetime magazine exceeded the facts of the article. The chances were not described as "dire."

PERSON: Robert K. Merton 

HEADLINE: Robert K. Merton, Versatile Sociologist and Father of the Focus Group, Dies at 92 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Robert K. Merton, one of the most influential sociologists of the 20th century, whose coinage of terms like "self-fulfilling prophecy" and "role models" filtered from his academic pursuits into everyday language, died yesterday. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.
 Mr. Merton gained his pioneering reputation as a sociologist of science, exploring how scientists behave and what it is that motivates, rewards, and intimidates them. By laying out his "ethos of science" in 1942, he replaced the entrenched stereotypical views that had long held scientists to be eccentric geniuses largely unbound by rules or norms. It was this body of work that contributed to Mr. Merton's becoming the first sociologist to win a National Medal of Science in 1994. 
 But his explorations over 70-odd years extended across an extraordinary range of interests that included the workings of the mass media, the anatomy of racism, the social perspectives of "insiders" vs. "outsiders," history, literature and etymology. Though carried out with the detachment he admired in Emile Durkheim, the French architect of modern sociology, Mr. Merton's inquiries often bore important consequences in real life as well as in academics. 
His studies on an integrated community helped shape Kenneth Clark's historic brief in Brown v. Board of Education, the Supreme Court case that led to the desegregation of public schools. His adoption of the focused interview to elicit the responses of groups to texts, radio programs and films led to the "focus groups" that politicians, their handlers, marketers and hucksters now find indispensable. Long after he had helped devise the methodology, Mr. Merton deplored its abuse and misuse but added, "I wish I'd get a royalty on it."
He spent much of his professional life at Columbia University, where along with his collaborator of 35 years, Paul F. Lazarsfeld, who died in 1976, he developed the Bureau of Applied Social Research, where the early focus groups originated. The course of his career paralleled the growth and acceptance of sociology as a bona fide academic discipline. As late as 1939 there were fewer than a 1,000 sociologists in the United States, but soon after Mr. Merton was elected president of the American Sociological Association in 1957, the group had 4,500 members.
Mr. Merton was sometimes called "Mr. Sociology," and Jonathan R. Cole, a former student and the provost at Columbia, once said, "If there were a Nobel Prize in sociology, there would be no question he would have gotten it." (Mr. Merton's son, Robert C. Merton, won a Nobel Prize in economics in 1997.)
Another of Mr. Merton's contributions to sociology was his emphasis on what he termed "theories of the middle range." By these he meant undertakings that steered clear of grand speculative and abstract doctrines while also avoiding pedantic inquiries that were unlikely to yield significant results. What he preferred were initiatives that might yield findings of consequence and that open lines of further inquiry. In his own writings he favored the essay form, "which provides scope for asides and correlatives," he said, over the more common and streamlined scientific paper.
He was often came up with clearly phrased observations that combined originality with seeming simplicity. Eugene Garfield, an information scientist, wrote that much of Mr. Merton's work was "so transparently true that one can't imagine why no one else has bothered to point it out."
One early example of such illuminating insight appeared in a paper called "Social Structure and Anomie" that he wrote as a graduate student at Harvard in 1936 and then kept revising over the next decade.
Mr. Merton had asked himself what it was that brought about anomie, a state in which, according to Mr. Durkheim, the breakdown of social standards threatened social cohesion. In a breakthrough that spawned many lines of inquiry, Mr. Merton suggested that anomie was likely to arise when society's members were denied adequate means of achieving the very cultural goals that their society projected, like wealth, power, fame or enlightenment. Among the spinoffs of this work were Mr. Merton's own writings on the ranges of deviant behavior and crime.
A tall, pipe-smoking scholar, Mr. Merton often used the trajectory of his life story, from slum to academic achievement, as material illustrating the workings of serendipity, chance and coincidence, which so long fascinated him.
Robert King Merton was born Meyer R. Schkolnick on July 4, 1910, in South Philadelphia; he carried that name for the first 14 years of his life. He was the son of immigrants from Eastern Europe and lived in an apartment above his father's milk, butter and egg store until the building burned down. As a teenager performing magic tricks at birthday parties, he adopted Robert Merlin as a stage name, but when a friend convinced him that his choice of the ancient wizard's name was hackneyed, he modified it, adopting Merton with the concurrence of his Americanizing mother after he won a scholarship to Temple University.
In a lecture to the American Council of Learned Societies in 1994, Mr. Merton said that thanks to the libraries, schools, orchestras to which he had access, and even to the youth gang he had joined, his early years had prepared him well for what he called a life of learning. "My fellow sociologists will have noticed," he said, "how that seemingly deprived South Philadelphia slum was providing a youngster with every sort of capital -- social capital, cultural capital, human capital, and above all, what we may call public capital -- that is, with every sort of capital except the personally financial." It is not difficult to see connections between such views and Mr. Merton's insights into the causes of anomie.
In a 1961 New Yorker magazine profile by Morton Hunt, Mr. Merton was described as displaying "a surprising catholicity of interests and a talent for good conversation, impaired only slightly by the fact that he is alarmingly well informed about everything from baseball to Kant and is unhesitatingly ready to tell anybody about any or all of it."
Indeed, what is Mr. Merton's most widely known book, "On the Shoulders of Giants," went far beyond the confines of sociology. Referred to by Mr. Mertonas his "prodigal brainchild," it reveals the depth of his curiosity, the breadth of his prodigious research and the extraordinary patience that also characterize his academic writing. The effort began in 1942, when, in an essay called "A Note on Science and Democracy," Mr. Merton referred to a remark by Isaac Newton: "If I have seen farther, it is by standing on the shoulders of giants." He added a footnote pointing out that "Newton's aphorism is a standardized phrase which has found repeated expression from at least the 12th century."
But Mr. Merton did not stop there. Intermittently during the next 23 years he tracked the aphorism back in time, following blind alleys as well as fruitful avenues and finally finished the book in 1965, writing in a discursive style that the author attributed to his early reading and subsequent rereadings of Laurence Sterne's "Tristram Shandy." Denis Donoghue, the critic and literary scholar, wrote of the book admiringly as "an eccentric and yet concentric work of art, a work sufficiently flexible to allow a digression every 10 pages or so." He admitted, "I wish I had written 'On the Shoulders of Giants.' "
More recently, over the last three and a half decades, Mr. Merton had been gathering information about the idea and workings of serendipity, and thinking about it in the same spirit in which he had written the earlier book, which he liked to call by its acronym, OTSOG. As he had done with all his investigations, he collated and pondered data he had entered on index cards. Most days he started work at 4:30 a.m., with some of his 15 cats keeping him company. During the last years of his life, as he fought and overcame six different cancers, his Italian publisher, Il Mulino, prevailed on him to allow them to issue his writings on serendipity as a book. And four days before his death, his wife, the sociologist Harriet Zuckerman, received word that Princeton University Press had approved publication of the English version under the title, "The Travels and Adventures of Serendipity."
In addition to Ms. Zuckerman and his son, Mr. Merton is survived by two daughters, Stephanie Tombrello of Pasadena, Calif., and Vanessa Merton of Hastings-on-Hudson; nine grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: In Picking Top Schools, Klein Trips on Urban Politics 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The New York City school system has long served strikingly different constituencies: middle-class and poor, white and minority, have and have-not. Little wonder, then, that when Chancellor Joel I. Klein said he would choose about 200 schools to exempt from a new uniform curriculum, he found himself treading a minefield.
 With the "200 Club," as some parents and teachers have been calling the list of schools, Mr. Klein, a former prosecutor and business executive who has spent most of his adult life outside New York, has tripped over the highly charged politics of race and class that swirl around urban school systems and so often stymie change. 
 Now that Mr. Klein has released the list of exempted schools, parents who thought their schools should have made the list are resentful that their children will have to use the same curriculum as those in poor neighborhoods with failing schools. 
But if Mr. Klein had chosen only the highest performing schools for the list, as parents originally expected him to do, instead of a racially and economically diverse group that includes some striving but still mediocre schools in poor areas, he might have come under even more fire.
What possessed the controversy-averse Mr. Klein to stir up such a commotion? Some veteran New York educators and political consultants chalked up his decision to exempt certain schools from the curriculum to a stubborn insistence on doing what he thought was the right thing, without considering all the consequences.
"They tried to approach it on what they believed were the merits, which is always a danger," one longtime political operative said. "You never let your candidate be in a situation where they have to choose winners, because the only people who remember are the ones who lose."
Most of the people complaining belong to a constituency that the school system has long bent over backward not to alienate: educated, middle-class parents who could put their children in private schools or move to the suburbs, but have chosen the city school system. These parents select a school painstakingly, after concluding that they would be proud to send their children there.
Many of these parents prize racial diversity or unusual curriculums, and while they want their school to be good, they do not necessarily care if its test scores are not among the city's highest.
Mr. Klein sent many such parents reeling when he excluded dozens of relatively successful middle-class schools from his list. Some parents have panicked without considering that the prescribed curriculums are not so scripted as to strip teachers of creative license.
To some of these parents, it did not even matter if their children's school was already using the standardized program, as some schools in middle-class neighborhoods are. What mattered was that their school had not made Mr. Klein's list, which they saw as an all-important status symbol.
"There is always going to be a whole lot of emotion associated with how your school is labeled," said Ruth Cohen, the president of Pencil, an organization that works to increase corporate involvement in the New York City schools. "I don't know if there's any way it would have been palatable in New York."
Nobody disputes that Mr. Klein's intentions were good. He wanted to impose a uniform curriculum across the system to replace the patchwork of programs that had evolved over three decades of community control of the schools. He was trying to ensure that the many students and teachers who frequently switch schools had basically the same instruction wherever they went.
Yet Mr. Klein and his boss, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, also thought it important to let schools with winning records continue charting their own course. From their business-minded perspective, this meritocratic approach made perfect sense.
"These are corporate guys who are used to doing performance benchmarks," one education official outside the system said of Mr. Klein and Mr. Bloomberg. "They thought it was O.K. to say, 'Everyone who gets over an 85 on the test doesn't have to stay after school.' But they didn't take the race politics into account."
Many New Yorkers assumed that Mr. Klein would simply exempt the 200 schools that scored the highest on standardized tests. Those schools overwhelmingly serve white and Asian students in middle-class neighborhoods in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. But the idea of rewarding only the most affluent schools in a system that serves mostly poor, black and Hispanic students stirred an immediate outcry.
The main message that Mr. Klein wanted to send -- that a uniform curriculum would elevate the system as a whole -- got lost as lawmakers, parent advocacy groups and others with a stake in poor minority schools warned of a caste system. How could Mr. Klein allow white and Asian schools to do whatever they wanted while rigidly controlling black and Hispanic schools, they asked?
Realizing he had walked into a political morass, Mr. Klein quietly worked out a formula that would ensure that his list was racially, geographically and economically diverse. Although the list included only a few schools in the Bronx and none in poor neighborhoods like East New York, West Harlem or Ocean Hill-Brownsville, 55 of the 209 schools chosen serve mostly black and Hispanic populations. (Mr. Klein originally picked 208 schools, but added one last week that he had mistakenly passed over, Public School 130 in Bayside, Queens.) 
At some of those 55 schools, just over half the students passed standardized reading and math exams last year. Since schools serving middle-class students needed higher test scores to make the list than those serving poor ones, some parents and educators complained of a double standard. 
"I would not have chosen to grant an exemption based on anything other than academic achievement with a very standardized set of parameters," said Merryl H. Tisch, a member of the State Board of Regents from Manhattan. "Community leaders who advocated for certain schools need to search their souls about whether the kids in those schools who are not meeting standards are going to be well served by not having the standard curriculum."
Mrs. Tisch and others predicted that most of the high-performing middle-class schools that did not make the list would be added to it in the coming weeks, since Mr. Klein is allowing an appeals process. 
So, by doing this, Mr. Klein may end up appeasing the school system's middle-class constituency for now, though other challenges loom as he tries to give poor children the same educational opportunities as their middle-class counterparts.
For example, next year, to comply with a new federal law, Mr. Klein plans to allow students in schools labeled as failing to transfer to better schools anywhere in the city. The policy may curtail the number of middle-class students who are granted transfers into top schools, since children in failing schools would have priority. 
Middle-class parents may also fight the policy because they would not want children from poorer neighborhoods transferring to their schools. 
Some educators who support Mr. Klein's broad policy agenda said they feared his decision to include some schools on the list for the sake of diversity sent a message that he would buckle on other issues, too.
"What's been great up until now is that both Klein and Bloomberg have been immune from the very entrenched politics of different groups in this city," one education official said. "If people are perceiving a weakness in that armor, we are going to be in trouble. Their efforts can't be punctured by race or special-interest politics."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ANKARA; 
Turkey Expected to Vote On G.I. Presence Tuesday

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
The Turkish foreign minister said today that his country's Parliament would probably vote on Tuesday on whether to allow thousands of American combat troops to use Turkey as a base for attacks on Iraq. 
 Foreign Minister Yasar Yakis told Turkish television that American and Turkish negotiators were still trying to resolve several fundamental issues, including the exact role of Turkish troops in northern Iraq and the control of the country's oil fields there. But he said there was a "high probability" that a deal could be worked out in time to hold the vote on Tuesday. 
 Mr. Yakis spoke as Turkish and American negotiators continued their discussions in Ankara, the capital. 
Parliamentary approval would clear the way for the arrival of as many as 40,000 American troops, envisioned as the northern component of a two-pronged attack against Iraq. Turkey's leaders had been resisting American pressure, in large part out of fear that a war would wreck the economy. Last week, Turkish officials approved an economic assistance package worth as much as $15 billion in grants and loans or loan guarantees that is meant to cushion the economy if war comes. 
The remaining issues, discussed by Turkish and American negotiators today, involve the possibility of Turkish intervention in northern Iraq. In his interview today and in statements last week, Mr. Yakis outlined a Turkish vision for a role in northern Iraq that seemed at odds with that of the Bush administration. 
Mr. Yakis has suggested that his government intends to send tens of thousands of Turkish troops into northern Iraq to prevent the establishment of a Kurdish state. The Turkish government has fought a long-running insurgency against its own Kurdish minority, and is afraid that a Kurdish state in northern Iraq would revive similar desires here. 
The Americans are concerned that a large-scale Turkish intervention in northern Iraq could ignite age-old ethnic hatreds between the Turks and Kurds, and prompt a similar intervention in the region by the Iranian military. In interviews, American officials have said they want to limit any Turkish intervention to dealing with refugees. 
In the interview today on CNN, Mr. Yakis indicated that he wanted to ensure that the oil fields around the northern Iraqi cities of Mosul and Kirkuk did not fall into the hands of Kurdish fighters. Turkish officials fear that Kurdish possession of the oil fields would give the Kurds the economic power to form their own state. 
In the interview, Mr. Yakis indicated that the Turks preferred to have American forces take the oil fields.
"The formulation we are nearing agreement on is that those areas will be under U.S. control," he said.
Mr. Yakis said negotiators were also discussing the possibility of disarming Kurdish militias after a war. The main Kurdish groups have thousands of armed men under their leadership, and there is speculation that American commanders may give them more weapons before a war in Iraq. 
Mr. Yakis has expressed concern about any weapons, presumably artillery, that the Americans would give to the groups in preparation for a war. In an interview last week, he suggested that the Turkish government would not allow the Kurds to hold on to their guns. 
"If those weapons given to the Kurds would be pointed against us, this is something we cannot accept," he said in an interview on Friday. "This is why we insist that these weapons should be accounted for accurately as to whom they are given, when the time comes to collect them. 
"We should also prevent these arms from reaching undesired hands." 
A senior Kurdish official said this weekend that his forces would resist any Turkish attempt to disarm them. Barham Salih, prime minister of the eastern Kurdish zone, controlled by the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, said the Kurds would not surrender their weapons until a democratic government was established in Baghdad. 
"Turkey has no business getting militarily involved in northern Iraq," Dr. Salih said. "Turkey's intervention would invoke latent historical sensitivities and invite other neighbors to intervene."
"This is a Pandora's box," he added. "It is better left alone."
The Anatolia News Agency reported that Turkish and American officials agreed today to oversee the arming and disarming of the Iraqi Kurds jointly. The report could not be confirmed. 
In his interview on Friday, Mr. Yakis also suggested that Turkish soldiers might be sent to protect the ethnic Turkoman population of northern Iraq. American and Kurdish officials worry that such a Turkish role could send their troops deep into northern Iraq. 
"The Turkomans don't need to be armed for protection; instead, soldiers could be located in their areas," Mr. Yakis said. "All we want is stability in the region. We won't be going into northern Iraq to fight either people living in this region or the Iraqis."
"Turkey will be there militarily only to prevent any kind of development that would harm stability," he said.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Signs of a Rise in Hospital Patients 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
As aging boomers and their elders submit in growing numbers to surgery for ailing hearts and aching joints, the number of patients in hospital beds each night in New York City has leveled off after more than a decade of steep decline, and is even showing signs of rising.
 The numbers, documented in a new report by the United Hospital Fund, mirror a national trend, but the change is especially striking in New York City, where the number of people staying in hospitals on an average day plummeted during the 1990's. Health care experts who not long ago were predicting continued declines at New York City hospitals now foresee years of slow but steady growth, as the baby boom generation reaches old age, requires more care and takes advantage of new surgical techniques. 
 The shift could have profound consequences for New York's hospitals, many of which are financially troubled.
"A long-term switch to growing rather than shrinking is going to have all kinds of serious effects, many of which we probably haven't even thought of," said James R. Tallon Jr., president of the United Hospital Fund, a nonprofit group that studies health care issues and finances health care projects. 
In the 1990's, New York State and insurance companies put heavy pressure on hospitals in the city to cut costs by downsizing, pointing to the drop in the number of patients they housed. That, in turn, helped spur a wave of hospital mergers and ward closings. A long-term turnabout in the trend could lessen the pressure on hospitals to shrink.
But with the economy stumbling, New York's hospitals are still being pressed hard by Albany, Washington and managed care companies to cut costs, and Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed significant cuts in state payments to hospitals.
One reason New York City's health care costs are higher than the national average is that there is a longstanding tendency to use hospitals for services that are provided in doctors' offices in other parts of the country. If hospitals become more crowded, that would add to the pressure on them to shift to more outpatient care.
Pamela Brier, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, said that increasing business for hospitals does not necessarily translate into better financial conditions for them.
"The patients we're seeing are, on the whole, much sicker than those we saw 10 years ago," she said. "That, combined with the continued pressure to cut costs, does not spell good news."
The number of patients in hospitals on an average night fell nationally during the 1990's, in part because of a boom in outpatient surgery that used to require hospital stays. In a way, that decline in the daily census was misleading, because the number of people admitted to hospitals actually rose a bit during the decade. But over the same period, managed-care restrictions and improved techniques cut the length of the average hospital stay by 30 percent. So, even as the number of hospital inpatients over the course of a year climbed, the number on any given day fell.
In New York City, the drop in the daily hospital census was accelerated by the ebbing of three great epidemics: AIDS, crack cocaine and violent crime.
Over all, New York City's hospital census peaked in 1987, when there were 30,000 inpatients on an average day, the study said, and then came a long, steep decline to about 20,000 in 1999. That 33 percent drop was more than double the 16 percent decline nationally in the same period.
"There were two conflicting sets of trends, one up and one down, but the downward trend lines were so dramatic that until they leveled off a few years ago, they really masked the upward ones," Mr. Tallon said.
One upward trend was the city's growing population. But the more pronounced one was a sharp increase in the number of surgical procedures, driven by the development of new techniques.
The number of people undergoing coronary angioplasty (the insertion and inflation of a balloon to open a blocked artery near the heart), nearly tripled in the 1990's. Knee and hip replacements rose by more than half. Fusion of spinal vertebrae, usually to treat injury or arthritis, more than doubled. Stomach bypass operations for obese people tripled. 
As the population gets older and heavier, and the success rate rises for those procedures, the demand for them will continue to climb, hospital officials say.
The number of people in New York City's hospitals each day rose slightly in 2000 and into 2001. The World Trade Center attack prompted a drop in hospital use in the city, as people postponed elective treatment and suburbanites opted for local hospitals. Even so, the study shows that the numbers for the first half of 2002, the most recent available, are about the same as those for 1999.
Anecdotally, officials at several hospitals say that more beds are filled now compared with a year ago, and that they now believe the underlying long-term trend is slightly upward.
Nationally, the hospital census rose 3 percent from 1999 to 2002, the first significant increase in two decades.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A2-6

Iraq Seeks Talks With U.N. On Future of Its Missiles
Iraq hopes that technical talks with United Nations weapons experts might stave off the forced destruction of its most potent short-range missiles, but played down the importance of these weapons in defending the country. Diplomatic maneuvering is increasing for a new resolution authorizing the use of force. A1

HEADLINE: The Future at Ground Zero 

 BODY:
Later this week we'll know which of the two designs for the World Trade Center site has been selected, the one by Studio Daniel Libeskind or the one by the Think team, which includes the architects Rafael Vinoly and Frederic Schwartz. But it's worth pausing to consider where we are and how we got here. The city will be the winner no matter which design is selected. It's not hard to see how either would transform Lower Manhattan. And the very process of arriving at this point has already changed the city. 
 At first, the clearing of what had become an almost consecrated mountain of rubble took place in ad hoc fashion. As time passed, the excavation progressed in a more systematic way, allowing the debris to be cleared away in less time and for less money than anyone had expected. The chaos of that first day gave rise to a meaningful and resourceful order. 
 This page hoped, as did many New Yorkers, that something similar would happen in the process of planning a new Lower Manhattan. The question wasn't just whether a design would emerge that would match the symbolic power of Ground Zero. It was also how the design would emerge. When it comes to development, this city is a maze of intersecting interests, and the potential for cronyism is enormous. Yet this was no ordinary real estate. It's safe to say that New Yorkers probably know more about these 16 acres, and about the leases and contracts that shaped them, than they do about any other place in the city. The tragedy of 9/11 gave the public a civic claim to that site, and the knowledge that has built up over time has given the public what it needed to use that claim wisely. That we are where we are -- about to learn which of these designs will move forward -- is the result of unprecedented public participation in urban planning.
None of this has been perfect. The effort to reach a consensus on these designs, even the effort to find designs worth consensus, has been a learning process. But the city will reach an important moment this week when it becomes clear which proposal has been chosen. That decision will speed the competition and planning for a memorial. To a certain extent, it will also ratify the openness of this process and the perhaps unexpected capacity of the major institutional players, like the city, the state, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority, to find common ground.
Things will get trickier when the money starts to flow and the contracts start to be doled out. But in a city as full of civil and commercial frictions as this one, in a time as financially difficult as the present, with the need to move forward rapidly pressing on all of us, we have nonetheless found our way to a set of choices that are far better than we might have hoped for through a process that was far more democratic than history would have led us to expect. That alone is a fine memorial.

HEADLINE: Outlawing Russia's Sex Traders 

 BODY:
With criminal ease, Russia's organized gangs use young people's dreams to lure them into the back rooms of the world. Work in tourism abroad, a well-dressed woman promises. Model for glamorous magazines in America, a smooth-talking man suggests. Then, all too suddenly, the struggling shop girl, the lonely young boy or the frantic single mother wakes up as a prostitute in a foreign country with no time for dreams and no way to escape. 
 Last week, the Russian parliament took a much-needed step toward cracking down on this brutal human trafficking. The Duma drafted a law that would require the government to warn Russians about the deceitful methods used to turn women and children into modern-day sex slaves. The bill, which needs to be approved by the Russian government and then enforced by police, would make trafficking in humans illegal. And it would require authorities to provide real help for those forced into servitude. Given Russia's crime-ridden society, it will not solve the problem. But without it, criminal gangs will be freer to earn an estimated $7 billion a year trafficking in unwilling prostitutes. Human rights groups have suggested that thousands of Russians are dragged away each year to underground brothels around the world. 
 Russia is not the only nation with a booming slave business, but its effort to change the laws comes at the right time. Under a law passed in 2000, Washington issues an annual list of nations that are "significant" contributors to this growing global problem. This year, the law allows President Bush to withhold aid or impose limited sanctions if countries like Turkey, Bosnia, Indonesia and Cambodia fail to make an effort to combat this scourge. That threat is an important tool to force governments like Russia's to lock up slave traders and help their desperate victims.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
'Medicaid' As a Verb, Then a Crutch

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI wants New York to cut Medicaid. The country's Cadillac of Medicaid programs is just too expensive, says he.
 What he neglects to say is how the program got that way in the first place. Enrollment is rising (the recession) and the population is aging (it happens). But there is another factor: the governor's own policies. 
Mr. Pataki ran for his first term in 1994 pledging to tame Medicaid -- health insurance for the poor, elderly and disabled. But he learned. Following entrenched New York tradition, he did not cut Medicaid. He expanded it, offering coverage to more of the state's working poor and using Medicaid funds to finance salary increases for hospital union members whose leader, Dennis Rivera, then endorsed him. 
Mr. Pataki was so successful in expanding what he once pledged to shrink that now he is trying to return to his fiscally conservative roots.
His conduct should not surprise New Yorkers. Their governors have treated Medicaid like a political tool since its origins in the mid-1960's; Nelson A. Rockefeller realized that it provided a way to subsidize health services that the state and local governments were providing, and went after every last dollar. (Washington picks up half of Medicaid's costs, and in New York, the state and localities share the rest.)
"Medicaid became a verb -- to Medicaid," said James R. Tallon Jr., president of the United Hospital Fund, a health care policy and research organization. "We Medicaid things." It wasn't long before New York was using Medicaid to pay for new and expanded services. Better to get some federal dollars than none, went the thinking in New York, though many other states were wary of the financial burden. 
There are many reasons for New York's expensive Medicaid program, ranging from the ever-high cost of doing business in the state to the disproportionate number of elderly and disabled people who need long-term care. The large immigrant population is also a factor, as is New York's generous menu of Medicaid services.
But many economists say that the central reason for the cost is "Medicaiding," a way of political life. The state spends more of its money on only one thing, education.
Instead of cutting Medicaid, Mr. Pataki channeled Medicaid money to a program called Family Health Plus, which provides health insurance to adults who earn too much for Medicaid, and used the program to guarantee a raise to members of the politically influential hospital workers' union. 
Except for critics from the right, few would fault expanding health care to the working poor, especially with the growing number of uninsured people in the state. But with the budget so out of whack now, how to pay for this new program? Money from the large tobacco settlement helps pay the state's share. Now Mr. Pataki wants to use the tobacco money to help close the budget gap.
SO under his proposed budget, fewer New Yorkers could qualify for Family Health Plus.
There is no talk, though, of touching the union deal. A deal is apparently a deal and under it, the state raised the rates of payments to hospitals and nursing homes -- not to cover patient care, but to cover the salary increases. The state's share of the raises was to come from two sources: the conversion of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a profit-making insurance company from a nonprofit one, and higher Medicaid reimbursement rates that, despite broad warnings to the contrary, the governor counted on from Washington.
As many expected, those higher rates did not materialize. And as critics often note, the Blue Cross conversion could have financed the very kinds of health care services now on the chopping block. In other words, as in other states, the conversion money could have cushioned the recession's blow. 
Mr. Pataki, the off-again-on-again fiscal conservative, has imposed policies that leave him little option but to demand cuts in Medicaid. What he gave, he would now take away. He wants local governments to raise their Medicaid contribution to cover hospital stays and clinic visits, in exchange for the state picking up the cost of prescription drugs. Along with scaling back Family Health Plus, he would also reduce hospital reimbursement rates.
With his proposed cuts facing strong opposition, he is not likely to get everything he wants, but he will get some of it. That leaves those who might be hurt by the cuts to look to the future. For as sure as boom follows bust, the cycle will repeat itself some day in New York, proud and predictable home of "Medicaiding."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DIPLOMACY; 
Powell Seeks China's Help, And, at U.N., Its Abstention

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will try today to narrow sharp differences with China on the United States' two most important foreign policy goals: dismantling North Korea's nuclear weapons programs and disarming Iraq.
 In meetings with President Jiang Zemin and his successor-in-waiting, Hu Jintao, the Communist Party secretary general, Mr. Powell will urge China to play a more forceful role in pressing North Korea to abandon its nuclear programs and meet with the United States in a "multilateral forum," American officials said. 
 "China has considerable influence," Mr. Powell said on Friday, noting that China is the principal supplier of food and fuel aid to North Korea. 
Speaking of the Chinese, a senior State Department official said today, "They can do more."
Mr. Powell is on the second leg of a three-nation Asian tour, having met with senior Japanese officials over the weekend. From China, he will proceed to South Korea for the inauguration on Tuesday of Roh Moo Hyun as president.
On Iraq, Mr. Powell is expected to encourage the Chinese not to veto a new United Nations resolution that the United States and Britain plan to introduce into the Security Council early this week.
China, along with France and Russia, opposes the use of military force to disarm Iraq, and all three are permanent members of the Security Council with the power to veto United Nations resolutions.
American officials are hoping that China can be persuaded to abstain on the Iraq resolution. Though China is uncomfortable with the United States projecting its military power across much of the globe, it also wants to maintain its improving relations with the United States, those officials say.
Mr. Powell predicted on Sunday that the Security Council would act on the new resolution soon after Hans Blix, one of the chief United Nations weapons inspectors, briefs the Council on his latest findings on March 7. 
He said the resolution would be "simple" and "to the point" in declaring that Iraq had failed to comply with past United Nations resolutions requiring it to disarm. The resolution would be viewed as authorizing military action to enforce disarmament, American officials said.
Mr. Powell also described the United States as entering a period of "intense diplomacy" on Iraq, and he urged Japan and other American allies to lobby members of the Council to support the Iraq resolution.
"It is time to take action," Mr. Powell said in a news conference in Tokyo. "The evidence has been clear. They are guilty."
On North Korea, Mr. Powell is looking for the Chinese to persuade the North Koreans to attend a "multilateral forum" where a side meeting with the United States could be arranged, American officials said. 
The United States has proposed inviting North Korea to a meeting sponsored by the European Union and the United States, Britain, France, Russia, China, South Korea, Australia and Japan. But North Korea has rejected that idea, demanding one-on-one talks with the United States that would cover a number of issues, including economic aid and a nonaggression pact. 
The Bush administration has said it will talk to North Korea only about permanently dismantling its nuclear programs, and only in a multilateral setting. Once North Korea "steps back" from its weapons program, the United States will be willing to discuss economic assistance and security agreements, American officials said. 
"You can't eat plutonium," Mr. Powell said in Tokyo, a reference to North Korea's urgent need for food aid and agricultural assistance. "As long as you pursue those technologies, those who can help you grow the things that you can eat and develop an economy that will assist your people can't help you."
In Japan over the weekend, Mr. Powell encouraged Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi and Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi to help persuade fence-sitting members of the Security Council to support the American-sponsored Iraq resolution.
American officials say that although Japan does not have a seat on the Security Council, it maintains good relations with several of the 10 nonpermanent Council members, in large part because of its substantial foreign aid commitments. 
"We hope that the prime minister and foreign minister, because they have been supporting our efforts, will continue to support those efforts," Mr. Powell said in Tokyo. "I hope that once they see the resolution, they will find it the appropriate thing to do to show support for that and to contact members" of the Council.
But it remains unclear how strongly Japan will press the United States' case on Iraq. Mr. Koizumi, who has supported passage of a new resolution, is also under pressure from some members of his own Liberal Democratic Party to avoid supporting a war.
In Japan, as in much of Europe, opinion polls indicate that there is strong public opposition to military action against Iraq. For that reason, Mr. Koizumi and his advisers have tempered their comments in recent days, saying their support for a new resolution does not constitute support for war. 
"We have yet to reach a stage in which we should make a decision on it," Ms. Kawaguchi said on Japanese television on Sunday when asked whether Japan supports going to war against Iraq.
American officials are hoping that Japan will eventually provide fuel and perhaps warships for a military strike against Iraq. 
Japanese ships are assisting the United States in naval operations around the Indian Ocean as part of American efforts to destroy remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. But Japanese officials have indicated that they will need a vote of the Japanese Parliament to authorize the use of those ships in a military action against Iraq.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: KOREAN PENINSULA; 
U.S. Approach on North Korea Is Straining Alliances in Asia

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
With little of the clamor generated by preparations for war with Iraq, the showdown between the United States and North Korea over that country's nuclear weapons program is severely testing Washington's oldest Asian alliances.
 In recent weeks, senior officials in officially pacifist Japan have spoken of mounting a "pre-emptive strike" against North Korea, if it appeared that the heavily armed Communist state intended to use its ballistic missiles against Japan. 
 "Our nation will use military force as a self-defense measure if they start to resort to arms against Japan," said Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba.
For many Japanese commentators, Mr. Ishiba's statement was meant to draw attention to the fact that Japan in reality has no strike ability. More than as a credible threat against North Korea, it was intended to influence a debate that has gathered momentum during the administration of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi over giving the country's armed forces, which face sharp constitutional limits on their action, a larger role in the country's defense, and in making Japan a player in international security again. 
When Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrives here on Monday for the inauguration of Roh Moo Hyun as president of South Korea, he will try to narrow differences with a man whose response to tensions with North Korea has been virtually the opposite of Japan's and, if anything, even more radical.
Mr. Roh has given strong indications that he intends to accelerate South Korea's embrace of North Korea, even as the United States looks for ways to ratchet up pressure on North Korea.
To the dismay of Washington, Mr. Roh has spoken in recent weeks of establishing an economic community with North Korea, stepping up trade, aid and investment there, ruling out economic sanctions and military strikes against the country and even of personally "guaranteeing" North Korea's security.
The president-elect said he would replace the current armistice agreement with a treaty between the Koreas in order to ensure peace on the Korean Peninsula.
"It is better to struggle than to suffer deaths in a war," Mr. Roh said in a speech to the Federation of Korean Trade Unions. "Koreans should stand together, although things will get difficult when the United States bosses us around."
A senior South Korean diplomat said: "It looks like Roh is prepared to throw the alliance away and make common cause with North Korea. We don't understand why he seems to trust North Korea so completely."
While Japan looks nervously at North Korea and is beginning to explore ways to augment its alliance with the United States, South Koreans and experts in this country's affairs are contemplating the end of the five-decade-old alliance between the countries, at least as it has existed, with 37,000 American troops on the front lines here.
"The Japanese are on the spot because the U.S. alliance with South Korea is defunct, and there is no point in insisting on it any more," said Robyn Lim, a regional security expert at Nanzan University in Japan. "The U.S. alliance with Japan is integrally linked with the U.S. alliance with South Korea. Indeed, since the Korean War, the American presence in South Korea has been as much about protecting Japan as it was about South Korea."
Increasingly, the United States is on the spot in South Korea, as well. Mr. Roh, a liberal labor lawyer with almost no international experience, began appointing relatively conservative aides to his national security team today, in what appeared to be a bid to reassure Washington.
He has also distanced himself from the anti-American protests that occurred here throughout the December electoral campaign and seemed to favor his candidacy. Most important, after campaigning for a "more equitable" alliance with the United States, he has said that he sees a place for American troops in this country, even after the two Koreas are united.
There are already signs of a deep distrust of Mr. Roh in the Bush administration. American military officials here say plans are being drawn up to remove thousands of American troops from positions along the demilitarized zone between South and North Korea, and to close the headquarters of American forces in Korea at Yongsan, in the heart of the Seoul, as rapidly as possible.
In a private conversation here last week, a senior American military analyst here said there were profound doubts about what the new South Korean government would do if the United States struck at North Korea's nuclear facilities.
Referring to North Korea's leader, the analyst said: "Kim Jong Il would probably attack our troops on the DMZ and then pick up the phone to Roh and say: 'If the Americans retaliate, I will have to strike back again. We don't want to kill Koreans, but the Americans' Yongsan base is in the middle of your capital. You must do something to stop the Americans.' "
Under such circumstances, the analyst said, Washington would have little confidence in Mr. Roh, who has said he would never support the use of force against North Korea.
Just as the United States is rumored to be contemplating moving its military bases out of Germany, there has been a great deal of talk here, still unofficial but inconceivable even a few months ago, about a possible phase-out of the American military presence in this country.
"As both our forces have modernized, the possibilities for a new division of roles have grown," said the United States ambassador, Thomas C. Hubbard, in a recent speech here, in which he reaffirmed the American interest in retaining troops here.
South Koreans have paid close attention to the recent rift between Washington and its traditional European allies, Germany and France, and many complain that the talk of an American withdrawal is fed by the petulance of a United States that is not accustomed to Asian allies articulating a strong vision of their own security interests.
"Should the United States give up Korea so easily?" said Paik Hak Sun, director of Inter-Korean Studies Program at the Sejong Institute, an independent policy group. "An American rivalry with China is inevitable. Japan will always be a close ally of the United States, for fear of China, but the Korean Peninsula is a lot closer to China, and if the U.S. can keep its troops here it can counter China better and compete for the friendship of the Korean people."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Salomon Reviews Parts of Account

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The Salomon Smith Barney division of Citigroup in New York has started a review for the creative and media parts of its account, which would proceed without the incumbent agencies, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising and Universal McCann in New York.
 The creative part of the account had been handled by McCann-Erickson, and the media part by Universal McCann; both are divisions of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. 
A spokeswoman for McCann-Erickson, Susan Irwin, confirmed a report of the review in the online edition of Adweek. Ms. Irwin described the parting of ways as amicable, adding that the agencies had decided not to take part in the review. 
 The review comes four months after Citigroup announced that it would separate the global equity research and private wealth-management operations of Salomon Smith Barney from the corporate and investment banking operations.
Among other agencies that work for Citigroup are Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, which said it would not take part in the review; and Merkley Newman Harty & Partners in New York, part of the Omnicom Group.
Ad spending by Salomon Smith Barney rises and falls with the fortunes of the stock market. It increased from $35 million in 1998 to $65 million in 2000, according to CMR, the division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending in major media, and then declined to $20 million in 2001, the last full year for which data were available.

HEADLINE: TV Networks Plan Flood Of Reality For Summer 

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
If you think network television is awash in reality shows now, just wait until summer.
 The four big networks are preparing to unleash at least two dozen reality shows from June to September, dwarfing the number currently on their schedules and more than doubling the number they broadcast last summer. 
 In "Roseanne," for example, camera crews will follow the comedian Roseanne Barr as she pitches a cooking show to cable networks and searches for men on a Jewish Internet dating service. "The Will" plans to enlist a rich benefactor to put his potential heirs through all sorts of tests to determine who will inherit his fortune. And then there is "The Simple Life," a reality-show version of the old situation comedy "Green Acres," in which a pair of privileged young women, the hotel heiress Paris Hilton and her best friend Nicole Richie, will move in with a hardscrabble farm family. 
Television executives originally embraced such limited-run reality shows as an inexpensive way to combat the glut of summer repeats that always advanced the erosion of their audiences by inviting viewers to flock to cable channels. But the summer months also increasingly serve as a petri dish for the networks' regular seasons; where the biggest summer reality hits, like "Survivor" and "American Idol," can be transplanted into in-season schedules. 
Over the last four years such moves have radically altered the competitive balance among the networks, and, for many younger viewers, have made traditional sitcoms, dramas or newsmagazine programs look dated -- and vulnerable. Aware of this track record, many television executives view this coming summer as the ultimate laboratory for a restructuring, if not outright reinvention of the business.
"The economics of television demand cheaper shows like this," said Michael Davies, the producer of the former prime-time hit "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," whose coming summer reality show "Wife Swap" will have families from different social strataexchange mothers for two weeks. 
"To exclusively have had expensive scripted dramas and comedies was perverse," Mr. Davies said. "You could not afford it. I think you're going to find the whole nature of the television season, with 22-episode cycles of scripted shows, changed."
Many viewers, especially those in the young adult groups that most networks and advertisers covet, have welcomed the transformation. Last week offered the starkest proof yet. Seven reality shows were among the 13-highest rated shows, topped by the 40 million who watched "Joe Millionaire" on the Fox Network pick his special someone and offer his hand in temporary stardom. Those ratings are comparable to an Academy Awards broadcast.
"I watch them all," said Traci Brandon, 25, a indexer at Corbis, a photo agency, in New York. "These real people, they're just crazy. They're a lot more interesting to watch than what writers are coming up with. And they're funnier, too."
Bibi Prival, 28, a special events coordinator at the Sense of Smell Institute in New York, said that because escapism is at the heart of these shows' appeal, intelligence need not be a crucial ingredient.
"When a scripted show isn't smart, it's bad; but when a reality show isn't smart, for some reason, it's entertaining," Ms. Prival said. "For some reason, you get off on the vapidity, sluttiness, stupidity and awkwardness of these shows."
All those qualities figure to be on ample display everywhere on television this summer. ABC, which has been the busiest network this season in the reality field, with shows like "The Bachelorette" and "Are You Hot?" will contribute up to six more entries this summer. Besides "Roseanne" and "The Will," the network has also scheduled a PG-rated version of the film "Indecent Proposal" called "Love for Sale," in which an unmarried couple is offered a large sum of money to have one of them go off on a vacation with a stranger of the opposite sex. ABC is also considering a show in which hopeful palooka boxers will work toward a Rocky-inspired match with Mike Tyson.
Fox plans another edition of "Temptation Island" along with "The Simple Life." Executives at the network are withholding details about other prospective titles, but acknowledge Fox could have as many as five entries this summer. 
CBS has announced three summer reality shows, including new seasons of "Big Brother" and "Amazing Race," and may add one or two more. Its main new entry: "Cupid," described by the CBS executive in charge of reality, Ghen Maynard, as "Blind Date" meets "American Idol." (Simon Cowell, the acerbic British judge on "American Idol" is one of the producers.) A young woman and her two best friends will form a panel to judge young suitors who must make an impression with their looks, talent or personality within 30 seconds. Ten finalists will then go on dates with the young woman, and the ultimate winner is chosen by audience votes.
No network, however, will be as aggressive this summer as NBC, which plans no fewer than 10 summer reality series.
NBC, unlike the other networks, has not created a blockbuster reality show, and, at least partly as a result, has seen its long-term dominance among younger adults falter over the last six weeks. Fox, fueled by "Joe Millionaire" and "American Idol," has surged ahead.
So NBC is packing its schedule, hoping one or more reality entries will become a success. The ideas include four talent contests similar to "American Idol" -- for movie action heroes, comedians and two categories of singers, children under 16 and so-called senior citizens. In the singular world of network television, "seniors" are defined as people over 35.
NBC will also have its dating division, including "Around the World in 80 Dates," a kind of international "Bachelor," who will add contestants from various countries to his planeload of available young women as the show goes along. The network has even scheduled "The Restaurant," a behind-the-scenes look at the start-up of a restaurant in Manhattan.
This assemblage from the big networks does not even count the plans of cable networks, many of which have their own plans for the genre, nor the efforts of the part-time broadcast networks, the WB and UPN, which plan competition shows featuring surfers and fashion models respectively. Between those channels and cable, 10 or more additional reality series could easily be added. 
In all cases, the shows will have short runs of 5 to 11 weeks, which many executives see as a key to the success of reality shows. "We've finally learned what the rest of the world has known for a long time: Telenovelas work," said Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment, referring to the limited-run soap operas popular in Latin American countries and elsewhere. "You put on eight episodes, nobody has to make a long-term commitment."
Network executives acknowledge that their reality strategy contains risks, beginning with the possibility of oversaturation. "It scares me to death," one senior entertainment executive said. "If this bubble bursts and you've relied on this stuff exclusively, you're going to be dead."
Numerous executives cited the example of ABC's over-reliance on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" after it became the first of the explosive summer hits in 1999. ABC cut back on developing scripted series and when the ratings for "Millionaire" collapsed, the network's fortunes went with it. 
"This is all about balance and using your unscripted hits strategically," said Sandy Grushow, the chairman of Fox Entertainment. While Fox's surge in the last few weeks can be attributed largely to the strength of its reality hits, Mr. Grushow said the network has used the shows like "American Idol" to bolster the ratings of some existing scripted shows on its schedule like the highly regarded drama "24."
Many executives said the biggest unknown is how the possible outbreak of a war with Iraq might affect the audience's taste for these kinds of shows. "Every one of these felt wrong after 9/11, so we have to see," said Lloyd Braun, the chairman of ABC Entertainment. 
The summer glut is certain to weed out the lesser ideas, Mr. Zucker said. "The best programs will survive," he said. "We're in the middle of a frenzy now. But things will eventually recalibrate themselves." 
Still, he concluded, "It's going to be a wild summer."

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Key to Domestic Agenda Could Be Victory in Iraq

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex. 

 BODY:
For months now at the White House, it has been all Iraq, all the time. On Saturday at his ranch here, President Bush met with the prime minister of Spain to talk about Iraq. On Tuesday in the Oval Office, he will meet with the prime minister of Bulgaria to talk about Iraq. This past Thursday in Georgia, he gave a speech about the American economy -- and talked about Iraq.
 Administration officials readily acknowledge that Iraq has drowned out most of the discussion of Mr. Bush's domestic agenda. "There's not a lot of oxygen in the air," said Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director. 
 But what administration officials and Republicans close to the White House also concede is that the president's ability to sell the public and Congress on one of the most ambitious domestic agendas in decades is linked to the outcome of the potential war in Iraq, with victory a turnkey to legislative success. A victory, they say, would give momentum to the president's plans to cut taxes and overhaul Medicare, which right now face objections even from some members of Mr. Bush's own party.
"If Saddam decided to leave the country tomorrow," a senior White House official said last week, "a lot of that uncertainty would be removed, and I think you would see salutary effects in a number of areas, including on the legislative and political fronts."
Officially, there is no linkage. Administration officials say publicly that they would be foolish to count on the political capital from a war that could, after all, go wrong. "Medicare needs to be modernized, and people deserve jobs regardless of what happens in Iraq," said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary. "We don't tie the two together." 
But if the war is protracted, with rising costs and increasing casualties, say some Republicans and centrist Democrats the White House is relying on, Mr. Bush's proposals will languish.
"If we get tied up in Iraq, it's going to make it more difficult to get a domestic agenda that costs a lot of money," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, who is regularly consulted by the White House. "If it goes well, obviously things can change dramatically."
It is hard not to ignore the obvious, which is that the domestic agenda and a possible war are moving forward in parallel time. The White House strategy is to push the centerpiece of the agenda, Mr. Bush's $670 billion package of tax cuts, into the legislative process now, so that the proposal will be up for debate on Capitol Hill this spring and summer -- when it is possible that the president will have emerged victorious on Iraq. That is a lesson learned, Republicans say, from Mr. Bush's father, who after the American victory in the 1991 Persian Gulf war had only a minor legislative agenda to offer Capitol Hill.
"He could have had anything he wanted from a Democratic Congress, but they never had a domestic Desert Storm to follow up," said David R. Gergen, a White House adviser in the Nixon, Ford, Reagan and Clinton administrations. "This group has been smart enough to know that if they have an array of proposals already fleshed out in the pipeline, with debate under way, with committees considering them, the president marching in with an 85 percent approval rating can push through far more than the normal political process will allow."
Other Republicans agree, up to a point.
"It's quite natural that if he would have a big international victory, it would help him," said Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is the most influential senator on tax legislation. "But he shouldn't count on it."
As Mr. Bush headed back to the wintry landscape of Washington yesterday after a long weekend at his ranch, where he drove Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain through the greening fields in the presidential pick-up truck, he faced a meeting with the nation's governors on Monday, a session with his economic advisers on Tuesday and a speech to a Latino coalition on Wednesday.
But the reality underneath the domestic bustle is that Mr. Bush's week will be dominated by his battle for votes in the United Nations Security Council on a new resolution authorizing military force against Saddam Hussein.
The march toward Baghdad that started back in August is in a period of "final deliberations," Mr. Bush declared this weekend, signaling that Mr. Hussein may have only weeks before an American attack.
Meanwhile, Democrats and Republicans say that for all practical purposes, Medicare, prescription drugs and Mr. Bush's proposal to eliminate the dividend tax, to name just his top domestic priorities, are waiting for Iraq.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: HEARTS AND MINDS; 
Firing Leaflets and Electrons, U.S. Wages Information War

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
Even before President Bush orders American forces to loose bullets and bombs on Iraq, the military is starting an ambitious assault using a growing arsenal of electronic and psychological weapons on the information battlefield.
 American cyber-warfare experts recently waged an e-mail assault, directed at Iraq's political, military and economic leadership, urging them to break with Saddam Hussein's government. A wave of calls has gone to the private cellphone numbers of specially selected officials inside Iraq, according to leaders at the Pentagon and in the regional Central Command. 
 As of last week, more than eight million leaflets had been dropped over Iraq -- including towns 65 miles south of Baghdad -- warning Iraqi antiaircraft missile operators that their bunkers will be destroyed if they track or fire at allied warplanes. In the same way, a blunt offer has gone to Iraqi ground troops: surrender, and live. 
But the leaflets are old-fashioned instruments compared with some of the others that are being applied already or are likely to be used soon.
Radio transmitters hauled aloft by Air Force Special Operations EC-130E planes are broadcasting directly to the Iraqi public in Arabic with programs that mimic the program styles of local radio stations and are more sophisticated than the clumsy preachings of previous wartime propaganda efforts.
"Do not let Saddam tarnish the reputation of soldiers any longer," one recent broadcast said. "Saddam uses the military to persecute those who don't agree with his unjust agenda. Make the decision."
Military planners at the United States Central Command expect to rely on many kinds of information warfare -- including electronic attacks on power grids, communications systems and computer networks, as well as deception and psychological operations -- to break the Iraqi military's will to fight and sway Iraqi public opinion. 
Commanders may use supersecret weapons that could flash millions of watts of electricity to cripple Iraqi computers and equipment, and literally turn off the lights in Baghdad if the campaign escalates to full-fledged combat.
"The goal of information warfare is to win without ever firing a shot," said James R. Wilkinson, a spokesman for the Central Command in Tampa, Fla. "If action does begin, information warfare is used to make the conflict as short as possible."
Senior military officials say, for example, that the American radio shows broadcast from the EC-130E "Commando Solo" planes follow the format of a popular Iraqi station, "Voice of the Youth," managed by President Hussein's older son, Uday.
The American programs open with greetings in Arabic, followed by Euro-pop and 1980's American rock music -- intended to appeal to younger Iraqi troops, perceived by officials as the ones most likely to lay down their arms. The broadcasts include traditional Iraqi folk music, so as not to alienate other listeners, and a news program in Arabic prepared by Army psychological operations experts at Fort Bragg, N.C.
Then comes the official message: Any war is not against the Iraqi people, but is to disarm Mr. Hussein and end his government.
American commanders say they believe that these psychological salvos have, to some degree, influenced Iraqi forces to move their defenses or curtail their antiaircraft fire.
"It pays to drop the leaflets," Lt. Gen. T. Michael Moseley, commander of allied air forces in the Persian Gulf, said by telephone from his headquarters in Saudi Arabia. "It sends a direct message to the operator on the gun. It sends a direct message to the chain of command."
Deceptionand psychological operations have been a part of warfare for centuries, and American commanders carried out limited information attacks -- both psychological operations, or "psyops," and more traditional electronic warfare like jamming or crippling the enemy's equipment -- in the Persian Gulf war in 1991 and the air campaign over Kosovo in 1999, as well as in Afghanistan. But commanders looking back on those campaigns say their current planning is much broader and more tightly integrated into the main war plan than ever before.
"What we're seeing now is the weaving of electronic warfare, psyops and other information warfare through every facet of the plan from our peacetime preparations through execution," said Maj. Gen. Paul J. Lebras, chief of the Joint Information Operations Center, a secretive military agency based in Texas that has sent a team of experts to join the Central Command info-warfare team for the Iraq campaign.
As modern combat relies increasingly on precision strikes at targets carried out over long distances, the military is likewise increasingly aware that there are many ways to disable the operations at those targets.
An adversary's antiaircraft radar site, for example, can be destroyed by a bomb or missile launched by a warplane; it can be captured or blown up by ground forces; or the enemy soldiers running the radar can be persuaded to shut down the system and just go home.
"We are trying very hard to be empathetic with the Iraqi military," said a senior American information warfare official. "We understand their situation. The same for the Iraqi population. We wish them no harm. We will take great pains to make those people understand that they should stay away from military equipment."
Even so, the military's most ardent advocates of information warfare acknowledge that American pilots ordered into enemy airspace would rather be told that antiaircraft sites were struck first by ordnance, rather than by leaflets.
Aerial pictures help the military assess bomb damage to a target. The softer kind of strike is harder to assess.
Information warfare experts look for what they call "the voila moment."
"In Afghanistan, the biggest lesson we learned in our tactical information operations -- the radio and TV broadcasts -- was the importance in explaining, 'Why are we here?' " a senior American military officer said. "The majority of Afghanis did not know that Sept. 11 occurred. They didn't even know of our great tragedy."
During the war in Afghanistan, this officer said, "The voila moment came when we saw that the population understood why coalition forces were fighting the Taliban and Al Qaeda."
In Iraq, he said, "it will be when we see a break with the leadership."
Delivering radios to the people of Afghanistan presented a particular problem. About 500 were air-dropped over the country, and all of them were destroyed on impact. The military and aid groups passed out more than 6,500, and millions of leaflets were dropped telling the Afghan people of frequencies used for the American broadcasts.
The American military also took over one important frequency, 8.7 megahertz, used by the Taliban for its official radio broadcasts. That became possible once the towers used by the Taliban for relaying their military commands were blown up as part of the war effort. As in most totalitarian governments, the military and government used the same system for their radio broadcasts. The American military continues to broadcast to the Afghan people over that channel.
Improvisation remains a hallmark of the emerging information war, said Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Maney, of the Army's Civil Affairs and Psychological Operations Command.
In Afghanistan, General Maney said, the American military found it hard to get its radio and television messages out to many villages that had access to neither. So Special Forces troops made contact with local coffee-house managers, and offered them the same radio programs being broadcast from Commando Solo planes, but on compact discs to be played over a boom box for the patrons.
The program gave birth to a new icon on the military's maps of Afghanistan: a tiny picture of a coffee mug to indicate the location of village businesses that agreed to play CD copies of the American radio programming.
If Mr. Bush orders an attack against Iraq, the information offensive will expand to a fierce but invisible war of electrons. Air commanders will rely on a small but essential fleet of surveillance and reconnaissance aircraft, including the radar-jamming EC-130H Compass Call and electronic-eavesdropping RC-135 Rivet Joint. There are just over a dozen of each aircraft in the American arsenal.
Flying from Prince Sultan Air Base, outside Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, the Rivet Joint is already playing an important role in collecting Iraqi radio and radar emissions, which are jammed when American and British planes in the no-flight zones periodically attack targets on the ground. The RC-135, a military version of a Boeing 707 jet with a bulbous nose filled with sensors, is essentially a flying listening post, orbiting at the edge of the battlefield above 30,000 feet.
In the rear of the planes, filled with high-powered computers and other sensors, intelligence specialists, many of whom speak Arabic or Farsi, monitor the airwaves, intercepting conversations from military communications links or other networks. Much of this information is passed to the National Security Agency for analysis.
At the front of the plane, which has a 32-member crew, electronic warfare specialists sit at a separate bank of computers, gathering up radar signals of all kinds, including Iraqi air defenses. Rivet Joints have the ability to scan automatically across an array of communications frequencies, allowing an operator to home in on individual frequencies and pass that information on to the Awacs radar or J-Stars ground-surveillance planes, which have better ability to pinpoint the locations of the transmissions.
The Compass Call is a modified C-130 cargo plane, also filled with high-powered computers and sensors. Usually flying at above 20,000 feet and, ideally, about 80 to 100 miles from the target to be jammed, the Compass Calls are directed to their targets by the Rivet Joints, other aircraft or targets identified in their pre-mission planning. The 13-member crews include linguists, cryptologists, other analysts and the flight personnel.
Metal antenna cables hang down from the plane's tail in a distinctive pattern that looks like a metal trapeze or cheese-cutter. Electronic signals are collected from sensors in the blunt nose of the airplane; antennae in the rear of the aircraft blast electrons that jam enemy radar and other communications.
Flying perpendicular to the target to maximize the jamming, on-board specialists lock on to the frequencies to be disrupted. The plane can jam multiple targets at once. When it comes time to carry out a mission, a flight officer pushes a little red button on a computer keyboard, "JAM," and up to 800 watts of power is zapped at the target. If the target switches frequency, the Compass Call operators are ready to jam that ina constant cat-and-mouse game.
In a war against Iraq, military commanders say, new technology will probably allow those electronic combat planes to plant false targets in Iraqi radars and spoof the air defense systems.
In an interview, Gen. John P. Jumper, the Air Force chief of staff, declined to discuss the highly classified technical advances, except to say, "We're approaching the point where we can tell the SA-10 radar it is a Maytag washer and not a radar, and put it in the rinse cycle instead of the firing cycle."
