HEADLINE: Japan, Its Finances in Disarray, Picks Old-School Central Banker 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Backing away from his own calls for an independent, reform-minded policy maker to lead the Japanese central bank, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has selected a career bureaucrat backed by the country's establishment to be the bank's next governor.
 The choice of Toshihiko Fukui to succeed Masaru Hayami, whose term ends next month, has not yet been formally approved by the cabinet, but it is now considered all but certain. It ends months of speculation here about how Mr. Koizumi would make what will probably be his most important economic policy decision this year. 
 By choosing a defender of the status quo rather than a "deflation fighter," Mr. Koizumi disappointed many economists in Japan and critics abroad, who had hoped for a break in the logjam that has kept the country from taming its economic problems. But two big constituencies -- Japan's main business groups and the staff of the central bank itself -- supported Mr. Fukui, a former deputy governor of the bank. 
Like Mr. Hayami, Mr. Fukui has rejected politicians' demands that the central bank establish an inflation target and take other steps considered radical here meant to pump up the sagging economy and halt the four-year slide in prices. Bond prices and the yen rose today on market expectations that Mr. Fukui would oppose taking major steps to spur inflation, the yen settling in New York at 117.92 to the dollar. 
Significantly, Mr. Fukui will be joined on the bank's governing board by two new deputies -- Toshiro Muto, a former vice finance minister, and Kazumasa Iwata, who worked at the Economic Planning Agency and is now a cabinet adviser and a professor at the University of Tokyo. 
By choosing a career bureaucrat from each of Japan's main financial policy-making centers, Mr. Koizumi has opted to create a balance of power among the agencies, which have feuded during Mr. Hayami's five-year tenure. The infighting, much of it rude and in public, has gotten in the way of taking important steps to fight deflation or to deal with the immense pile of bad loans plaguing the nation's banks. 
Skeptics said today that the appointments would just prolong gridlock. But other analysts said the new lineup might produce more coordinated solutions to Japan's seemingly intractable problems.
Mr. Muto and Mr. Iwata are expected to push for the central bank to buy many more government bonds, as a way of capping a recent rise in long-term interest rates, if the government agrees to take stronger steps to clean up the banks.
"What's very important for Japan's economy is to have a comprehensive review of the problems and a full-fledged set of policies," said Yasuhisa Shiozaki, a member of Parliament from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party with financial experience. "Fukui, as a mainstream team player, could do this." 
Formal nomination hearings must still be held and a vote taken in Parliament before March 19, when Mr. Hayami will retire. Senior members of the ruling party, eager to avoid a time-consuming battle with the opposition, met with Mr. Koizumi tonight to discuss the nominations. 
Mr. Fukui, 67, a native of Osaka, has worked at the central bank for 40 years, including stints at local branches and as the bank's representative in Paris. After heading the research and credit management bureaus, he rose to executive director and then deputy governor.
But his rise hit a snag in 1998, when he and the bank's governor at the time, Yasuo Matsushita, were forced to resign to take responsibility for a bribery scandal involving leaks of financially sensitive information, an episode that will probably be raised at his confirmation hearing.
Exiled from the central bank, Mr. Fukui became chairman of the Fujitsu Research Institute, a private policy group, and deputy chairman of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives, two posts that won him strong backing in the business circles that support the ruling party.
As governor of the bank, Mr. Fukui will face banking and financial problems like few seen elsewhere in modern times. The nonperforming loans on Japanese banks' books now amount to at least 15 percent of the country's gross domestic product -- five times the scale of the 1980's savings and loan crisis in the United States. New bank lending has been declining for five years, starving even healthy companies of credit. 
Under Mr. Hayami's leadership, the central bank lowered short-term rates to near zero beginning in 1999, and has been flooding the money markets with cash. But the policy had the unintended effect of making it easier for lenders to keep failing borrowers on indefinite life support and avoid the harsh medicine of foreclosures and write-offs.
For the fiscal year that ends on March 31, the Japanese economy is expected to record growth of just 1 percent, and next year promises to be no better. The banks are accelerating write-offs somewhat and posting huge losses, but bad loans are still piling up faster than they are written off. The government may yet have to intervene on a large scale no matter what the central bank does. 
"The huge amount of assets the central bank has already bought has failed to stop deflation or get banks lending again," said Akio Mikuni, who runs an independent credit agency. "The problems are much bigger than the Bank of Japan." 
In recent interviews, Mr. Fukui has said much the same thing. He told Bloomberg News, "Deflation is something like being trapped in a pit, and we can't get out of it unless everyone plays his or her own role." He also rejected calls for the central bank to switch its price policy goal from stability to inflation.
Backers of inflation targeting, as such a switch is known, say that consumers and businesses will only begin to spend again if they think that the central bank and the government are both in earnest about forcing prices upward. Measures like a huge new expansion of the money supply have been suggested.
But Mr. Fukui, like Mr. Hayami, has resisted such ideas, saying that once it started, inflation would be too hard to stop.
Critics say that kind of thinking is a throwback to the immediate postwar period, when Japan's economy was in ruins and prices were soaring. Mr. Hayami joined the central bank toward the end of that period, and like many at the bank today, he is a staunch defender of a strong yen, which keeps prices down. 
"Bank of Japan bureaucrats remember hyperinflation the way Texans remember the Alamo," said Chris Walker, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. 
But Japan's problems have become far more complex. Deflation is making it harder for debtors to repay their obligations, while negligible interest rates have made it impossible for pensioners to live off the income on their savings. For companies, continual downward pressure on prices erodes profits.
The government, though, has run up more than 600 trillion yen ($5 trillion) in debt over 10 years, trying to kick-start the economy with deficit spending on public works projects and with tax cuts. Any increase in interest rates now would risk sending debt service payments spiraling out of control.
To alleviate those fears, the central bank has been buying more and more government debt -- it is up to 1.2 trillion yen ($10 billion) in long-term bonds a month. Many investors expect Mr. Muto and Mr. Iwata to press for yet more purchases.
Those purchases may help keep a lid on long-term rates, but they will do little or nothing to spur growth or break deflationary expectations, analysts said. 
Naming two deputies who favor more bond purchases "looks analogous to having the accelerator pressed to the floor while the gears are in neutral and the hand brake is on," said Richard Jerram, an economist at ING Baring Securities.

HEADLINE: Labor, Under the Gun, Meets to Plot Strategy 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb 24 

 BODY:
As the nation's union leaders gather at a luxury resort here for their annual winter meeting, there is no denying they are in a funk. 
 For many unions -- especially the steelworkers, machinists and airlines -- the weak economy has meant devastating layoffs as well as pressure for deep concessions. The Bush administration has thrown labor on the defensive time and again, from proposing to privatize hundreds of thousands of federal jobs to obtaining the power to exempt employees from union contracts in the new Department of Homeland Security. 
 There is also trouble within the house of labor. Union leaders are bickering over political strategy and whether to support a war in Iraq. The movement has been embarrassed by a federal investigation into the way several union presidents who sat on the board of Ullico, a union-owned insurance company, made hundreds of thousands of dollars in profits from trading the insurer's stock. 
Adding to the discomfort, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is holding the meeting at a hotel that is the focus of a Department of Labor investigation and lawsuit. The department has sued several officials from the plumbers union for using $800 million from its pension fund to build the 39-story seafront hotel, the Westin Diplomat Resort and Spa, which has a spa, 10 clay tennis courts and an 18-hole golf course.
"Unions are clearly in a defensive mode," said Richard W. Hurd, a labor relations professor at Cornell University. "Unionized operations have been hit disproportionately by layoffs. It's a tough period right now for labor."
Some labor leaders expect more bad news on Tuesday, when the Bureau of Labor Statistics is to release its annual report on union membership. Despite the efforts by John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, to persuade unions to organize more workers, many union officials expect the bureau to report that union membership dropped last year nationwide, largely because of layoffs at heavily unionized companies, like Boeing, United Airlines and Bethlehem Steel.
Alarmed by the loss of membership, some labor leaders are saying the A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting needs to focus on a single objective: figuring out ways to sign up more workers.
"We have not solved the organizing challenge that we have," said John Wilhelm, president of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, which has lost 20,000 members since the Sept. 11 attacks. "We have to devote far more resources to that task and have to be far more aggressive about it."
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials are set to announce this week that the federation's 65 labor unions organized 520,000 workers last year; privately, though, some labor leaders said they thought some of those unions had exaggerated their numbers. 
For labor to rebound, many labor experts say that more unions need to imitate the vigorous organizing efforts and heavy spending of the Service Employees International Union, which said it organized 135,000 workers last year, far more than any other union.
In a novel step, Mr. Wilhelm; James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters; and several other union leaders agreed today to set up a nonprofit foundation to help promote the right to organize. The new group, the National Rights at Work Committee, will make the case that aggressive anti-union tactics by employers have unfairly undercut workers' ability to join unions and unions' ability to organize. 
This week, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. also plans to release a poll of 1,602 adults that found that 66 percent of respondents approved of unions, and 22 percent disapproved, an approval rating that would be the highest in 35 years. 
Labor leaders want President Bush and Congress to support legislation making it easier for unions to organize, but that is unlikely considering the political climate. Indeed, a big debate within labor's ranks is whether the overall movement has been hurt or helped by the efforts of individual unions to cooperate with President Bush and to work out deals with the administration and Congressional Republicans.
Some labor leaders are questioning the wisdom of working with Mr. Bush since he pushed to weaken union protections for employees in the Homeland Security Department; to privatize the hundreds of thousands of federal jobs; and to enact new tax cuts that help the rich disproportionately.
"There was some belief on the part of unions that this administration was reaching out and was going to listen, but I'd say the doors are slamming pretty fast," said Andrew Stern, president of the service employees' union. 
Even the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union that President Bush has courted most vigorously, expressed dismay with recent administration moves. Bret Caldwell, the union's spokesman said, "The Teamsters union is certainly disappointed with some of the decisions that the Bush administration has made in recent months."
Noting the splits in the movement, Martin J. Maddaloni, president of the plumbers and pipefitters' union, faulted many unions that disagreed with President Bush's plans on issues like energy exploration in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. 
"The president's energy policy is a good one, and we should support it," he said. "It can create jobs."
As head of the union whose pension fund owns and built the Diplomat, Mr. Maddaloni will serve as the meeting's unofficial host. Many plumbers have criticized him for steering so much pension money into the hotel, arguing that the fund will never earn a good return on that investment. Indeed, in its suit, the Department of Labor says that the fund's trustees breached their fiduciary duties by investing so much.
But Mr. Maddaloni said: "It's a great investment. You remove money from the stock market, which hasn't done well, and you put it into real estate. The timing was perfect."
Some labor leaders have questioned the wisdom of holding the meeting at a hotel that is a target ofthe lawsuit. Officials noted that they reserved the Diplomat long before the lawsuit was brought.

HEADLINE: Daley Walks, Not Runs, Toward Chicago Election 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Tuesday is Election Day here in the nation's third-largest city. The ballots are printed. The polling machines are in place. Mayor Richard M. Daley has booked a ballroom at the Hilton for his victory party.
 The only thing missing is the campaign. 
 Mr. Daley, a 14-year incumbent inching toward his legendary father's 21-year tenure at Chicago's helm, has refused to debate his three opponents. After his 95-year-old mother died last Sunday, the mayor erased his entire schedule; he has made only two brief public appearances in the past 10 days. He declined to be interviewed as well.
The only glimpse of Mr. Daley is in television advertisements that seem more like a valentine to the city than an appeal for another term. The only reminders of the election are the banners throughout town on which aldermen pair their names with his, counting on coattails.
"It's a travesty -- it's totally disheartening," said Steve Edwards, host of "Eight-Forty-Eight," a public affairs program on radio station WBEZ. "If nothing else, campaigns, I would think, are supposed to be moments in which everyone can reflect on the state of the city today. When you don't have a robust campaign, you don't have a public conversation about the priorities."
The extraordinary lack of campaign activity in the mayor's race -- in which all the candidates are Democrats -- reflects the vacuum of political debate and dissent in recent years at City Hall. Votes on even controversial items are routinely 50 to 0 in line with the mayor's position. While his father, Richard J. Daley, ruled a political machine that traded patronage jobs for precinct turnout, this Mayor Daley has dangled local development and other neighborhood improvements as incentives. 
Helped by the economic boom of the 1990's, Mr. Daley is widely praised for improving Chicago's schools, beautifying its streetscape and bringing many large development projects to the city. But he has recently laid off 625 municipal workers and had to defend huge cost overruns at Millennium Park, a signature project downtown.
"I think he's infinitely more powerful than his father," said John Callaway, the longtime host of "Chicago Tonight," a public affairs television program. "The lack of opposition is probably the biggest impediment to his having an even better run. He needs to have his political and municipal judgmental muscles tested."
Vacancies have allowed Mr. Daley to appoint 19 of the current 50 aldermen; the others have him largely to thank for raising their salaries from $40,000 in 1989 to $98,000 by 2006. He has paired the loyalty of the dwindling white ethnic communities with support from lakefront liberals, middle-class blacks and the growing Hispanic neighborhoods to block any potential rainbow coalition from opposing him.
"Machiavelli said there's two ways to get devotion, fear and love -- some of them love him and some of them fear him," said Paul Green, a political scientist at Roosevelt University, noting the trend of City Council candidates' twinning their names with the mayor's on political paraphernalia. "It's sort of like putting lamb's blood over your door; you have to have Daley's support."
Some call it leadership by consensus; others, co-opting. In any case, the mayor has traded endorsements this year even with Helen Schiller, previously his most vocal critic on the City Council. With the results hardly in doubt, Tuesday is more a coronation than an election.
"This is a dictatorship, it's not a democracy," said Robert T. Starks, a political scientist at Northeastern Illinois University. 
Today, as the mayor huddled with far-flung relatives who had come to town for his mother's funeral, his main opponent, the Rev. Paul Jakes, shook hands amid the snow flurries at subway stops, then visited a high school, a college campus and a church. In the smelly basement of East-West University downtown, Mr. Jakes told a political science class how the Rev. Jesse Jackson, his son, Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., and former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, among others, had all declined to challenge the mayor.
"Not one elected official, not one businessperson, would step up to the plate," Mr. Jakes said, turning the dingy podium into a pulpit. "I said, 'Well, if you need someone and you want me to go, here I am.' "
Mr. Jakes criticized Mr. Daley's policies on subsidized housing and appointment of a man without a doctorate to run the school system. He denounced Chicago as a crime capital and questioned the accountability system in a city where 21 people were trampled to death last week in a nightclub that was supposed to have been closed by a court order. But his booming preacher's voice seemed to echo in the emptiness, with no television camera rolling. 
A few blocks away at Mr. Daley's re-election headquarters, six volunteers were scattered among 20 computer stations using software to dial phones and remind people that the polls would open in less than 18 hours. "It's the real McCoy," Deanna Shoss told one dubious voter. "It's the actual election for mayor. Glad we could call and remind you."
Greg Goldner, Mr. Daley's campaign manager, said volunteers had made 40,000 phone calls over the weekend and would call 35,000 numbers on Tuesday to get out the vote. And while Mr. Daley himself is on hiatus, his 24-member campaign staff has been dispatched to neighborhood coffees, Mr. Goldner said.
"We don't take it for granted," he added.
If gaining a majority is a foregone conclusion, Tuesday still brings important hurdles for Mr. Daley. His advisers hope he will top the 72 percent he received in the 1999 election. Perhaps even more important, they want a majority of African-American votes; the mayor won about 43 percent of the black vote last time, up from just 7 percent in 1989. 
But Jane M. Byrne, Chicago's mayor from 1979 to 1983, sees a more depressing trend in the numbers: turnout dropped from 48 percent in 1991 to 42 percent in 1995 and 1999, with 35 percent predicted for Tuesday. 
"The machine always likes it when there's not controversy; then they just sneak through," Ms. Byrne said. "We're probably one of the only places in the country that wants to hold an election in February, on purpose because of the weather."

U.S. Introduces Resolution As Endgame Starts on Iraq
The United States, Britain and Spain introduced a United Nations Security Council resolution saying that Iraq "failed to take the final opportunity" to disarm, beginning a diplomatic endgame that Bush administration officials predicted would lead either to Saddam Hussein's exile or to military action to disarm Iraq and topple his regime. SCIENCE TIMES F1-12

DNA's Midlife Crisis
This year, the genetic revolution that James D. Watson and Francis Crick ushered in with their discovery of the structure of DNA celebrates its 50th birthday. The molecule that for so long exemplified youthful bravado has become another aging, pot-bellied baby boomer. In the view of some biologists, nothing would better suit the DNA industry than a genuine midlife crisis, a realization that this may not, after all, be the fulcrum around which the Milky Way wheels. HEADLINE: Graft Aggravates Woes Plaguing Central America 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: GUATEMALA CITY 

 BODY:
Long a mainstay of politics and business in Central America, corruption has taken on new life under the region's fledgling democracies and is more pervasive and corrosive than at any time in recent memory, analysts and diplomats say.
 For the most vulnerable countries, like Guatemala, barely six years from civil war, the problem is making it more difficult to consolidate law and order and gain popular trust in government. 
 For the United States it is undermining the fight against drugs, contraband and illegal immigrants as politicians and former military officers who had been built up as cold war allies now trade on their influence to enrich themselves. 
In January, Washington "decertified" Guatemala as a cooperative partner in the antidrug effort, a step that jeopardized millions of dollars in foreign aid and further tarnished Guatemala's image with investors. 
"I think it the most corrupt country right now," said Manuel Orozco, Central America project director at the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy group in Washington.
The Guatemalan government, angered by the American decision, insists that the problem goes beyond drug trafficking -- and beyond Guatemala -- and that American officials have been inattentive to an issue that is nibbling away at efforts to generate trade and lift large swaths of the region out of poverty.
Indeed, Guatemala is hardly alone. Half of Central America's countries dwell in the bottom 20 percent of Transparency International's annual rankings of the most corrupt countries in which to conduct business.
In Honduras, millions of aid dollars sent for rebuilding efforts after Hurricane Mitch struck in 1998 have gone unaccounted for, while rural poverty and despair have increased.
Last year prosecutors in Nicaragua, one of the hemisphere's poorest countries, accused former President Arnoldo Aleman of stealing $100 million from the government. The shock felt by many Nicaraguans was compounded by the Nicaraguan Congress's slowness to lift the immunity that Mr. Aleman enjoyed as a legislator. He is now under house arrest awaiting trial.
In Panama, a country whose freewheeling economy has long been favored by those seeking to hide or channel illicit funds, corruption is nearly taken for granted.
Last year an opposition legislator, Carlos Afu, was accused by his own party of accepting $1.5 million for his vote to confirm two Supreme Court justices. He defended himself by appearing on television waving $6,000 in $100 bills that he said promoters had just paid him to approve their development project. The message: everyone here sells his vote.
Instead of being prosecuted as a confessed bribe taker, Mr. Afu, who now votes with the government, has been rewarded with a committee chairmanship. 
The Bush administration announced last year that it would make anticorruption efforts a condition for foreign aid increases. But the difficulty of withholding aid from governments in a poor region that has become a popular smuggling route was demonstrated when Washington waived penalties on national security grounds after it decertified Guatemala.
Guatemala presents a special challenge. By most measures it has not only the region's widest gap between rich and poor, but an everyday tolerance for corruption at almost all levels of government and business.
Carlos Gonzalez, a law student here, learned just how ingrained it had become when a police officer stopped him one night for no apparent reason, frisked him and asked about the cellphone he was carrying.
"He asked where the receipt was," Mr. Gonzalez recalled. "Of course, I didn't have it. So he told me the phone was stolen and was staying with him. Where can you go to complain about something like this -- to the police?"
Not exactly. Byron Barrientos, the former minister of governance who oversaw the police, is himself facing allegations of having embezzled as much as $13 million. Though no longer in office, he remains in government, as a member of Congress, joining some 20 other lawmakers embroiled in scandals.
"Corruption is a matter of double standard," Foreign Minister Edgar Gutierrez said in response to written questions. "Everyone points fingers, but few are willing to point fingers, combat and do away with corruption in their own profession or sector."
The big money, diplomats and human rights advocates say, is being made by a shadowy smuggling network of former military officers.
The group is a holdover from Guatemala's 36-year civil war with leftist guerrillas, when regional military commanders controlled lucrative businesses in illegal logging or amassed sprawling properties.
Now, as they adjust to the peace brought about by accords signed in December 1996, they are seeking other ways to secure their futures in retirement.
In addition, prosecutors say that about $100 million has been stolen by various high-ranking officials, some of whom have fled the country. Last year, in their frustration, American officials resorted to revoking numerous visas to block suspected criminals from doing business in or fleeing to the United States.
Among those whose visas were blocked was Francisco Ortega Menaldo, a former general whom American officials suspect of ties to drug trafficking and human rights abuses.
American officials increasingly suspect that security breaches are tipping off drug gangs to raids by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. One of the biggest scandals last year involved the disappearance of 1.6 tons of cocaine from police custody and the subsequent disbanding of the country's antinarcotics squad.
Even in cases in which arrests have been made, suspects often go free. "Basically, all the sectors of law enforcement, the judiciary, the Public Ministry and the police have all been either bought off, penetrated or intimidated," said one diplomat.
Prosecutors are investigating five men who were once among the country's highest-ranking army officers in connection with smuggling of drugs and people.
But prosecutors complain that they are fearful, intimidated and underbudgeted as they have been inundated by more than 2,400 corruption cases since 2000. Distrustful of even the police, they find themselves staking out suspects on their own.
Karen Fischer, the special prosecutor for corruption, suspects compliant judges of putting up judicial roadblocks to delay or derail some cases. Even at the bottom of the bureaucratic chain, prosecutors and others find that clerks demand bribes simply to move paperwork.
"You have to fight with the court to not release people," Ms. Fischer said. "You have to fight with the police to bring them in. The problem of corruption in Guatemala is so spread out."
Under growing pressure, the government has set up an anticorruption commission to look at issues of inefficiency and official impunity, which are of special interest to international donors and lenders who will be meeting in May to review Guatemala's progress.
"Corruption in Guatemala is a type of social pathology that should be analyzed by a sociologist or psychiatrist," said Elfidio Cano, a member of the panel. "It has become a culture that legitimizes itself."

HEADLINE: City-Sold Lots Stay Vacant, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Hundreds of vacant lots that the city has sold at auction since 1996 remain empty trash-strewn lots that blight neighborhoods in desperate need of more housing, according to a report released yesterday by a housing advocacy group.
 The report, by New York Acorn, found that in 10 neighborhoods with a great deal of vacant land, 66 percent of the vacant lots that the city has sold at public auction since 1996 remain vacant. The report, which was released at a City Hall news conference, called for a moratorium on future city land auctions. 
 Councilman James Sanders Jr., the chairman of the Council's Economic Development Committee, said that he supported the group's call to end the auctions.
"This highest-bidder system has led to speculation -- to land speculators, to people who are flipping land and just sitting on this land as we have a homeless problem that seems to skyrocket," he said.
The neighborhoods that the report studied because of their large number of vacant lots were Mott Haven, Hunts Point, Morrisania and Highbridge in the Bronx, Far Rockaway in Queens and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Bushwick, Crown Heights, Brownsville and East New York in Brooklyn. Councilman Charles Barron, who represents East New York, said, "Affordable housing has become an oxymoron in New York City."
City sales of vacant lots -- which accelerated in the 1990's in an effort to get more land on the tax rolls -- have declined in recent years, the report found. In 1999, the peak year, the city took in $100 million by selling vacant lots. Last year the city took in just $4.9 million. 
The Bloomberg administration, which outlined a plan in December to build thousands of new housing units for the city, is convening a task force to look at the sale of city-owned land, said Jennifer Falk, a mayoral spokeswoman. But the administration has no plans to stop the auctions, she said.

HEADLINE: Safe Therapy Is Found for High Blood-Clot Risk 

BYLINE:  By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
Low doses of a cheap blood-thinning drug can safely prevent dangerous blood clots in the veins of people who are prone to them, doctors reported yesterday, saying the findings should prompt an immediate change in treatment for high-risk patients.
 The drug, warfarin, also sold as Coumadin, has been in use since the 1950's and is available in generic form. 
 Until now, there has been no proven long-term therapy that is safe for high-risk patients. When a clot develops, people are usually given warfarin for three to six months, but then the drug is stopped, because it increases the risk of severe bleeding. Without warfarin, however, almost a third of the patients will form another clot within eight years. 
The new study has found that after a few months of standard treatment with full doses of warfarin, clots can be prevented with lower doses, about half of what is normally used to treat someone with a clot. The lower doses provide a safe middle ground, reducing the risk of more clots without increasing the risk of hemorrhage.
The study supporting the long-term use of small doses of warfarin is to be published April 10 in The New England Journal of Medicine but was released yesterday and posted on the journal's Web site (www.nejm.com ) because the findings have immediate implications for patients.
The study itself was halted ahead of schedule by its sponsor, the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, because a safety board found such a benefit to treatment that it would have been unethical to keep giving placebos to people in the control group.
"This really ought to change the standard of care overnight," said Dr. Paul Ridker, the first author of the study and director of the center for cardiovascular disease prevention at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. 
"For the first time we have a study demonstrating a safe and effective treatment to prevent the recurrence of this condition," said Dr. Yves Rosenberg, a medical officer at the national institute. He said doctors should offer the treatment to all patients at risk for clots.
Blood clots, known as deep vein thrombosis, are considered a major public health problem in the United States. Estimates of the incidence vary, doctors say, because blood clots often go undiagnosed, including many fatal ones. 
Dr. Rosenberg, a medical officer at the institute, said 250,000 to 500,000 Americans a year suffered from clots. Others suggest there are two million cases a year in the nation.
Half occur in surgical patients or people with cancer, other illnesses or trauma, and half occur for no known reason. 
People at highest risk for developing blood clots are those who have had them in the past. The clots form most commonly in the legs, but about half break loose and reach the lungs, a condition called pulmonary embolism, which can be fatal. Blood clots in the lungs kill at least 10,000 Americans a year, and perhaps as many as 40,000, Dr. Rosenberg said.
Some people can develop clots from sitting or lying still for too long, even from sitting in cramped airplane seats on long flights -- hence the name "economy class syndrome."
In recent years, the tendency to develop clots has been recognized as a chronic disease, sometimes due to hereditary blood disorders. 
The study included 508 patients at 52 hospitals in the United States, Canada and Switzerland who were at high risk because they had already had blood clots, for no known reason. They were followed for an average of 2.1 years, some as long as 4.3 years. Half got low doses of warfarin, and half got placebos. Of the 253 on placebos, 37 developed blood clots, as compared with only 14 of 255 on the drug. The risk reduction was 64 percent. 
The treatment was safe, the researchers said. Although more patients on warfarin had hemorrhages (five versus only two in the placebo group), the difference was not statistically significant. One patient had a stroke caused by a brain hemorrhage, but that person was in the placebo group, not on warfarin.
Dr. Ridker said he and his colleagues began the study in hope of finding a way to help patients who were living with the constant threat of forming dangerous blood clots.
"It's frightening," Dr. Ridker said. "We take care of a lot of these patients, they have these risk factors and don't know what to do. Patients are frustrated."
Dr. Ridker said he asked the National Institutes of Health to pay for the study because he assumed that drug companies, which underwrite many studies, would not be interested, since warfarin is generic and companies would not make money promoting it.
Dr. Ridker said: "I said to N.I.H., 'Look, what do we do with these patients? Maybe a low dose will make just enough change in the coagulation system to prevent these blood clots from coming back, and maybe it will be safe."'
In an editorial accompanying the study in the journal, Dr. Andrew I. Schafer of the University of Pennsylvania said the study findings meant it would be reasonable for doctors to give low-dose warfarin to patients at risk for clots. But he also noted that the advice might change in the future, as more studies were done and as new drugs became available.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: NUCLEAR STANDOFF; 
North Korea Tests a Missile as South Korea Prepares for a New President

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
North Korea, in a provocative reminder of the tense security situation on the Korean Peninsula, on Monday conducted its first missile launching test in three years, South Korea's Yonyap news agency said today.
 The move by North Korea appeared to be an attention-getting measure as a new South Korean president, who has vowed to be aggressive in reshaping his country's relationship with the United States, prepares to take office today. 
 The unidentified North Korean rocket was fired into the sea between Korea and Japan, but it landed in North Korean waters. North Korean missiles are considered to be highly accurate, and the move seemed carefully calibrated to draw attention without being highly provocative -- a flashing signal rather than a red light. In its last missile test, in 1998, North Korea launched a missile that flew over Japanese territory, setting off a crisis between the countries. 
Officials in Washington with access to American intelligence said they were not alarmed by the launching today, which they described as a test of a "short range tactical missile." It appeared to be an antiship missile, which would make the test far less threatening than the 1998 launching of the Taepodong long-range missile over Japan.
The missile in this test, American officials said, fell harmlessly into the Sea of Japan. "This is something that they test periodically," one official said, though it is not clear that North Korea has conducted such a launching for the past few years.
The Japanese foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, said today that Japan was examining the reports about the missile, Agence France-Presse reported. Japanese news reports said the missile was a surface-to-vessel short-range Silkworm, which has a maximum range of 60 miles.
North Korea's move came as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here on an East Asia tour dedicated in part to drum up support for Washington's call for multilateral talks with North Korea. 
The departing president, Kim Dae Jung, gave a farewell speech on Monday in which he issued an indirect but unmistakable rebuff to the United States. "More than anything, dialogue between North Korea and the United States is the important key to a solution," he said.
Mr. Kim's comments are a mere foretaste of the difficulties in store for American policy makers on the Korean Peninsula, where North Korea is proceeding to restart its nuclear energy program, in defiance of international arms control agreements, while South Korea, under its incoming leader, Roh Moo Hyun, vows to oppose either economic penalties or a military strike.
Mr. Powell will take more comfort from Mr. Kim's comments about the presence of 37,000 American troops in this country, under a bilateral alliance forged in 1953 at the end of the three-year Korean War. "Realistically, for the maintenance of peace on the Korean Peninsula, North-South reconciliation and the solid South Korea-U.S. security alliance must be continued," Mr. Kim said.
Anti-American sentiment has grown in South Korea over the last year, including large street protests this winter against the American troop presence here. Although he has distanced himself from those demonstrations, Mr. Roh has spoken frequently and with apparent conviction about the need to "rebalance" the alliance with the United States, an ally that he has complained has become inattentive and overbearing.
Although he has often contradicted himself on the issue, Mr. Roh has also made statements suggesting that South Korea must begin preparing to assume responsibility for its own defense. The statements come against a backdrop of policy statements about North Korea, including the formation of an economic community with North Korea, which American and Korean regional analysts say would create tremendous strains with a Bush administration that is intent on isolating North Korea.
"If the American policy is simply to wait for North Korea to make a huge mistake, there is no future for the alliance, and no future for the American position in East Asia," said a close foreign policy adviser to Mr. Roh.
Mr. Kim's farewell comments sounded almost like a corrective, both to this kind of thinking and to foreign critics who have blamed his strategy of rapprochement with North Korea, known as the sunshine policy, for deteriorating relations with Washington.
The sunshine policy seemed to receive a fatal blow nearly two years ago, when the newly inaugurated President Bush received Mr. Kim at the White House and expressed open skepticism about efforts to reach out to the North. Later, Mr. Bush included North Korea in his so-called axis of evil.
In the last year of Mr. Kim's presidency, his standing with the South Korean public has plummeted. Snowballing scandals involving his cabinet and entourage wiped out a hard-won reputation for probity.
Mr. Kim can take some consolation in the election of Mr. Roh, who has not only taken inspiration from sunshine policy in forming his own approach to North Korea, but also seems inclined toward clemency toward Mr. Kim.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls 

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The merchandise trade surplus in Japan contracted for the first time in 11 months as imports surged along with the rise in crude oil prices. 
The country's surplus stood at 105 billion yen ($890 million) in January, 42.8 percent lower than in January 2002. Exports grew 7.9 percent, but imports grew even faster, at 10.7 percent. The trade surplus with the United States, Japan's single largest trading partner, fell 8.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Two Agencies Shut Their Doors

BYLINE:  By Sean Mehegan 

 BODY:
Two agencies have closed because of the struggling economy, consolidation among clients and the losses of large accounts.
 One agency is Hampel/Stefanides in New York, which was shut by its parent, the Envoy Communications Group in Toronto, after 10 years in business. 
At one point recently, Hampel/Stefanides had 60 employees and billings estimated at $100 million, but it lost accounts like CDnow.com, Castrol Worldwide and National Discount Brokers. 
 Geoffrey Genovese, president at Envoy, which is trying to cut costs as revenue declines, confirmed a report of the closing this week in Adweek.
Larry Hampel and Dean Stefanides, founders and creative directors of Hampel/Stefanides, are joining the Tucker Partnership in New York, which is being renamed Tucker, Hampel, Stefanides & Partners. Mr. Hampel, Mr. Stefanides and William Tucker, managing director at Tucker, said they expected to attract former clients of Hampel/Stefanides like Aer Lingus, BASF and Steve Madden. The three men all worked together at a former agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York.
Another agency that closed is HDC in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., formerly Harris Drury Cohen, which had been in business since 1980. As recently as 1999, the agency had billings estimated at $100 million and was trying to become a powerful force in South Florida advertising. But it lost several senior executives, as well as accounts like the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau and Sea-Doo.
Some remaining accounts and employees of HDC are being absorbed by Zimmerman & Partners Advertising in Fort Lauderdale, part of the Omnicom Group. Michael Goldberg, the chief executive at HDC, was named to the new post of chief marketing officer at Zimmerman.

Analyst Reduces Advertising Forecast

BYLINE:  By Sean Mehegan 

 BODY:
The analyst who follows Madison Avenue for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, Lauren Rich Fine, has cut her estimates for advertising spending in 2003.
 In a report, Ms. 
Fine lowered her estimate of growth in American ad spending compared with 2002 to 3.7 percent from 4 percent. She also lowered her estimate of global growth to 2.7 percent from 3 percent.  Ms. Fine also offered her initial forecasts for ad spending in 2004, predicting an increase from 2003 of 6 percent in the United States and 5 percent worldwide.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
STEWART, A CEMETERY OPERATOR, CUTS 2003 FORECAST

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Stewart Enterprises Inc., a leading operator of cemeteries and funeral homes, cut its 2003 forecast after fiscal first-quarter net income fell. The recession has made it harder for Stewart to sell prepaid funeral products and services, and yields from the company's trust funds are leaner amid slumping financial markets. 
First-quarter profit was also hurt by an increase in cremations, which are less profitable than traditional burials. The company, which is based in Metairie, La., lowered its 2003 earnings forecast to 30 cents to 35 cents a share, from 40 cents to 43 cents. Net income in the first quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to 9 cents a share, based on a preliminary review, the company said. Stewart's stock fell $1.19, or 25 percent, to $3.60 a share.

HEADLINE: 3 Large Retail Chains Report Snow Significantly Hurt Sales 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Three major retailers -- Federated Department Stores, J. C. Penney and Wal-Mart Stores -- said yesterday that February sales at stores open at least a year slowed after a snowstorm kept many people at home on Washington's Birthday. 
 Federated, the parent of Macy's, said sales at stores open at least a year would decline as much as 8.5 percent in February, more than its previous forecast for a drop of up to 5 percent. 
 J. C. Penney said February sales at its department stores fell as much as 3 percent, and Wal-Mart said sales were near the low end of its estimate for a gain of 2 to 4 percent. 
Stores from Virginia to New Hampshire closed after as much as 30 inches of snow fell over the Washington's Birthday weekend, with sales on the Monday dropping more than half from year-earlier levels. 
Shares in Federated dropped 76 cents, to $24.82; Wal-Mart declined $1.26, to $47.64; J. C. Penney fell 95 cents, to $19.39.
Sales on Washington's Birthday fell 55 percent from a year earlier in the Northeast, according to ShopperTrak RCT, which tracks data from more than 30,000 retailers. Sales had been within expectations before the snowstorm, the retailers said. 
 February sales at stores open at least a year are expected to rise 0.5 percent, said Mark Niemira, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi. He reduced his estimate last week after forecasting an increase of as much as 2 percent at the beginning of the month. 
A spokesman for Wal-Mart, Tom Williams, said sales returned to normal levels by last Wednesday. Results were helped by sales of coats, shovels and food, he said. Wal-Mart closed stores in Washington and at least eight states last Monday. 
Macy's East, Federated's largest division, extended its holiday discounts through Sunday to pick up some lost sales after closing about 30 of about 110 stores last Monday, a spokeswoman for Macy's East, Elina Kazan, said. The east division accounts for about a third of sales at Federated, which also operates Bloomingdale's and Lazarus stores. 
J. C. Penney also closed stores in the Northeast last Monday. Sales at stores in the western United States rose for the week, J. C. Penney said. 
Sales at Penney's Eckerd drugstore division were unchanged, compared with expectations for a slight gain. Catalog and Internet sales declined about 12 percent, less than a forecast for a 20 percent drop.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo; 
The President's Tax Cut and Its Unspoken Numbers

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
The statistics that President Bush and his allies use to promote his tax-cut plan are accurate, but many of them present only part of the picture.
 For instance, in a speech in Georgia last week, the president asserted that under his proposal, 92 million Americans would receive an average tax reduction of $1,083 and that the economy would improve so much that 1.4 million new jobs would be created by the end of 2004. 
 No one disputes the size of the average tax reduction, and the jobs figure is based on the estimate of a prominent private economic forecasting firm. 
But this is what the president did not say: Half of all income-tax payers would have their taxes cut by less than $100; 78 percent would get reductions of less than $1,000. And the firm that the White House relied on to predict the initial job growth also forecast that the plan could hurt the economy over the long run. 
The average tax cut (the total amount of revenue lost divided by the total number of tax returns) is over $1,000 because a few rich taxpayers would get such large reductions. For households with incomes over $200,000, the average cut would be $12,496, and the average for those with incomes over $1 million would be $90,222.
But the cut for those with incomes of $40,000 to $50,000, according to calculations by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, would typically be $380. For those with incomes of $50,000 to $75,000, it would be $553.
The president's jobs figure was based on a preliminary analysis by Macroeconomic Advisers, of St. Louis. The firm, to whose services the White House subscribes, issued projections in January concluding that by raising disposable income, bolstering stock values and reducing the cost of capital, the president's program would lead to 1.365 million new jobs by the end of next year.
But the White House has never mentioned the caution in the second paragraph of the firm's report. The forecasters predicted that if the tax cuts were not offset within a few years by reductions in government spending, interest rates would rise, private investment would be crowded out, and the economy would actually be worse than if there had been no tax changes.
The president has not proposed spending reductions that would offset the tax cuts. To the contrary, the administration has argued that the budget deficits resulting from the cuts would be too small to harm the economy.
Another argument that administration officials make regularly is that under the president's plan, the wealthy would bear a larger share of the nation's tax burden than they do now. A table released last month by the Treasury's office of tax analysis showed that people with incomes over $100,000 would see their share of all income taxes rise to 73.3 percent from the current 72.4 percent.
At the same time, the table showed, taxpayers with incomes of $30,000 to $40,000 would get a 20.1 percent reduction in income taxes, and those earning $40,000 to $50,000 would get a 14.1 percent cut. 
The problem with figures like those is that a large percentage of a small amount of money may be less important to a low- or middle-income family's lifestyle than a small percentage of a large amount of money would be to a rich family. For example, a $50 tax cut would be a 50 percent reduction for a household that owed only $100 in taxes to start with, but that small amount of money would not significantly improve the family's well-being.
A better measure may be the increase in after-tax income, or take-home pay, that would result from tax cuts. According to data from the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation, the tax reduction of $380 for a family with an income of $45,000 would amount to less than 1 percent of the household's after-tax income. But the $12,496 tax cut received by a family with an income of $525,000 would mean a 3 percent increase in money left after taxes.
The president and his advisers also offer a variety of incomplete statistics to bolster their proposal to eliminate the taxes on most stock dividends.
Among the points they make are that more than half of all taxable dividends are paid to people 65 and older, that their average saving from eliminating the tax on dividends would be $936, that 60 percent of people receiving dividends have incomes of $75,000 or less and that up to 60 percent of corporate profits are lost to income taxes paid by either the companies or the stockholders. 
All that is true, but here is a more complete picture:
Only slightly more than one-quarter of Americans 65 and older receive dividends. Two-thirds of the dividends the elderly receive are paid to the 9 percent of all elderly who have incomes over $100,000.
The Tax Policy Center at the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute calculated that the average tax cut from the dividend exclusion would be $29 for those with incomes of $30,000 to $40,000 and $51 for taxpayers with incomes of $40,000 to $50,000.
On the other hand, the two-tenths of 1 percent of tax filers with incomes over $1 million (who have 13 percent of all income) receive 21 percent of all dividends, and the Tax Policy Center figured that their average tax reduction from the dividend exclusion would be $27,701. For taxpayers with incomes of $200,000 to $500,000, the typical tax cut from the exclusion was calculated at $1,766.
In instances where both the corporation and the shareholder are paying taxes at the maximum rate, it is possible, as the administration maintains, for 60 percent of the profits to be taxed away. But calculations based on I.R.S. data and performed by Robert S. McIntyre of the nonpartisan Citizens for Tax Justice show that on average, only 19 percent of corporate profits are paid in taxes by companies and shareholders combined. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 1, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A Washington Memo article on Tuesday about the Bush administration's use of statistics to promote its tax-cut plans referred imprecisely to the source it used to project that the cuts would create 1.4 million jobs by the end of next year. While the administration did take into account a preliminary analysis by the St. Louis forecasting firm of Macroeconomic Advisers, the White House officially cited the work of its own Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Blair Outlines Plans to Slash Emissions Over 50 Years 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair laid out ambitious plans today to fight global warming by cutting carbon dioxide emissions in Britain by 60 percent in the next five decades and gently criticized President Bush for failing to do more to combat the damaging effects of greenhouse gases.
 Framing the issue of global warming as one of national security, Mr. Blair said the United States was wrong to back out of the Kyoto Protocol of 1997, which sought to minimize noxious carbon dioxide fumes. The Bush administration drew the ire of a number of industrialized nations when it backed out of the treaty, arguing that compliance would cost American businesses too much money. 
 But today, in clear disagreement with Britain's foreign policy ally, Mr. Blair said economic growth and environmental awareness can coexist.
"Even the Kyoto targets have proved controversial with some countries, notably America," Mr. Blair said at a conference on sustainable development here. "Many see it as a threat to the pursuit of economic growth. I believe this needn't be the case. If we harness new technology, the evidence is mounting that we can achieve a target of 60 percent, and at reasonable cost."
The prime minister added, "There will be no genuine security if the planet is ravaged by climate change."
Mr. Blair's proposals on global warming would far exceed the standards of the Kyoto treaty, which would require countries to slash greenhouse gas emissions to below 1990 levels by 2012. That would amount to a 2 percent cut, Mr. Blair said. In his plan, Britain would cut the carbon dioxide it releases into the atmosphere by 60 percent by 2050.
Carbon emissions, the noxious fumes produced by cars and factories, have been cited as causes for global warming. The gradual warming of the earth's temperatures has unleashed catastrophic floods and storms around the world, causing enormous, irreparable damage, Mr. Blair said.
He said he and the Swedish prime minister, Goeran Persson, had written to Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece, whose country holds the rotating European Union presidency, calling on other European countries to adopt the 60 percent goal.
"Whilst Kyoto was an enormous achievement, it is simply not enough," Mr. Blair told the audience.
The government also promised hundreds of millions of dollars to make Britain more energy efficient and to spur the use of renewable power sources like wind and waves. It also plans to create an exchange system by 2005, similar to one in the United States, that will allow companies that produce too much carbon dioxide to buy credits from companies that fall below the threshold.
The plan, laid out in a white paper, steps away from any increase in the use of nuclear power to offset Britain's oil consumption -- a contentious issue -- but it does not rule out the construction of more nuclear plants.
Environmentalists praised Mr. Blair's plans today and said they hoped he would not stray from his goals of conserving energy and reducing greenhouse gases.
Britain, which produces oil and natural gas from fields in the North and Irish seas, will become a net importer of gas by about 2006 and oil by 2010 as its supplies dwindle, the white paper stated.
Mr. Blair said he would continue to press the United States and other industrialized countries to intensify their efforts to fight global warming.
President Bush sparked a furor among the signers of the Kyoto Protocol when his administration announced that it would not ratify the agreement, which it saw as unworkable for American companies. Instead, the administration sought voluntary commitments from companies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
"We will continue to make the case to the U.S. and to others that climate change is a serious threat that we must address together as an international community," he said. "We in Britain have shown that it is possible to break the relationship between economic growth and ever rising pollution." 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 25 about Britain's plans to fight global warming by reducing carbon dioxide emissions characterized the gas incorrectly. It is not noxious except in extremely high concentrations.

HEADLINE: Governors Get Sympathy From Bush but No More Money 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
President Bush told governors today that he would not support proposals to provide new fiscal assistance to states struggling with what governors say is the worst financial problems since World War II.
 The governors heard the grim message in a visit to the White House on the third day of the annual winter meeting of the National Governors Association. 
 Governors of both parties said that while Mr. Bush understood their problems, he offered no money. 
"The president did not offer additional fiscal assistance," said Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado, chairman of the Republican Governors Association.
Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania, a Democrat, said: "President Bush was honest and frank. He told us there's no more money for anything. He said essentially, 'You're on your own.' "
The meeting has exposed a partisan rift within the governors association, which normally operates by consensus. Democratic governors said Mr. Bush had ignored the states' fiscal problems, and they asserted that his tax proposals could exacerbate those problems. Republicans defended Mr. Bush and said governors should not always be begging for more federal aid.
In an effort to patch up their differences, the governors agreed on a statement urging the federal government to pay more of the cost of federal mandates in education, Medicaid and domestic security. They did not request a specific amount of money, though the proposal could mean a significant increase.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Bush told the governors that he wanted to work with them to improve education, health care and domestic security. He deflected calls for more money by restating his support for tax cuts as a way to stimulate the economy, create jobs and increase revenue for the federal government and the states.
"Since the economy is not as good as we would like it to be, we ought to accelerate the tax relief" adopted in 2001, Mr. Bush said. Eliminating the taxation of most stock dividends "will be stimulative in the sense that it gets $20 billion into our economy this year," Mr. Bush said, adding that "it helps capital formation," which in turn enables entrepreneurs to hire more people.
Mr. Bush, a former governor of Texas, said the federal government had fiscal problems of its own and could not bail out the states.
"We've got an issue with our own budget, and you've got issues with your budgets," Mr. Bush said. "We can talk about that. Our budget is in a deficit. It's because we went through a recession and we're at war."
Gov. James E. Doyle of Wisconsin, a Democrat, gave this account of the White House meeting: "There was a lot of talk about giving states more flexibility, but I did not hear anybody say there was more money coming."
Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, a Republican, said, "You can't just keep printing money."
White House budget documents, issued three weeks ago, show that federal grants to state and local governments are expected to rise 9 percent this year, to $384 billion.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, received a mixed reaction today when he asked the governors to support sweeping changes in Medicaid, the federal-state program for 45 million low-income people.
Under the administration's proposal, states would still have to cover most welfare recipients and poor children, but would receive vast new power to alter or eliminate benefits and eligibility for about 15 million other Medicaid recipients, including many who are elderly or disabled.
"You have complete discretion" over those optional beneficiaries, Mr. Thompson told the governors. 
Referring to the Bush proposal, Mr. Thompson said, "It's a program set up for governors." Moreover, he said: "You would not have to match dollar for dollar the federal government's share. This is a net saving to every state."
Governors of both parties like the prospect of having more control over Medicaid costs, one of the fastest-growing items in state budgets. But they said they were worried that the Bush proposal could eventually cap the federal contribution to state Medicaid programs.
The National Governors Association decided today to establish a bipartisan committee of eight governors to negotiate with the administration and Congress on changes that could be made in Medicaid this year.
"It's vitally important to move very quickly," Mr. Thompson said.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, expressed reservations about the Bush proposal. "The federal government would give you more money in the first seven years, but take it back in the next three years," Mr. Breaux told the governors.
Mr. Breaux urged the governors to think carefully about the hardship that could result in the final three years. "You will have drastic slashing of optional programs," Mr. Breaux said, noting that prescription drugs were an optional benefit that could be cut under the president's proposal. 
Mr. Thompson said the federal government would still provide "an open checkbook" to the states for people whom the states are required to cover. But he made no guarantees for the other recipients. 
Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, a Republican, said the president's Medicaid proposal was "very attractive because it enables us to get a handle on Medicaid growth and costs."
But Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said that under the Bush proposal "much of the financial risk could be transferred from the federal government to the states," and he said that states would face "some great big cuts at the tail end" of the 10-year period.
Mr. Dingell said he favored a temporary increase in the federal share of Medicaid, as proposed by Senators Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, and John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia.
Mr. Thompson has rejected that proposal, saying it would give states a license to reduce their own Medicaid spending.

HEADLINE: Threats, Promises And Lies 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
So it seems that Turkey wasn't really haggling about the price, it just wouldn't accept payment by check or credit card. In return for support of an Iraq invasion, Turkey wanted -- and got -- immediate aid, cash on the barrelhead, rather than mere assurances about future help. You'd almost think President Bush had a credibility problem.
 And he does. 
 The funny thing is that this administration sets great store by credibility. As the justifications for invading Iraq come and go -- Saddam is developing nuclear weapons; no, but he's in league with Osama; no, but he's really evil -- the case for war has come increasingly to rest on credibility. You see, say the hawks, we've already put our soldiers in position, so we must attack or the world won't take us seriously. 
But credibility isn't just about punishing people who cross you. It's also about honoring promises, and telling the truth. And those are areas where the Bush administration has problems.
Consider the astonishing fact that Vicente Fox, president of Mexico, appears unwilling to cast his U.N. Security Council vote in America's favor. Given Mexico's close economic ties to the United States, and Mr. Fox's onetime personal relationship with Mr. Bush, Mexico should have been more or less automatically in America's column. But the Mexican president feels betrayed. He took the politically risky step of aligning himself closely with Mr. Bush -- a boost to Republican efforts to woo Hispanic voters -- in return for promised reforms that would legalize the status of undocumented immigrants. The administration never acted on those reforms, and Mr. Fox is in no mood to do Mr. Bush any more favors. 
Mr. Fox is not alone. In fact, I can't think of anyone other than the hard right and corporate lobbyists who has done a deal with Mr. Bush and not come away feeling betrayed. New York's elected representatives stood side by side with him a few days after Sept. 11 in return for a promise of generous aid. A few months later, as they started to question the administration's commitment, the budget director, Mitch Daniels, accused them of "money-grubbing games." Firefighters and policemen applauded Mr. Bush's promise, more than a year ago, of $3.5 billion for "first responders"; so far, not a penny has been delivered.
These days, whenever Mr. Bush makes a promise -- like his new program to fight AIDS in Africa -- experienced Bushologists ask, "O.K., that's the bait, where's the switch?" (Answer: Much of the money will be diverted from other aid programs, such as malaria control.)
Then there's the honesty thing.
Mr. Bush's mendacity on economic matters was obvious even during the 2000 election. But lately it has reached almost pathological levels. Last week Mr. Bush -- who has been having a hard time getting reputable economists to endorse his economic plan -- claimed an endorsement from the latest Blue Chip survey of business economists. "I don't know what he was citing," declared the puzzled author of that report, which said no such thing.
What Americans may not fully appreciate is the extent to which similarly unfounded claims have, in the eyes of much of the world, discredited the administration's foreign policy. Whatever the real merits of the case against Iraq, again and again the administration has cited evidence that turns out to be misleading or worthless -- "garbage after garbage after garbage," according to one U.N. official.
Despite his decline in the polls, Mr. Bush hasn't fully exhausted his reservoir of trust in this country. People still remember the stirring image of the president standing amid the rubble of the World Trade Center, his arm around a fireman's shoulders -- and our ever-deferential, protective media haven't said much about the broken promises that followed. But the rest of the world simply doesn't trust Mr. Bush either to honor his promises or to tell the truth.
Can we run a foreign policy in the absence of trust? The administration apparently thinks it can use threats as a substitute. Officials have said that they expect undecided Security Council members to come around out of fear of being on the "wrong" side. And Mr. Bush may yet get the U.N. to acquiesce, grudgingly, in his war. 
But even if he does, we shouldn't delude ourselves: whatever credibility we may gain by invading Iraq is small recompense for the trust we have lost around the world.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Provincial Upstarts Who Changed the World

BYLINE:  By BENSON BOBRICK; Benson Bobrick is the author of "Angel in the Whirlwind: The Triumph of the American Revolution," among other books.

 BODY:
TO BEGIN THE WORLD ANEW
The Genius and Ambiguities of the American Founders
By Bernard Bailyn
Illustrated.
185 pages. Knopf. $26.
 Every once in a while a book of history comes along that seems to perfectly inhabit its own sphere. This is such a book. It is small, made up of five topical essays of modest length; but within its brief compass it delineates the world of the founding fathers with equatorial poise, clarity and grace. 
 Early American history is Bernard Bailyn's choice domain, and for the past 40 years or so no one has been a better guide to the riches it can yield. His previous work has earned him two Pulitzer Prizes and a National Book Award, among other honors. In this new book, "To Begin the World Anew," he seems to have distilled the thought of a lifetime into a group of unimpeachable assessments that take the measure of each subject with a just and proportionate eye. 
Each subject is one that counts. He looks at the relatively "provincial" world of the founders, which allowed the freshness of their ideas to flourish unchoked by the assumptions of Old World salons; at the inner coherence of Thomas Jefferson's mercurial career; at Benjamin Franklin's succes d'estime in Paris as part of the American delegation; the nature and lasting force of the Federalist Papers; and the immediate impact of the new American constitutional ideas on political thought throughout Europe and the Western Hemisphere.
"The founders of the American nation," Mr. Bailyn writes, "were one of the most creative groups in modern history. . . . Again and again they were warned of the folly of defying the received traditions, the sheer unlikelihood that they, obscure people on the outer borderlands of European civilization, knew better than the established authorities that ruled them; that they could successfully create something freer, ultimately more enduring than what was then known in the centers of metropolitan life." 
The assessment of Jefferson is particularly fine, if only because he has suffered of late by comparison with John Adams, whom Mr. Bailyn also esteems. Jefferson (like Adams) had notable faults, and these are not denied. But the positive impact of his gigantic presence is also well affirmed: Beyond his contribution to the Declaration of Independence (a committee effort, true, but closely based on his draft), we are reminded of his great state paper, the Act for Establishing Religious Freedom, from which our traditions of free worship in some measure flow; of his foremost role in proposing the Bill of Rights ("what the people are entitled to against every government on earth"); of his Bill for the More General Diffusion of Knowledge, in support of public education ("Enlighten the people generally, and tyranny and oppressions of body and mind will vanish like evil spirits at the dawn of day"), and other fundamental contributions to American life. The sweeping achievements of his two terms as president hardly bear dispute.
Jefferson's early anti-Federalist stance, moreover (for which he has often been scourged), was rooted in a principled fear of abuses by centralized power, while his opposition to Alexander Hamilton's scheme for economic development (as tied to the Bank of the United States) was fairly based on a conviction that monied interests might ultimately corrupt the American political system, as they had that of England under George II.
Though by turns a principled moralist, crafty opportunist, apostle of the Enlightenment, and firebrand of revolutionary zeal, Jefferson re-emerges here in sum as a truly great man; as one, in truth, who tried to keep the promise of the Revolution going and whose apparent gyrations revolved around his core "romantic vision" of a life that only free institutions could secure.
"More than any other of the Revolution's original leaders," Mr. Bailyn writes, "Jefferson explored the ambiguities of freedom." For that he paid a heavy price. Obliged to assume a hundred roles, in the end "he left a legacy of compromise and incompleteness which his critics would forever assail." 
Jefferson was one kind of "tempered idealist." Franklin another. In Franklin, Mr. Bailyn finds the realism and idealism of American diplomacy deftly blended and personified. No one was more competent at holding the two together, or more curious in projecting the changing public image of himself as that of the new American man. Mr. Bailyn looks at his protean incarnations -- as a businessman, scientist, rustic diplomat and thinker -- each memorably rendered in a series of timely portraits, some painted, some carved or in sculptured form.
Ultimately, his cumulative persona in the portraiture becomes endowed with a mythological largeness that seems to fuse his American image with that of the enlightened hopes of "humanity itself." This is the famous portrait by Joseph Duplessis, which "radiates experience, wisdom, patience,tolerance and a world-weariness beyond all cleverness and guile. One sees, and feels, a dignified presence, a calm, dispassionate, rich personality unconstrained by nationality, occupation or rank." Franklin favored it above all others, and declined to sit for other portraits after it was done.
As the type and epitome of the shrewd but visionary sage, Franklin helped craft the Franco-American alliance that made British defeat in the war all but certain. A decade later, on the home front, the founders, in a similar spirit, forged the Constitution into a document that gave their ideals a practicable form. Rejecting the popular theory (as advanced by Thomas Paine in "Common Sense") "that simplicity in government was a virtue, complexity an unmitigated evil," they wrestled over the matter like Jacob with the angel until at last they were able to persuade one another and themselves that the rights and freedoms of the individual could be secured only by an intricate balance of powers within a constitutional frame. Even Jefferson came to accept the notion (then novel) that sovereignty could be divided, and power "created and constrained at the same time." In this way, by subtle reformation and amendment, the great document became a "bill of powers and a bill of rights combined." 
Some of the arguments involved in its creation are preserved in the Federalist Papers, a series of polemical essays written in a white heat during the ratification process. Though plainly partisan, flung out like ephemeral flares, these papers have since acquired their monumental status as a gloss on the intentions of the founders, with an authority just below that of the Constitution itself. Mr. Bailyn's discussion of their dialectic is intellectually thrilling as he shows how some of the more difficult issues were resolved. 
After the Constitution was approved, the new ideas it contained caught fire and spread. Within a generation or two, they had "inspired the march toward radical social goals" in England, helped frame the constitutional debate in revolutionary France, influenced the form of government other European countries would adopt, and encouraged the development of democracy in Latin America, though the story there remains one of shattered hopes.
This is a gem of a book, rich in understanding, well wrought within its scale. Though Mr. Bailyn is fond of opposing the "metropolitan" to the "provincial" as perennial opposites in thought and style, such pairings, of course, borrow truth from each other's strength. That might be said of Mr. Bailyn's own pages, which offer a thoroughly urbane account of the provincial wellsprings of our nation's life.
