HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ISTANBUL; 
Turkish Parliament Is Asked to Approve U.S. Troops

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
Turkey's government asked Parliament today to allow as many as 62,000 American troops into the country for up to six months for an attack on Iraq, Turkish officials said.
 The resolution, approved by the Turkish cabinet on Monday, would also grant the Americans permission to base up to 255 airplanes and 65 helicopters in the country for use against Iraq, according to Anatolia, the state-run news agency. 
 The measure also authorizes the dispatchof Turkish troops into northern Iraq, although it specifies no numbers. The move is being bitterly resisted by leaders of Iraq's Kurds, who fear Turkish designs to dominate the region in a post-Saddam Hussein Iraq. 
Deputy Prime Minister Mehmet Ali Sahin, who confirmed the American troop numbers, did not say when the Parliament would vote on the resolution.
But there were growing signs of a revolt today within the majority Justice and Development Party over allowing Turkey to be used as a base for an American invasion. And several opposition deputies with the Turkish Republican People's Party attended a Parliament session wearing white ribbons on their lapels as a sign of opposition to war.
The figures in the resolution are the most specific yet released detailing the size of the force envisioned by the Americans for a northern front. Some 80 American ships carrying equipment for the Fourth Infantry Division are floating off the Turkish coast, idling in the water until a deal is done.
Turkish officials have already allowed some ships to begin unloading heavy equipment. In recent discussions, American officials have spoken of a force of around 40,000 troops and support personnel. 
Asked about the Turkish figures, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld declined today to say whether they reflected the size of the force envisioned by the Americans. 
In the event of war, American officials want to use Turkey as a staging ground for an attack across Iraq's northern frontier, hoping it would comprise the northern end of a two-pronged assault on Baghdad. 
Turkish officials said they would wait until a final agreement was reached with the Americans on all aspects of the operation before putting the resolution to a vote. Some senior officials predicted a vote could come Thursday.
In exchange for granting access, Turkey's leaders have been seeking billions of dollars in economic aid to cushion against the likely economic shocks of war. In addition, the Turks seek American approval for a plan to send thousands of Turkish troops into northern Iraq to prevent the establishment of a Kurdish state. 
The negotiations between the Turks and the Americans continued, with one senior American official, Marisa Lino, negotiating with Turkish officials until 7 a.m. today. Robert Pearson, the American ambassador, left the Turkish Ministry at 2 a.m., officials said. Both resumed negotiations in the afternoon.
Ertugrul Yalcinbayir, one of three deputy prime ministers, indicated today that he would oppose granting access to the American troops. "If it is not approved, democracy would be strengthened," Mr. Yalcinbayir said.
He did not state explicitly how he intended to vote. 
Mr. Yalcinbayir's remarks followed the meeting of the Turkish cabinet Monday, when Prime Minister Abdullah Gul ran into vigorous opposition from his closest supporters over the proposed agreement with the Americans.
The opposition within the cabinet was one reason why the parliamentary vote was not scheduled today, officials said. 
Polls here show that Turkish public opinion is running strongly against a war, but Turkish officials say the pressure from the Americans has been unrelenting.
One senior member of the Turkish government said today that members of the Justice and Development Party were excoriated by their local constituents when they returned home for the recent Muslim holiday of Kurban Bayram.
The members of Parliament were reminded, this government official said, of how staunchly the Turks opposed their country's involvement in a war with Iraq. 
"They had a very tough time, I can tell you," said the Turkish official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "All the people attacked them. The feeling is very negative."
However, another senior Turkish official, who also spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the members of the Justice and Development Party would almost certainly do as they were told to do by the party leaders. He cautioned, however, that it was still unclear if the leadership and, particularly, the party leader, Tayyip Erdogan, were ready to endorse an agreement with Americans.
"One thing Tayyip Erdogan cannot do very well is say he believes in something he doesn't believe in," the Turkish official said. "If he goes on television when this is over and tells the Turkish people that he was unwilling to sell their dignity and independence, they'll back him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Turkish deputies wore white ribbons at a Parliament session in Ankara yesterday to signal their opposition to a United States-led war on Iraq. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
A War of Succession With 70's Soul

BYLINE:  By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
SOUL CIRCUS
By George P. Pelecanos
341 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
 It's no great feat to begin a new mystery right where the last one in the series left off. What is harder -- and what George P. Pelecanos does so easily in his latest, "Soul Circus" -- is to bring established characters back to such a warm welcome. 
 The central figure in this author's most recent books is Derek Strange, a Washington private detective in his 50's whose taste for smooth, tender, optimistic soul records of the 1970's is as emphatic as his moral code. Derek on the job embodies the spirit of the music he loves. To the sounds of the O'Jays and the Chi-Lites and Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes, he keeps his considerable cool and sustains faith in the kind of Love Train that could make this a better world.
But the world of "Soul Circus" needs a lot more than music to improve it. Once again Mr. Pelecanos zeroes in on reckless gangsters in Washington's predominantly black districts, like Anacostia, which "was the most beautiful section of town and also the ugliest, often at the same time." And with the same kind of narrative advocacy that John Grisham brings to tort reform in his latest hit, Mr. Pelecanos looks across the state line into "Mer-land" and sees where trigger-happy Washington toughs are getting their guns.
"Soul Circus," which thanks three Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms employees and a clergyman in its acknowledgments, describes the gangland power vacuum created by the arrest of Granville Oliver at the end of its predecessor, "Hell to Pay." Oliver's incarceration has left all manner of drug dealers and hangers-on jockeying for position and aligning themselves with new power brokers. And when the players in this story choose to stake out turf and assert their manhood, guns are an essential part of their transactions.
One of the new book's principals is Ulysses Foreman, a former cop with a lucrative new gun-dealing business. He now lives within a mile of Anacostia in a fairly rural setting. "You could even hear crickets chirping on summer nights," the book reports, "though those sounds were sometimes mixed with the occasional crack of gunshots riding up from Southeast, if the wind was right." It is to this book's credit that Ulysses is a vital, entertaining figure as well as a symptom of social ills.
For all the weapons floating through "Soul Circus" -- in onescene, Mr. Pelecanos simply describes how a criminal drives a young woman with no prior convictions to Maryland and has her buy him a gun, because she can pass the legally required background check -- this is not a book built on violence. Instead, Mr. Pelecanos once again looks for the roots of angry, bullying behavior and examines them through the knowing eyes of Derek Strange.
Like the novels of Richard Price, whose influence is evident here, "Soul Circus" is both tragedy and thriller, especially as it describes the all but accidental casualties of urban warfare. Much of the trouble in this book is kicked off by the insecurities of a little guy ("Boy looked like a water rat ain't had nothin' to eat for, like, forever") filled with pent-up resentment and trampled pride.
Meanwhile, Mr. Pelecanos continues to display a sharp eye for detail and a terrific ear for street dialogue. ("Two of my boys just got deaded by one of your guns; you know this.") He further culminates an Elmore Leonardesque wry economy and a lilting way with back-and-forth banter, never more so than when Strange hits the streets with his younger white partner, Terry Quinn. (Terry is so white, at least by Derek's standards, that he has sex to the music of Neil Young.)
"Careful, man," Quinn says, as Derek goes into musical raptures while driving. "You keep shutting your eyes when you're gettin' all soulful like that, you're gonna get us killed." Derek replies that he doesn't need to look because he can drive from memory.
Derek turns even more reckless late in the novel, when it becomes payback time for some of the story's most heinous characters. And Mr. Pelecanos, in letting Derek gruesomely humiliate a man who has disrespected a woman, risks letting his hero's avenging virtuousness go too far. Mr. Pelecanos also treads a thin line between cogent argument and oversimplification when he ascribes the woes of young men in "Soul Circus" to the lack of worthwhile father figures -- and lets Derek try to pick up that slack. But in the end, Derek proves as soul-stirring and eminently likable as his favorite songs.
"Soul Circus" provides some wrenching turns of plot, even as it assures the reader that this series is alive and well. Once again, Mr. Pelecanos ends a book with a clear, promising notion of where a subsequent one will start. And once again, he will leave readers eagerly awaiting his next move.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George P. Pelecanos (Erica Berger/Little, Brown)

HEADLINE: Riding a Bear Market in Oriental Carpets 

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
FOR anyone who has ever wanted an old Persian rug to warm up a favorite room, now may be the time to snag one. Thousands of old Oriental carpets will be on sale at reduced prices this month, many in the softer palette favored by designers this year.
 Sales will take place both downtown and uptown in Manhattan, with antique carpets that used to sell for $20,000 going for $10,000 or less. 
 Rosalind Candlin Benedict, a rug appraiser and consultant, advises patience, saying that finding the right one may mean plowing through stacks. Out of 100 old rugs, she said, "there are always only three or four lovely ones." 
Prices, she added, are returning to "normal" after years of inflation. "In the 90's, nothing was real," she said. 
Graham Head, president of the rug division at ABC Carpet & Home, concurs. "The days of Mrs. So-and-So coming into ABC and impulsively buying a $20,000 rug are over," he said. "The economy has finally forced prices to become realistic." Furthermore, he declared, rug prices are often determined by decorative value, except at the high end, where factors like age and quality come into play. 
Mr. Head will run a "liquidation" sale for some of his suppliers from March 6 to 23 featuring more than 2,000 rugs consigned to the store by a dozen longtime wholesalers. Prices will run from $499 for an old 3-by-5-foot Turkish carpet to $59,000 for a 14-by-20-foot Ferahan Sarouk. (The store is at 888 Broadway, at 19th Street; 212-473-3000.)
Many of the ABC suppliers, clustered in the area between Union Square and 34th Street, came to New York from Iran in the 1970's, bringing out their fortunes in rugs. They say that after a 25-year boom they are being squeezed by the shrinking market for old rugs, a victim of the recession not only in the United States but also in Europe, where many old rugs are bought from sources in the United States. 
The old-rug business has also been hurt by a trend toward modernist interiors and by the advent of high-quality new rugs produced using traditional weaving techniques, handspun wools and vegetable dyes.
Habib Soumekh, a fourth-generation dealer from Iran and the owner of Sohrab Oriental Rug on West 30th Street, said, "I'm in business 42 years, but I never had a year like this." 
Mr. Soumekh, who is supplying rugs to the ABC sale, will offer an early-20th-century Serapi, 10 by 15 feet, for $12,500; previously, he said, it was $25,000. His inventory also includes Kerman, Mahal, Tabriz and Heriz styles from the first half of the 20th century. 
ABC's staff will assist customers, and the store will earn a commission on each sale. 
On the Upper East Side, where high-end decorators and their clients tend to gravitate, two other Iranian dealers are pooling hundreds of rugs at a five-day sale that begins tomorrow. The dealers, Nader Bolour, the owner of Doris Leslie Blau, and David Amini, owner of Beauvais Carpets, will offer 1,000 new and antique rugs, starting at $700. A new Chinese-made Aubusson, 10 by 14 feet, formerly $6,600, is now $2,800. A 9-by-12-foot Heriz, woven in 1910 and formerly $16,000, will be $6,000. (The sale, at 969 Third Avenue, near 57th Street, will be held tomorrow and Sunday through Thursday; (212) 688-2229.)
The two dealers maintain that there is still a strong market for high-end rugs (over $50,000) but that they have a glut in the "midrange" (up to $30,000). 
Periodic "tent sales" at Bloomingdale's are also contributing to the downward pressure on prices. The store is advertising "thousands of handmade rugs" this month at discounts of 50 to 70 percent. 
"New rugs are our biggest competition," said Ellie Naja, a wholesaler who is consigning 300 old rugs to the ABC sale. "The new ones are unbelievable; sometimes we're confused ourselves." 
Many rug wholesalers operate in the style of an old-fashioned Mideastern carpet business, where prices are flexible. "Stack your rugs to the roof and let the customer choose," said Leslie Stroh, the editor of Rug News. At one showroom last week, a wholesaler sat alone amid carpets piled to the ceiling, with a humming tea kettle waiting to be pressed into service.
Dealers speak longingly of the 90's, when decorators and their clients shopped for patterns, not prices. During that era, a huge selection and a pot of tea were often enough to close a deal. But now, Mr. Stroh said, "the more rugs you have, the more dead inventory you have."
The desire to clean house reflects cultural changes as well. Owners of family businesses founded generations ago say their children, raised in the United States, are interested in other things. "I'm not a business-oriented person," said Mr. Soumekh's son Amir, 21. A senior at Columbia, Amir plans to attend the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in the fall. 
The Internet has modernized some aspects of the carpet business, especially among customers who like to use it for research. But selling expensive rugs is still largely an in-store experience. 
"We make very few sales over $2,000 on the Web," said Mr. Head of ABC, which sends digital images of rugs by e-mail to customers who like to get an idea of the selection. 
Internet aside, for many people, buying an antique Oriental carpet remains daunting, partly because it is difficult to judge claims, whether they involve the rug's quality, value or history.
Dealers clearly hope that by slashing prices they can stimulate a gambling spirit among those who have longed for a handwoven rug from another time and place and have simply been waiting for the right price.
It may be a great time to look, but in the words of Mr. Head, "bring your healthy dose of skepticism."

HEADLINE: Europeans Propose to End 'Open Skies' Deals 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The European Union moved today to strip its members of power to negotiate their own bilateral aviation agreements with outside nations and to replace those agreements with unionwide deals negotiated in Brussels.
 At the same time, the union's executive body, the European Commission, laid out a plan to reshape the airline industry on the Continent to make it easier for carriers to ally, merge or acquire one another and, the commission hopes, become more efficient and competitive. 
 The bilateral deals, known as "open skies" agreements, were thrown into doubt in November when the European Court of Justice ruled that eight of the agreements between member nations and the United States breached European Union law, because they gave national "flag" carriers an unfair advantage over rivals.
The commission said today that the court's ruling gave it the right to step in and formulate a unionwide policy, and it announced plans to negotiate a new unionwide agreement directly with the United States, the most important nonmember. 
"We will be able to ensure that the E.U. can finally pull together in this field and work to develop international air transport to the benefit of the industry and consumers," said Loyola de Palacio, the commissioner responsible for transportation.
The commission's plan would leave existing bilateral deals in place until they are replaced by unionwide agreements. Ms. de Palacio said that by clearing away the legal uncertainty surrounding the existing agreements, she hoped the commission would win rapid approval from member nations to begin talks with the United States, "our uppermost priority."
The national governments are expected to decide on the commission's plan by the end of June.
European airlines broadly welcomed the new proposals. "It's a step back from the more confrontational approach the commission took before," said David Henderson, spokesman for the Association of European Airlines. "The commission seems to accept the bilateral nature of many of these agreements, and the need to keep them in place for the time being." 
Even so, he said, the commission's proposals will have major ramifications for the industry, Mr. Henderson said.
One element in the proposal became inevitable after last November's court ruling: the scrapping of clauses in any bilateral agreements that grant automatic rights to fly certain routes to airlines designated as national flag carriers.
Analysts do not expect a sudden rush by the big national carriers to open routes on one anothers' traditional turfs -- say, Lufthansa flying trans-Atlantic routes out of Paris. That would probably be uneconomic in any case, said Nicholas van den Brul of BNP Paribas in London.
"Maybe the large European airlines could have one or two extra hubs for their long-haul flights," Mr. van den Brul said. "But a multihub arrangement doesn't really make sense." 
More likely, he said, would be mergers and combinations that would reshape the industry into a handful of large companies offering long-haul flights, and a second tier of short- and medium-haul carriers whose flights would feed passengers into the long-haul carriers' hubs. "If these proposals are adopted, it would make it easier for KLM to operate as a merger partner with British Airways or Air France," Mr. van den Brul said.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines is an example of a national carrier from a smaller nation with little domestic traffic. Such carriers have struggled in recent years, and a few, notably Sabena in Belgium, have collapsed. But efforts by KLM to team up with airlines from bigger nations have been hampered by the bilateral agreements, which restrict direct flights between the two nations to those nations' airlines. 
"This was one of the main reasons B.A. couldn't merge with KLM," Mr. van den Brul said -- the resulting airline would not qualify as Dutch-owned under the agreements.
The high costs and restricted routes of the traditional carriers have made it hard for them to compete with low-cost short-haul and medium-haul competitors like EasyJet and Ryanair, whose routes generally stay within the European Union, and several more of the old flag carriers are likely to shut down or be swallowed up, analysts said. But "not having so many flag carriers around doesn't automatically mean less choice," Mr. van den Brul said.

HEADLINE: MAKING AN ENTRANCE; 
High, Wide And Transomed

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AVERAGE American house size: down four square feet. Average American front door size: up seven square feet.
 The new American home, which has billowed by 50 percent since 1970 to 2,320 square feet, deflated gently in 2002, for the first time in seven years, according to a Department of Commerce report released last week. 
 Contributing to the cool-down in big houses, builders say, was a wave of first-time owners, spurred by low interest rates, buying small starter homes, and high-end homeowners staying put and not trading up because of economic and homeland security issues .
But one feature of new houses stands tall, and taller -- wider, too. 
It's the front door. That's "entryway" to you. A kind of one-trick pony that even the family forgets to use (the bell rings, you open it) the front door is currently the ambitious focus of dimension, design and dollars in the construction industry.
Once the point of heartfelt and humble, hand-grasping welcome, where the doormat greeted you, too, the new "decorative entry system" says "Welcome" from about 500 yards, with what looks like a portal into another dimension, not the foyer.
In strong evidence at the International Builders Show in Las Vegas last month, the package includes doors at least 8 feet tall and 3 1/2 feet wide, in pairs, with sidelights or windows, and a transom window above that can be taller than the doors. St. Peter's gates would be a side entrance in this world.
"It's the 'wow' appeal," said Joe Pompei, the owner of Pompei & Company, an entryway retailer in Medford, Mass. "In the past you would have picked up a typical Home Depot-type catalog door. Now, people are going way beyond that. It's a style statement." 
Mr. Pompei has executed entryways that cost as much as $40,000, including a stained-glass job that replicated a client's favorite Paul Klee painting. Builders report that an entryway can now be 10 percent of a construction budget. "The house started with the doors," said Lynn Bachman of her new home in Eden Prairie, Minn. Ms. Bachman, a food stylist whose clients include Pillsbury and Land O' Lakes, chose a pair of 12-foot-tall mahogany doors from a catalog, and customized them with four different types of glass. "An entry is a statement of the person who lives there," she said. "You need to come to a point in your life when you're self-actualized, and can exemplify that in design." Ms. Bachman went through a bad divorce; the house was built with stock earnings from an investment in Pfizer, the drug maker.
"I have no experience with Viagra," she said. "But when it went up, the house went up."
Mike Threlkeld, the president of Volunteer Lumber Sales, a door vendor in Knoxville, Tenn., summarized the appeal of the new entryways his way.
"You can see them from the road," he said.
Gopal Ahluwalia, a spokesman for the National Association of Home Builders, explained that though only 9 percent of Americans have double-door front entries, the price of the project had risen, to within a range of $2,500 to $25,000.
"You can't show off the inside of the house," Mr. Ahluwalia said. "What is visible is more critical to the homeowner than anything else. You could put gold bars between the walls and it wouldn't matter." The momentary stalemate in the size of the average house reflects, in part, a changing homeowner "who is interested in other things -- more quality and amenity -- a switch from 'bigger is better,' " he added.
Custom entryway companies like Pinecrest in Minneapolis, which has built doors for Tom Cruise, Prince Charles, George Clooney and Ms. Bachman, are being joined in the market by major wood-door manufacturers like Stanley, Morgan and Therma-Tru of Maumee, Ohio. Therma-Tru, the country's largest producer and seller of residential doors (three million a year), is introducing premium fiberglass front door combinations in exotic wood patterns through vendors like the Home Depot and Lowe's to capitalize on the increasing interest in a showcase entrance.
In a home valuation study commissioned by Therma-Tru in 2002, respondents added an average of 6 percent to the asking price of a home with an "enhanced entryway." The company's new Classic Craft entries, priced at $1,200 to $3,500, are up to 40 percent more expensive than its medium-range models.
"We're seeing customer willingness to spend more," said Dan Templeton, a vice president of Therma-Tru. "The perceived percentage of return on the investment beats out kitchen and bath improvements."
The industry standard for a front door, which is 3 feet by 6 feet 8 inches, has been steadily eclipsed in the last five years by examples that are in many cases keeping up with the scale of houses, entry halls in particular.
"You go into large homes, open the door, and you might be looking at a 32-foot ceiling; it used to be rare that it was 10," said Russell H. Underdahl, chairman of Pinecrest, which is at work on 400 doors for a royal family that he would not name.
"We've done a lot of work for a lot of kings," said Lorie Ingram, a president at Pinecrest and Mr. Underdahl's daughter. (A man's house is his castle: standing record, Johnny Cash's door, carved with a banjo and guitar and glazed with jade, not glass.)
Cantera Doors, a wrought-metal entryway specialist in Austin, Tex., sells the Infinity, a popular double door that is 6 feet by 10 feet of laser-cut steel with an optional stained-glass detail. It looks like Jimmy Stewart's fever dream in "Vertigo," costs $12,000 and weighs roughly 1,000 pounds.
New bride advisory: if he's carrying you, you're going to have to help push, if not pay.
"We can go 13 feet tall and 18 feet wide, but not in a hurricane area," said Mauricio Trevino, Cantera's founder and president. The nine-year-old company, which manufactures its doors in Mexico, as many of the big-door makers do, has annual residential sales of $8 million.
Mr. Trevino also voiced the "wow" factor, separating the "wow" into two syllables, like reverb. 
Cantera sold a $6,600, 800-pound wrought-iron entry, the Theater, with sidelights and a transom, to Dr. Zack Hillel, a cardiac anesthesiologist, and his wife, Dr. Anna Hillel, for their new colonial-style house in the Bronx. The doors have a vine motif and together weigh roughly 300 pounds -- sturdy enough for Tarzan to commute on.
"The builder was pretty impressed," said Dr. Hillel, who worries that the doors, without a hydraulic brake, could be capable of on-the-spot amputations. "You don't want to throw it against anyone's hand -- there would be no fingers." But, he explained, "it has the visual impact we wanted it to have."
In the lower registers of new housing, distinctive entryways are popular with developers eager to ring quick changes on tract housing. "Builders differentiate box architecture with different doors," Mr. Threlkeld said. "The doors set each home apart." He added that entryways can live a life of their own, without regard to the rest of the house, like family prodigies. Say, Tuscany opening onto Craftsman.
"Let's just put it this way," he said. "We've sold doors where my personal taste didn't think the styleof the door suited the style of the house."
Entryways have also proved popular with remodelers, as front doors provide a double-edge face-off with neighbors, a jambing up with the Joneses. "Welcome to our (more impressive) home -- and how do you get into yours?"
"A lot of the entries I'm selling right now are people ripping out the junk and upgrading," said Mr. Pompei, who gets multiple assignments on single streets.
Robin Kopit, the founder of Extraordinary Doors in Santa Cruz, Calif., thinks the custom entry is an ambassador of goodwill. Mr. Kopit's average job is $8,000 to $10,000. He recently installed two 1,500-pound mahogany front doors with bronze grills, measuring 10 feet by 4 feet and 7 inches thick, for a couple in Los Altos, Calif. He executed something similar at the back of the house. The woodwork alone cost $80,000.
"My dad said, 'Did they really pay you that?' " Mr. Kopit said. "It's a little bit of showoff, but you walk through your door every day," he said. "It creates a positive wave in your day."
Make that a tsunami.

HEADLINE: A Japanese Theme Park Company Fails 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The Huis Ten Bosch Company, one of Japan's largest theme park operators, has declared bankruptcy, highlighting the mounting troubles in the country's vast government-financed recreation industry.
 The collapse of the company, with debt of 220 billion yen ($1.8 billion), is the latest evidence of the breakdown between local governments and Japan's commercial banks, which together helped build many parks in the 1980's and 1990's. 
 For years, local governments have pressed banks not to exit the projects, so lenders continued to funnel money into unprofitable businesses. The long decline in real estate prices and mounting nonperforming loans, however, have left many banks little choice but to exit these projects. 
Huis Ten Bosch, which means house in the forest in Dutch, was one of the largest such ventures. Opened in 1992, the park is modeled on the 17th-century Dutch enclave in Nagasaki and was financed largely by Mizuho Holdings Inc., Nagasaki Prefecture and a consortium of three dozen companies. Mizuho Holdings, Japan's largest bank by assets, may not recover the 102.3 billion yen it lent to Huis Ten Bosch, though it added that the potential loss should not affect its earnings.
The park's failure is the legacy of a government-led expansion into local areas. In the 1980's, lawmakers in Tokyo, eager to send money back to their home prefectures, urged banks and local governments to build resorts, golf courses and other recreational developments. Tokyo gave local governments extra handouts, and banks, assuming the projects had government guarantees, made additional loans.
Many projects, though, turned out to be white elephants based on optimistic assumptions about the economy, tourism and what Japanese consumers would pay for a vacation. When the asset-inflated economy of the 1980's ended, Japanese started cutting back on spending on nonessentials and seeking bargains rather than luxury. Attendance has fallen 7 percent since 1996, when the park attracted 3.8 million visitors.
At the same time, more Japanese were traveling overseas, particularly to the United States and other parts of Asia, as the cost of international air fares fell. A round-trip ticket from Tokyo to Los Angeles costs about as much as two nights at a Japanese hot spring. The long slide in land prices has also saddled many of the so-called third-sector companies, which are jointly held by local governments and private companies, with an estimated 10 trillion yen ($83 billion) in nonperforming assets.
With the economy showing few signs of life, more of these resorts are likely to fail under the weight of their debts in the coming years.
"In a deflationary environment, these parks can't survive," said Kunji Okue, an economist with Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. "It's only a matter of time before more fail."
The collapse of Huis Ten Bosch comes two years after the Phoenix Resort Company went bankrupt, with 326 billion yen in debt. That company ran the Seagaia resort in Miyazaki Prefecture, also on the southern island of Kyushu. Both projects were extravagant. Seagaia, on the Pacific Coast, has golf courses and an indoor beach. Huis Ten Bosch has 4 hotels, 40 restaurants and 65 shops.
Both resorts were financed in part by large commercial banks. Most other projects, however, involve smaller regional banks that have closer ties to local governments. These banks are less able to handle losses stemming from a big bankruptcy and are being compelled not to abandon the resorts.
"Local governments are pressuring small banks to stay in the business even though they are not doing well," said Satoru Shinozuka, an analyst with Teikoku Databank, a private research company that tracks bankruptcies.
The failure of these theme parks represents an opportunity for some investors who want to overhaul the businesses. Seagaia was purchased by the American investment fund Ripplewood Holdings. Goldman, Sachs and others have bought up golf courses and hotels.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Huis Ten Bosch, the operator of an amusement park that opened in 1992 modeled on the 17th-century Dutch enclave in Nagasaki, has filed for bankruptcy, with debt of 220 billion yen ($1.8 billion). (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
First, a Moderate Advance; Then, Another Big Sell-Off

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors held to their pattern of retreating after even a moderate advance, sending shares sharply lower yesterday amid continuing concerns about Iraq. Hewlett-Packard's report of weaker-than-expected revenue contributed to the decline, which more than wiped out the previous session's gain. 
 The downturn was not surprising as sell-offs have been the norm for weeks. Analysts say stocks cannot be expected to move upward until it is clear whether there will be a war with Iraq. 
 "We are just sort of battening down the hatches and trying to figure out what is going to go on in the Middle East," said John C. Forelli, portfolio manager for Independence Investment in Boston. "The hope in the back of everyone's minds is there is a quick resolution and that businesses and consumers start spending again and give investors some faith in the market." 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 102.52 points, or 1.3 percent, at 7,806.98, erasing Tuesday's gain of 51.26 points. It was the Dow's second triple-digit loss in three days, after Monday's decline of 159.87. 
The broader market also retreated. The Nasdaq index fell 25.30 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,303.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 11.02 points, or 1.3 percent, to 827.55. 
Selling has dominated Wall Street in 2003, with the only exception being a short-lived New Year's rally. Many analysts do not expect investors' mood to improve until there is a resolution regarding Iraq. 
"I have rarely seen this much pessimism not turn into a rally," said Mike Weiner, managing director of equities at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. "But it is just hard to be positive." 
Analysts said investors were still smarting from the bigger-than-expected drop in consumer confidence reported on Tuesday. Consumer confidence in February fell to its lowest level since October 1983. 
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday that the plunge in confidence was "a very significant decline" but not a surprise. 
Disappointing earnings reports contributed to yesterday's slippage. Hewlett-Packard dropped $2.81, to $15.37, having reported quarterly earnings late Tuesday that met analysts' expectations but revenue that missed forecasts. 
Shares in Eaton Vance, the mutual fund and investment management company, declined 87 cents, to $25.23, after the company reported quarterly per share earnings that were 3 cents short of analysts' expectations. 
Gainers included the retailer Urban Outfitters, which rose $1.60, to $18.60, after its stock was upgraded to buy from neutral.

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Reuters) -- Treasury prices rose yesterday, as an auction of new short-term notes drew surprisingly strong demand. 
The $27 billion auction of two-year notes drew bids for two times the amount on offer. That demand came despite the notes going at 1.575 percent, the lowest yield ever in a two-year auction, beating the previous 1.71 percent.
The 10-year note increased 14/32, to a price of 100 28/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.77 percent from 3.82 percent. 
The 30-year bond increased 23/32, to 109 26/32. Its yield fell to 4.74 percent from 4.78 percent.

PERSON: BERLY ELLIS 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Perky, Blond and as Inescapable as Paying the Fare

BYLINE:  By CHRIS HEDGES 

 BODY:
TRUST someone to find a way to intrude on one of the few places left in New York where you can have an intellectual discussion with a stranger behind the wheel, and you get the idea behind putting televisions in taxis.
 Or, to steal the language from one company, TaxiVu, now shooting 28-minute segments for their taxi televisions, advertisers can deliver a "30-second commercial to a captive audience." 
 So now those heated discussions about a Sikh homeland, the perfidy of the Nigerian government, the best place to buy Egyptian falafel or tirades about the collapse of the Russian economy are being replaced with promos for restaurants, insurance firms, television shows and movies, and cheesy music. And, in a formula as old as television itself, a perky blond hostess with a thousand-watt grin and the enthusiasm of a Midwestern cheerleader will gush to us about the various ways we can spend our money. 
Berly Ellis, 27, whose glossy photo and resume assures her prospective employers that she is "a natural blonde," is the hostess for TaxiVu, a company that now has screens in 350 cabs, or perhaps 349, given that a cab flagged down on Sunday that carried the program did not have a working television screen. She is slowly working her way through the city's affluent neighborhoods, visiting this store and that shop, all the while insisting, although she is waiflike, how much she likes to eat. Indeed, the fact that she likes to eat has become something of the motif of the segments, all filmed in a day in places like Chelsea or the Upper West Side.
"By now you know how much I love to eat," she said in one segment, assuming that viewers have followed the previous segments.
Ms. Ellis is not a New Yorker. She grew up in Hershey, Pa. Her father, a jeweler, provides the jewelry she wears on the videos. Her name, Berly, is short for Kimberly. She majored at Pennsylvania State University in business and theater, with a minor in kinesiology, the branch of science that deals with the mechanics of human bodily movement, but which she said was the closest dance majors at her school could come to having a dance concentration.
"It was a mix of pre-med and dance," she said of her minor, seated in a restaurant in the Upper East Side sipping a glass of tap water.
She moved to Spanish Harlem, where she still lives with her roommate, also an aspiring actress, and has had a series of very minor roles. Her biggest moments of fame came as a student tutor, a nonspeaking part, in "A Beautiful Mind" and a role in a crowd scene in the movie "Liberty Heights."
"Ifyou squint your eyes really hard I think you can see my yellow beret in the ice skating scene," she said.
And then came TaxiVu -- not Hollywood, but for her a huge step up. She started to keep a file of all her friends who had seen her in a cab, "but then it got to be too many." She said some cabdrivers had waved to her and frequent cab riders had recognized her and called her the taxi girl.
She looks at the taped segments, which she calls episodes, as a public service.
"We promote businesses, restaurants, designers and musicians," she said, "all the things that make New York great."
She rarely gets more than two minutes on screen before being interrupted by a commercial, although it is hard to tell where the commercial ends and the show begins.
FOR example, on a backstage tour of the Loew's 34th Street Showplace she praises the marvels of the theater, assuring viewers that "with 18,000 watts of pure six-channel Surroundsound, the only thing that might compare to watching the film here is actually living the experience, but just barely."
The television screen starts as soon as the meter comes on. There is a mute button, but the picture cannot be turned off. When the 28-minute segment is finished the screen goes dead.
"You don't have to watch it again," she said.
The videos, which at times look a bit like home movies, do not pay the bills. She works as an events coordinator for a marketing firm. She works out in her home gym, and lists as her hobbies a variety of activities from figure skating and swing dance to studying "royal etiquette," helpful to an actress "for period pieces." She said she speaks some French, but added "now is not the best time in the world to practice French because people might throw things at you."
She objects to reality television, she said, "because it is not really good for families to watch."
She is as perky in person as she is in a cab. Her thin shoulders bob up and down. She pushes her blond hair behind her right ear. She frequently flashes her flawless smile. And she folds and unfolds her fingers, several covered with rings including a color-changing garnet. 
She reads fantasy books by Terry Goodkind, whom she calls "a phenomenal writer," although she also recently read a book on Islam by "two brothers from the Middle East."
"I chose to read it because it was authentic," she said.
But mostly life is about her dream of acting. And each new segment for TaxiVu, she hopes, will propel her into the world of theater and film.
"I want to do two films a year and two or three Off Broadway or Broadway plays a year," she said "like most actors."

GRAPHIC: Photo: BERLY ELLIS (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Moves to Raise Birth Rate and Draw Richer Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Local leaders announced today that they would begin accepting immigrants based partly on their wealth and talents and would adjust tax policies to encourage families to have more babies.
 "We want to upgrade the quality of the population," said Donald Tsang, the administration's chief secretary. 
 The immigration and tax policies, similar to Singapore's, are part of a flurry of changes here as Tung Chee-hwa, the territory's chief executive, has pursued closer integration with mainland China in response to economic weakness here. 
Mr. Tung's administration introduced tough internal security legislation to Hong Kong's Legislative Council today, as planned, and announced on Tuesday that it would cut welfare benefits and civil servants' pay in response to the declining cost of living. 
Mr. Tsang, the second-highest official after Mr. Tung, said at a news conference that the government would also impose a tax of about $50 a month on employers of foreign domestic helpers. The minimum wage for such helpers would be reduced by an equal amount, to $420 a month, although some already earn considerably more than that. 
Hong Kong's population of 7 million includes nearly 240,000 foreign maids, mainly from the Philippines, and they are encountering resentment because of high unemployment among native-born residents. 
The proceeds from the tax are to be used for further training of the native-born. The financial penalty for employing foreigners may prompt some employers to hire Hong Kong citizens who can no longer find work because many factories have moved to the mainland.
Immigration policies have long been controversial here, especially the rate at which this former British colony, now a fairly autonomous Chinese territory, allows mainland residents to settle here permanently -- 150 a day, almost all spouses or children of current Hong Kong residents.
Despite this emphasis on the reunification of families, mainland residents can wait up to a decade for permission to move here. There has been heavy intermarriage across the border since Britain handed over Hong Kong to China in 1997.
Businesses have been frustrated that this makes it hard for them to transfer experienced professionals here if they are mainland citizens . Under the new rules that Mr. Tsang announced tonight, a new category will be created for mainland managers and professionals to move here.
Immigrants will also be allowed to settle here if they invest at least $833,000. But mainland citizens will be excluded from the program because China's currency is not fully convertible and because Beijing has been wary of letting Hong Kong turn into a tax haven for the wealthy. 
Singapore, Australia, Canada, Britain and other countries also have special immigration rules for people who invest large sums, and there have been periodic discussions in Washington over whether the United States should adopt that approach.
Mr. Tsang recommended that the government offer the same tax deductions for all children and end the current policy of offering smaller deductions for third and subsequent children. While Hong Kong remains one of the most crowded cities on earth, it has become concerned with a steep decline in its birth rate. On average, 10 women here give birth to a total of just 9 babies in their lifetimes, compared with the 21 babies that would typically be needed for a self-sustaining population.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
New, Improved Hall Panel Elects No One

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A revolutionary change in the Baseball Hall of Fame's veterans committee produced no new members of the Hall yesterday. The new, expanded committee elected no former players and no former managers, umpires or executives, including Marvin Miller, who had headed the players union.
 If anyone had been given a chance with the 85-man committee, which included 58 members of the Hall of Fame, it was Miller, who led the players to unparalleled freedom and economic gain as the union's executive director from 1966 to 1981. 
 Neither Miller nor any of the 40 others on the two ballots really came close to the 75 percent needed for election. The closest was Gil Hodges, who led the 26-player ballot with 50 of 81 votes, or 62 percent. Miller had 35 votes and needed 60 of 79 votes on the ballot in the composite category of former managers, umpires and executives. 
Joe Morgan, vice chairman of the Hall and a Hall of Fame second baseman during Miller's tenure as labor chief, said he thought Miller was going to be elected.
"There were players voting and Marvin Miller changed the landscape for players," Morgan said in a conference call with Hall of Fame officials. "I figured a lot of players would vote for him. I'm shocked that his total wasn't higher than it was." 
When it was suggested to Miller on his own conference call that his chances of election would grow as recent players gain admission to the Hall and vote on the veterans committee, he said: "In a month I'll be 86. Under present rules there will not be another election for four years. Don't count on it."
Of the 15 candidates on the composite ballot, the longtime National League umpire Doug Harvey was the surprising leading vote-getter with 48 votes, or 61 percent, but he fell 12 votes short of the required 60. Walter O'Malley, who took the Dodgers out of Brooklyn to Los Angeles and opened the entire country to baseball, was next with 38 votes, or 48 percent. Miller was third with 35 votes, or 44 percent.
Hodges, the former Dodgers first baseman and Mets manager, was followed on the players' ballot by Tony Oliva with 48 votes (59 percent), Ron Santo with 46 votes (57 percent) and Joe Torre with 29 votes (36 percent).
Some people thought Torre's success in recent years as the Yankees' manager would enhance his chances of election, but he did not get even half of the 61 votes needed.
"It should be hard to make it to the Hall of Fame," Torre said at the Yankees' spring training camp in Tampa, Fla. "It's a special place for those reasons, and I think the committee, made up the way it is, they certainly are not going to be easy about letting people in because they know how hard it was to get there."
Morgan echoed that view. "I think a lot of players did look at it that way," he said. "Did this guy deserve to be in Cooperstown with the other immortals? That's the way to judge them."
Torre, an active union member when he played, also said he would like to have seen some candidates make it, Miller first and foremost.
Of the 53 Hall of Fame players on the committee, 41 played during Miller's tenure as the head of the union. But not all of those 41 players voted for Miller. In fact, at least 10 most likely did not.
The committee, which replaced the old 15-member veterans committee, was made up of 58 Hall of Famers, 25 writers and broadcasters who won awards linked to the Hall and two members of the old committee whose terms have not expired.
The Hall of Fame overhauled the veterans' voting because the old committee had encountered charges of cronyism. Much work went into the change, and Hall of Fame officials expected at least some candidates to be elected.
Miller had been ignored by the old committee and was given a strong chance for election once his name was placed on the ballot.
"It seems to me they may have to go back to the drawing board with their procedure," Miller said in a telephone interview immediately after the results were announced. "It's not just that they elected nobody; the old veterans committee did that once or twice. But if you make a big fanfare of having a new, better procedure and end up with zero people, I think you better go back to the drawing board. 
"If you're going to have zero people, you don't need the procedure," Miller added. "To me, that would mean the next time they have an election like this, it should only be among the people who didn't appear on this ballot. It's ridiculous to say let's do this again for the people who have been retired for many years and failed to get the necessary votes."
Hall of Fame officials rejected the idea that it makes no sense to repeat the procedure in two years for the players and four years for the managers, umpires and executives.
"I think we need at least one more election before we see where we go," said Jane Forbes Clark, the Hall's chairwoman.
Morgan likened this election to the experience some players have in the Baseball Writers Association balloting. Players are eligible for that ballot for 15 years, beginning five years after they retire.
"If a guy doesn't get voted in the first round, it doesn't mean he's not going to be voted in," Morgan said. "You have to give the process a chance.
"This was the committee's first time at bat," Morgan added. "We have to give them another at-bat, one more shot. If nothing happens two years from now, I think I'll have something to say."
But Morgan offered another thought. 
"Maybe not as many people fell through the cracks as people think," he said, alluding to the baseball writers' ballot. "We think there have been some, but maybe there haven't been any. Maybe the writers have done a pretty good job."
